Dear Sirs:

We are enclosing copy of our invoice of June 10, $535.50 which is outstanding on our books. According to our records, this seems to be in order but if there is anything wrong with it, we will be glad to have your advice. Otherwise, we trust it will be possible to have it passed for payment in the near future.

Yours very truly,

MARSHALL WELLS ALTA. CO. LTD.

L. Hallman
Credit Manager

Encl.
Reverend Madam:

The galvanized iron pipe which was supplied to the Holy Angels Residential School during the past summer was purchased from Marshall Wells Alberta Company Limited, Edmonton.

This firm sent their account to you and it was expected that you would certify the account and forward it to the Department for payment. We have not yet received this account and as a result the firm has not been paid and they are urging us to issue cheque. I understand that you have received the pipe and no doubt it is satisfactory. You should, therefore, certify the account and forward it to me immediately.

Yours truly,

REPORT ON A SURVEY OF THE SANITARY CONDITIONS AT THE ROMAN CATHOLIC MISSION AT FORT CHIPPEWYAN, ALTA.

Date - July 7 and 8, 1938

Fort Chipewyan is an old trading post of the Hudson's Bay Company situated at the western end of Lake Athabasca near the mouth of the Athabasca River. The white population totals about 100 people and several resident Indian families. From 500 to 600 Indians live in the vicinity and occasionally come to camp at the Fort when Treaty is being paid and also to trade and obtain supplies.

The Roman Catholic Mission is located just west of the settlement at the head of a shallow bay encircled by isolated rocky ledges. It consists of a residential school for Indian children, the oldest part of which was constructed in 1874, a church, priest's residence, stable and barn and numerous other outbuildings in addition. During the winter months the school is occupied by about 100 children and more stay on during the summer so that provision has to be made for adequate quantities of water for domestic purposes throughout the year.

With the assistance of one of the brothers examination was made of the sources of water supply and methods of sewage and garbage disposal.

Water Supply

The main source of supply is from Lake Athabasca, being pumped during the summer and hauled on sleighs from holes through the ice during the winter. The water intake is situated in front of the school at the end of a wooden wharf, the intake line consisting of 1-inch galvanized iron pipe with a foot valve. A small gasoline driven plunger pump discharges the water through a pipe line to 5 or 6 covered steel barrels in the kitchen. This water is used for all purposes including drinking and culinary in the new state.

During the winter, holes must be cut through the ice further out in the lake and the water hauled to the school on sleighs in the barrels. The summer consumption is estimated to vary from 400 to 600 gallons per day and the winter consumption 200 gallons daily.

The level of Lake Athabasca is controlled to a great extent by the levels of the Peace and Athabasca Rivers and shows quite a wide fluctuation. This frequently results in the
present water intake becoming stranded and to overcome this, 2,000 feet of 1½-inch galvanized iron pipe have been obtained and will be extended along the base of the west side of the bay out to deeper water (Photo No. 4). This pipe has to be taken up before winter sets in to avoid destruction or loss by drifting ice.

Sources of possible sewage pollution are all of local origin. The Athabasca River is highly turbid during the summer months carrying in suspension considerable quantities of clay and sand. Though practically all the residents in the settlement use the outdoor pit privy, none of which is closer than 100 feet to the lake and consequently all the surface drainage which may contain human sewage as well as dog droppings and other matter, is toward the lake with the drift towards the mission intake. The outer end of the boat dock is popular for bathing by children and consequently casual pollution may be expected from this source (Photo No. 1).

Another possible source of sewage pollution is the Indian camps perched on the bare rocks adjacent to the water intake area (Photo No. 4).

In my opinion the lake at this point is quite unsatisfactory as a source of drinking water supply during the summer.

A second source of supply is a shallow well in the rear of the mission which is at the present only being used by the stables. The well is about 600 feet from the main kitchen and about 250 feet from the stable and at a lower elevation. It adjoins the gardens and fields used for hay and clover crops and is about the only available site for a well in the vicinity because of the light overburden on the underlying rocks. The well is about 4 feet square and 24 feet deep, being lined with rock. The lower 18 feet is filled with impervious 3 feet thick overlying a waterbearing stratum of mixed clay and gravel. The top of the well is protected from surface drainage and a ditch between it and the stable carries off the drainage around it. There is both a small gasoline driven plunger pump and a hand pump which may be used to pump the water to the kitchen or stable. These are housed in a small wooden structure (Photo No. 5).

This well is exclusively used by the mission during the breaking up or freezing over of the lake when the pumped supply is not available. It is reported to produce an ample quantity although its use for drinking and culinary purposes has been objected to because of the taste which is somewhat mineral although not entirely disagreeable. The laboratory report on one specimen obtained was favourable (Table No. 1).

A third source of water supply frequently used is a slough several hundred yards back of the mission which is removed from sources of human sewage pollution (Photo No. 6). This source of supply appears to be quite suitable for all domestic purposes but unfortunately the quantity available
varies considerably from year to year so that it can only be used as an auxiliary supply. It might be feasible to develop this supply by building a low earthen dam at the lower end and laying down a temporary pipe line and pump, to the mission property.

A number of water specimens were collected for bacteriological analysis, the results of which were reported as follows:

**TABLE NO. 1**

Date of collection - July 8, 1939

1. **From Lake Athabasca at outer end of Fort Chipewyan dock**
   
   Number of organisms per c.c. - too numerous to count.
   Presence of organisms indicating unfavourable contamination - Positive
   Laboratory comment - plate count gives more than 3,000 bacteria per c.c. All five 10 c.c. portions and one of five 1.0 c.c. portions show B. coli of intestinal type.

2. **Shallow well at Roman Catholic Mission**
   
   Number of organisms per c.c. - 20
   Presence of organisms indicating unfavourable contamination - Negative
   Laboratory comment - this water appears to be of good quality and shows no evidence of unfavourable contamination in standard samples tested.

3. **Slough in rear of Roman Catholic Mission**
   
   No. of organisms per c.c. - 400
   Presence of organisms indicating unfavourable contamination - Negative
   Laboratory comment - this water appears to be of good quality and shows no evidence of unfavourable contamination in standard samples tested.

4. **Water Intake, Lake Athabasca, at Roman Catholic Mission**
   
   Number of organisms per c.c. - 500
   Presence of organisms indicating unfavourable contamination - Positive
   Laboratory comment - B. coli of intestinal type in all tubes of standard samples. Unsuitable for drinking purposes in raw state.

**Sewage Disposal**

During the summer months outside toilet buildings are used, one for each sex (Photos Nos. 7 and 8). These are frame structures erected over dug pits and have a number of rows of stalls in each with seats having no covers. The
buildings are poorly lighted and maintained, and no effort has been made to use screens and prevent the entrance of flies.

The location of these toilets is such as not to endanger any source of water supply and the light sandy soil in their vicinity appears to be suitable for their functioning although chlorinated lime could be used to good effect to reduce odors and partially disinfect the contents.

For night use and during the winter months pail type toilets are located at convenient points on each floor of the school, the contents being disposed of by emptying into the boy's outdoor toilet during the winter and being buried in a hole in the ground near the girl's toilet in the summer.

Garbage Disposal

All garbage is suitably disposed of by being fed to the animals, much of it being boiled in a stock pot and given to the chickens. Other refuse and rubbish is destroyed by burning and there were no nuisances or menace to health observed in this connection.

Conclusions and Recommendations

(a) Water Supply

It is recommended that Lake Athabasca be discontinued as a source of drinking water for the school during the summer months as the amount of local pollution to which it is subjected renders it unsafe for this purpose unless it is either boiled or chlorinated and filtered as well.

It would appear that the slough behind the mission could be further developed as a source of water supply by installing a summer pumping system.

The water of the shallow well also appears to be of good sanitary quality although possibly exposed at times to drainage from the stables and should be further developed for use during the winter months.

Filling both of these supplies it would also be possible to put up ice and store it for use as drinking and culinary water during the summer time.

After freeze up has occurred the water in the outlet channel of the lake is probably of safe sanitary quality so that it could be used as at present in being hauled from water holes. The provision of a pumping system for this purpose would hardly be practicable as it would require a heated pumping house to protect the pump and the heating of at least 3,000 feet of pipe line to prevent freezing up. It would also be necessary to remove this installation every spring to prevent loss or damage from drifting ice.
Since Fort Chipewyan is situated within the Province of Alberta, it is suggested that the Mission make arrangements with the Department of Public Health for frequent analysis of all water supplies used by them for drinking and culinary purposes.

(b) Sewage Disposal

The present use of the outdoor pit privy appears to be functioning quite well in principle.

It is recommended that window openings should be provided for the toilet buildings to lighten the interiors and that the walls and floors should be frequently whitewashed or painted white and always maintained in a clean condition. All ventilators, windows, and other openings should be fully screened to prevent the entrance of flies native to the vicinity and thus prevent the possible transmission of infection by this means.

Chloride of lime should be made available in ample quantities for dusting into the toilet pits in order to prevent local malaria conditions and also to disinfect the contents. Chloride of lime or other equally efficient disinfectant should also be used in all the pit type toilets located in the school.

(SGD) A.H. Ferry
District Engineer.

After freeze up has occurred the water in the outlet channel of the lake is probably of safe sanitary quality so that it could be used as at present in being hauled from water holes. The provision of a pumping system for this purpose would hardly be practicable as it would require a heated pumphouse to protect the incoming ice and the heating of perhaps 3,000 feet of pipe line to prevent freezing up. It would also be necessary to remove this installation every spring to prevent loss or damage from drifting ice.
Since Fort Chipewyan is situated within the Province of Alberta it is suggested that the Mission make arrangements with the Department of Public Health for frequent analysis of all water supplies used by them for drinking and culinary purposes.

(b) Sewage Disposal

The present use of the outdoor pit privy appears to be functioning quite well in principle.

It is recommended that window openings should be provided for the toilet buildings to lighten the interiors and that the walls and floors should be frequently washed or painted white and always maintained in a clean condition. All ventilators, windows, and other openings should be fully screened to prevent the entrance of flies native to the vicinity and thus prevent the possible transmission of infection by this means.

Chloride of lime should be made available in ample quantities for dusting into the toilet pits in order to prevent foul nuisance conditions and also to disinfect the contents. Chloride of lime or other equally efficient disinfectant should also be used in all the pail type toilets located in the school.

REPORT ON A SURVEY OF THE SANITARY CONDITIONS AT
THE ROMAN CATHOLIC MISSION AT FORT CHIPPEWAN, ALTA.

Date - July 7 and 8, 1938

Fort Chipewyan is an old trading post of the Hudson's Bay Company, situated at the western end of Lake Athabasca near the mouth of the Athabasca River. The white population totals about 100, together with several resident Indian families. From 200 to 300 Indians live in the vicinity and occasionally come to camp at the Fort when Treaty is being paid and also to trade and obtain supplies.

The Roman Catholic Mission is located just west of the settlement at the head of a shallow bay encircled by glaciated rocky ledges. It consists of a residential school for Indian children, the oldest part of which was constructed in 1874, a church, priest's residence, stable and barn and numerous other outbuildings in connection. During the winter months the school is occupied by about 100 children who remain there on during the summer months provision has to be made for adequate quantities of water for domestic purposes throughout the year.

With the assistance of one of the brothers examination was made of the sources of water supply and methods of sewage and garbage disposal.

Water Supply

The main source of supply is from Lake Athabasca, being pumped during the summer and hauled on sleighs from holes through the ice during the winter. The water intake is situated in front of the school at the end of a wooden wharf, the intake line consisting of 1½-inch galvanized iron pipe with a foot valve. A small gasoline driven hand pump discharges the water through a 1-inch pipe into 5 or 6 concrete steel barrels in the kitchen. This water is used for all purposes including drinking and culinary in the raw state.

During the winter, holes must be cut through the ice further out on the lake and the water hauled to the school on sleighs in the barges. The summer consumption is estimated to vary from 400 to 600 gallons per day and the winter consumption 200 gallons daily.

The level of Lake Athabasca is controlled to a great extent by the levels of the Peace and Athabasca Rivers and shows quite a wide fluctuation. This frequently results in the
present water intake becoming stranded and to overcome this, 2,000 feet of 1½-inch galvanized iron pipe have been obtained and will be extended along the base of the west side of the bay out to deeper water (Photo No. 4). This pipe has to be taken up before winter sets in to avoid destruction or loss by drifting ice.

Sources of possible sewage pollution are all of local origin. The Athabasca River is highly turbid during the summer months carrying in suspension considerable quantities of clay and sand. Though practically all the residents of the settlement use the common outdoor privy to the north of the lake shore, nevertheless which is near the surface drainage which may contain human sewage as well as dog droppings and other matter, is toward the lake with the drift towards the mission intake. The outer end of the boat dock is popular for bathing by children and consequently casual pollution may be expected from this source. (Photo No. 1).

Another possible source of sewage pollution is the Indian camps pitched on the bare rocks adjacent to the water intake area (Photo No. 4).

In my opinion the lake at this point is quite unsatisfactory as a source of drinking water supply during the summer.

A second source of supply is a shallow well in the rear of the mission which is at the present only being used for the stables. This well is about 500 feet from the school kitchen and about 30 feet from the stables and at a lower elevation. It adjoins the gardens and fields used for hay and clover crops and is about the only available site for a well in the vicinity because of the light overburden on the underlying rocks. The well is about 4 feet square with the walls and ditch being lined with rocks. The low-lying stratum of impervious clay 10 feet thick overlies a waterbearing stratum of mixed clay and gravel. The top of the well is protected from surface drainage and a ditch between it and the stables carries off the drainage around it. There is both a small gasoline driven plunge pump and a hand pump which may be used to pump the water to the kitchen or stable. These are housed in a small wooden structure. (Photo No. 5).

This well is exclusively used by the mission during the breaking up or freezing over of the lake when the pumped supply is not sufficient. It is reported to produce an ample quantity although its use for drinking and culinary purposes has been objected to because of the taste which is somewhat mineral although not entirely disagreeable. The laboratory report on one specimen obtained was favourable. (Photo No. 1).

A third source of water supply frequently used is a slough several hundred yards back of the mission which is removed from sources of human sewage pollution (Photo No. 6). This source of supply appears to be quite suitable for all domestic purposes but unfortunately the quantity available
varies considerably from year to year so that it can only be used as an auxiliary supply. It might be feasible to develop this supply by building a low earthen dam at the lower end and laying down a temporary pipe line and pump, to the mission property.

A number of water specimens were collected for bacteriological analysis, the results of which were reported as follows:

**TABLE NO. 1**

Date of collection - July 6, 1938

1. **From Lake Athabasca at cut or end of Fort Chipewyan dock**
   
   Number of organisms per c.c. - too numerous to count.
   Presence of organisms indicating unfavourable contamination - Positive
   Laboratory comment - plate count gives more than 3,000 bacteria per c.c. All five 10 c.c. portions and one of five 1.0 c.c. portions show E. coli of intestinal type.

2. **Shallow well at Roman Catholic Mission**
   
   Number of organisms per c.c. - 20
   Presence of organisms indicating unfavourable contamination - Negative
   Laboratory comment - this water appears to be of good quality and shows no evidence of unfavourable contamination in standard samples tested.

3. **Slough in rear of Roman Catholic Mission**
   
   No. of organisms per c.c. - 400
   Presence of organisms indicating unfavourable contamination - Negative
   Laboratory comment - this water appears to be of good quality and shows no evidence of unfavourable contamination in standard samples tested.

4. **Water Intake, Lake Athabasca, at Roman Catholic Mission**
   
   Number of organisms per c.c. - 500
   Presence of organisms indicating unfavourable contamination - Positive
   Laboratory comment - E. coli of intestinal type in all tubes of standard samples. Unsuitable for drinking purposes in raw state.

**Sewage Disposal**

During the summer months outside toilet buildings are used, one for each sex (Photos Nos. 7 and 8). These are frame structures erected over dug pits and have a number of rows of stalls in each with seats having no covers. The
buildings are poorly lighted and maintained, and no effort has been made to use screens and prevent the entrance of flies.

The location of these toilets is such as not to endanger any source of water supply and the light sandy soil in their vicinity appears to be suitable for their functioning although chloride of lime could be used to good effect to reduce odors and partially disinfect the contents.

For night use and during the winter months pail type toilets are located at convenient points on each floor of the school, the contents being disposed of by emptying into the boy's outdoor toilet during the winter and being buried in a hole in the ground near the girl's toilet in the summer.

Garbage Disposal

All garbage is suitably disposed of by being fed to the animals, much of it being boiled in a stock pot and given to the chickens. Other refuse and rubbish is destroyed by burning and there were no nuisances or menace to health observed in this connection.

Conclusions and Recommendations

(a) Water Supply

It is recommended that Lake Athabasca be discontinued as a source of drinking water for the school during the summer months as the amount of local pollution to which it is subjected renders it unsafe for this purpose unless it is either boiled or chlorinated and filtered as well.

It would appear that the slough behind the mission could be further developed as a source of water supply by installing a summer pumping system.

The water of the shallow well also appears to be of good sanitary quality although possibly exposed at times to drainage from the stables and should be further developed for use during the winter months.

Failing both of these supplies it would also be possible to put up ice and store it for use as drinking and culinary water during the summer time.

After freeze up has occurred the water in the outlet channel of the lake is probably of safe sanitary quality so that it could be used as at present in being hauled from water holes. The provision of a pumping system for this purpose would hardly be practicable as it would require a heated pump house set up over the channel ice and the heating of at least 3,000 feet of pipe line to prevent freezing up. It would also be necessary to remove this installation every spring to prevent loss or damage from drifting ice.
Since Fort Chipewyan is situated within the Province of Alberta it is suggested that the Mission make arrangements with the Department of Public Health for frequent analysis of all water supplies used by them for drinking and culinary purposes.

(b) Sewage Disposal

The present use of the outdoor pit privy appears to be functioning quite well in principle.

It is recommended that window openings should be provided for the toilet buildings to lighten the interiors and that the walls and floors should be frequently whitewashed or painted white and always maintained in a clean condition. All ventilators, windows, and other openings should be fully screened to prevent the entrance of flies native to the vicinity and thus prevent the possible transmission of infection by this means.

Chloride of lime should be made available in ample quantities for dusting into the toilet pits in order to prevent local nuisance conditions and also to disinfect the contents. Chloride of lime or other equally efficient disinfectant should also be used in all the pail type toilets located in the school.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt, with thanks, of the blue print of the plans of the Onion Lake R.C. Residential school, which reached me in good condition.

The actual building of our school of Fort Chipewyan, being in a condition of continual deterioration, I decided to begin the construction of a new one, trusting on the help of some friends, to help us covering the expenses it will involve. We fully realize that in the present conditions it is rather difficult for the Department to contribute the amount referred to in our previous correspondence.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

I am sending forward herewith letter received by this Branch from Archbishop Breynat.

It would appear that Archbishop Breynat is undertaking the construction of an Indian residential school at Fort Chipewyan in the hope, no doubt, that the Department will later recognize his claim for a substantial increase in the enrolment of pupils.

We have at this date at Fort Chipewyan an Indian residential school (Holy Angels) with an enrolment of 40 pupils and a per capita grant allowance of $175.00. This is a Church-owned school. Fort Chipewyan is in the Athabasca Agency. This Agency has an Indian population, according to the last census, of 1363, all of whom are listed as Catholics, and 294 Indians between the ages of 7 and 16 inclusive. The Holy Angels School is the only Indian school in this Agency with the exception of a small Indian day school at Fort Smith. This school has at this date an enrolment of 8 pupils.

In view of the decision reached about a year ago that the pupil enrolment at residential schools would not be increased at any time in the immediate future, I feel prompted to bring Archbishop Breynat's letter to your personal attention in order that no misunderstanding may arise in respect to the construction of this school. In this connection may I refer to my memorandum to you dated October 30, 1939.

RAH Director.

Dear Sir:

In the blueprint of Onion Lake Residential School which you have so kindly sent me I notice that the distance between the floors and ceilings are ten feet in the wings where the children have their quarters; while they are only nine feet in the other part of the building.

Owing to the special conditions in the North West where the cold is so intense, the winters so long, and therefore the ventilation is easier, I am taking the liberty of asking if you would be kind enough to let us keep a uniform height of nine feet between the floors and ceilings through the entire structure. This is what we have at our schools of Fort Resolution and Aklavik, and so far the Department have seen no inconvenience.

Trusting that you will be able to give this matter your favorable consideration, I remain,

Dear Archbishop Breynat:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 4th instant with reference to the height of the ceilings in the children's wings of the plan recently forwarded to you in connection with the work being undertaken at the Holy Angels Residential School.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

I am in receipt of Mr. Jackson's memorandum of October 2 enclosing the attached accounts in connection with the purchase of two horses and one bull for the Holy Angels Residential School at Fort Chipewyan, Alberta.

While it is not the general practice to purchase livestock for Church-owned Indian residential schools, I may say that Rev. J. Serrurot, O.M.I., Bursar of the R.C. Episcopal Corporation of Mackenzie, visited the Department this summer and on behalf of Archbishop Breynat pointed out that the animals mentioned on the account were extremely necessary. Father Serrurot stated that the Archbishop was having considerable difficulty in financing the school, due to the cut in the per capita allowance, and pointed out that the purchase of the horses would enable them to procure wood more easily and that the purchase of the bull was necessary in order to increase the herd and thereby have milk available in larger quantities for the pupils. Reports that have been received indicate that good work is being done at the Holy Angels School and in view of the strong representations made by Father Serrurot on behalf of Archbishop Breynat he was authorized to purchase the animals. It is hoped that you will find it possible to approve the issue of a purchase order so that the account may be paid.

Director.
Memorandum to:

Dr. H.W. McGill

Will you please refer to your memoranda of the 26th September and October 8th in reference to the approval of the purchase of two horses and one bull for the Holy Angels Residential School at Fort Chipewyan, Alberta.

In view of the fact that Father Serrurot was authorized to purchase the animals, the minister approved of the account being paid. He inquired, however, the reason why authority was given to the church authorities to make the purchase before the principle was discussed with this office. He does not think that as a general rule purchases of this kind should be borne by the Department.

Chief Executive Assistant.

Ottawa, October 14, 1941.

Re: Purchase of Supplies and Equipment,
Fort Chipewyan and Aklavik Residential Schools

Dear Father Serrurot:

Invoices and vouchers amounting to a total of $2,744.56, sent forward by you and representing supplies and equipment purchased for the above-noted schools have been submitted by the Board to the Purchasing Division for the issuance of the usual purchase order. It is unnecessary to add that before these invoices can be accepted for payment by the Treasury they must be accompanied by the purchase order.

The Director is in receipt of a memorandum from Mr. C. W. Jackson, Chief Executive Assistant, dated September 12, 1942, in which Mr. Jackson states:

"Will you please note the attached memorandum I have received from the Purchasing Agent, in reference to the purchase of certain electric lighting equipment for the Holy Angels School at Fort Chipewyan at a cost of $2,065.68. I have had an opportunity of going over your file and it would seem quite clear that the church authorities needed to purchase this equipment without requiring any authority from your branch to do so. It is noted in Father Serrurot's letter of the 20th July that the purchase was made at least prior to May 21st, for he stated in this letter that he had invoices of this date in his possession. While it is true that Father Serrurot advised you in his letter of the 25th April that some of these funds were set aside for purchasing an electric power plant for Fort Chipewyan, he was never advised that the Department would approve of the purchase being made. If the requisition had been forwarded to this office, as is the usual procedure, I am sure the Minister would not have approved of it without first assessing the reason why this substantial purchase was being made in war-time. There is no information on file to show why the existing equipment could not have been repaired and used until the war was over.

Under the circumstances, therefore, in view of the fact that no authority was given to the Church to make the purchase, the Minister suggests they should be advised that they will have to look after the account themselves.

The Minister approves of the expenditures that are made for the school at Aklavik amounting to $675.88.

In view of the above decision, I am returning herewith the Bruce Robinson Electric accounts amounting to $2,065.68.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Your letter of the 21st ultimo addressed to the undersigned at Fort Chipewyan has been forwarded to Edmonton but unfortunately, owing to very slow mail connections at that point, has not reached Edmonton until today. It is this morning only that your letter and its enclosures were delivered here.

Two days ago, I wrote you in connection with the account to be paid to the Bruce-Robinson Electric Co., Ltd. At the time I was unaware that you had written me on the 21st of September concerning this account. In view of the abovementioned letter, I would request you to ignore my letter of the 10th instant, since you give me all desired information in your letter received today.

While we thank you for having approved of the expenditures that have been made for the school at Aklavitik amounting to $678.88, at the same time we are quite surprised to learn that Mr. C.W. Jackson does not approve of the expenditures made for lighting equipment at Fort Chipewyan. It seems that Mr. Jackson is not aware that we have built a new school at Fort Chipewyan during the summer and consequently that there was and there is no lighting equipment of any kind in that new school. How then could we have repaired and used the existing equipment until the war would be over?

It must be pointed out also that we are not asking for special and supplementary funds for that purpose but that we only asked for having funds allotted for other schools located within the Mackenzie Diocese to be transferred to the two schools at Aklavitik and Fort Chipewyan. The Honourable Mr. Crozier had authorized this transfer of funds on June last. Truly, we bought this electric power plant and lighting equipment before submitting our list to the Purchasing Branch, for the same reason that we bought the material necessary for the school at Aklavitik all of which expenditure has been approved by the Minister. We explained in our letter of June 20th last why we had to take this unusual step. We are absolutely certain that, even with permission from the Purchasing Branch, we could not have secured that material in July or later. We had every reason also to think that the Purchasing Branch would have authorized the purchase in the light of the very exceptional circumstances actually existing; not to mention the necessity of having the material delivered at the end of the season that is Waterways, before September 15th. We only can express our keen disappointment that a negative answer has been made in the case of the Fort Chipewyan School and we believe that, under such circumstances, we were...
Mr. R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,

not treated in the way that we had reasons to expect to be. We feel that our case should be submitted anew to Mr. Jackson who has probably not been entirely aware of the various circumstances concerning our request in connection with the new school at Fort Chipewyan and we anticipate an affirmative answer to our claim.

The writer is forwarding today to His Excellency Archbishop G. Breynat who shall be in Ottawa in the course of next week the whole file regarding this matter so as to enable him to discuss things more fully with your good self or with Mr. Jackson should it be necessary for him to do so.

I take pleasure in enclosing herewith a snapshot of the new school at Fort Chipewyan which shows how the building looked from the exterior on August 28th last.

Yours very truly,

J. Serrurot, O.M.I.,
Bursar, R.C. Missions of Mackenzie.

I am sending forward herewith copy of a letter received by this Branch from the Reverend J. Serrurot, O.M.I., Bursar, R.C. Missions of Mackenzie, and also photos of the new Indian residential school at Fort Chipewyan, attached thereto.

In this connection may I refer to my memorandum to you dated June 17, 1941, and your reply thereto dated June 21, 1941? It would appear, from the evidence now submitted by Father Serrurot, that the new Diesel electric lighting equipment referred to in Mr. Jackson's memorandum of September 17, 1942, was not a replacement but was new equipment purchased for the recently constructed school. The old school was constructed in 1889 and has been for several years in a state of dilapidation. The new school is of fireproof construction throughout. It is 114 ft. long and 59 ft. wide. This memorandum is being submitted in response to the suggestion contained in Father Serrurot's letter. It is noted that Archbishop Breynat will discuss this matter with you at the time of his next visit to Ottawa.

Enclosure.

Director.
Ottawa, October 17, 1942.

Attention Mr. R.A. Hoey:

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I am in receipt this morning of a letter from His Excellency Bishop Breynat concerning the purchase of the electrical lighting plant for the Chipewyan Residential School and he desires that I should again approach the Department with a view to have the account for this purchase approved.

I do not think it is necessary for me to again refer to the circumstances that made it imperative for the Bursar of Reverend Bishop Breynat's Vicariate to place the order at the time that he did and without obtaining previously the authority of the Department to do so.

Nevertheless, I might say that the Bursar was advised by the manufacturers that, unless the order was placed immediately, delivery could not be guaranteed. The remark that the old equipment might have been repaired and used until the war was over, has no bearing on the case as Chipewyan is a new school built with missionary funds and replaces a very old building which did not possess an electrical plant.

Furthermore, as the Church authorities have expended $35,000.00 on the erection of this school and have received no grant from the Department, it would seem only reasonable that the electrical equipment should be authorized and paid for, even though it was found impossible to secure authority for its purchase before it was actually made.

Hoping that you will grant His Excellency's request, I remain,

Very truly yours,

[Signature]
EDUCATION:

I have no comments to make regarding the local school other than to note that the winter session is well under way. The Principal of the School, Sister Deslauriers is one of those particularly efficient teachers that one so often finds in the Sisters' Orders. I find that she handles the pupils with no small amount of discipline and that she conducts her classes and also those of her assistant with a definite course and a definite schedule in mind. I have had four years experience as a high school teacher and principal myself and I feel that I have some basis for making the statement, that on the whole the Department is being well served by the present staff of teachers at Chipewyan.

The outside construction of the new residential school is completed. The inside construction is being continued. It is expected that the building will be ready for occupancy in the fall of 1943. The building, of brick and tile construction, is a very radical departure from that usually found in the north. It will be completely modern in all respects. There is to be an infirmary of six rather large rooms; sufficiently large to hold four beds a piece.

J. Mellings, M.D.

Providence Mission ........$ 1121.00
Holy Angels .................. 500.00
Fort Resolution .............. 900.00

Very dear Sir,

With reference to repairs and equipment needed for the R.C. Indian Residential Schools in the Mackenzie District, we beg to submit herewith our lists for the fiscal year 1944-45.

The notation made on these lists with regard to firms, catalogues and prices, aim simply to offer you some specific information concerning the material in question.

As for transportation, we would greatly appreciate it, if the Department would pay the freight charges as far as Waterways, Alberta. Dear Sir:

Would you please ask the Department of Indian Affairs if they would supply the Boys' Ward with a tent 13x24 ft.? It is intended for both winter and summer use. At all times the boys enjoy going out into the bush for their lunch - especially their Thursday "pancake lunch", but this can be possible only if they have a little shelter. The tent would serve that purpose. In summer, some twenty or more boys remain at the School for the holidays, and unless they can establish their "day quarters in the bush, they are not entirely happy, no matter how comfortable the place. If they had a tent under which they could retire against a too hot sun or a shower, their natural taste for life in the wilderness could be, at least, partly satisfied.

The donation of two such tents was made to our School several years ago, at the request of our Agent, but after years of most appreciated service, they have gone to ruins. As they had been a cause of general enjoyment for our little Indian pupils, we thought of asking for one to replace them.

Begging you to kindly lay our request before the Department, I remain,

Sir,

Re: His Excellency Bishop Trocellier's request for Fort Chipewyan, Fort Resolution, Fort Providence and Aklavik for the fiscal year 1946-47.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

I have just received from His Excellency Bishop Trocellier, the enclosed demands for the fiscal year 1946-47.

There are two items which call for special mention. The first one is that of $10,000 for the Chipewyan School. This amount is to be used for the installation of a water system. At the present time, two men are employed every day of the year, hauling water for this school. The cost, especially in Chipewyan, is very high and the service relatively poor due to the small quantity of water that can be drawn with the equipment on hand. During the war, nothing was asked for this installation but now that peace has again come to us, it is to be hoped that the Government will willingly contribute this small amount to complete the erection of this school.

This building has cost the Church well $100,000 and it seems only reasonable and justifiable for the Government to contribute at least 1/10th of its cost.

The second item is that of $3,000 for the Aklavik School. The improvement which it is sought to put in with this money, is necessary and should have been done several years ago but again war conditions prevented us from doing it. We hope therefore that you will also grant this amount.

I hope that you will take into account the various remarks that appear at the bottom of the requisition sheets as they are all very essential to the proper shipping of the goods asked for.

Yours very truly,

J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

When His Excellency Bishop Trocellier, O.M.I., was in Ottawa last Fall, we called on you and on Mr. Hoey regarding the above project and asked that the sum of $10,000 be included in the 1946-47 estimates, for this purpose.

His principal reason for asking for this arrangement is the scarcity of material and the necessity of speed in these purchase. The building season in Chipewyan is very short. Dear Father Gilles:

We have your letter of the 24th instant, enclosing statements regarding the installation of the water system at the Holy Angels Residential School.

You forwarded two statements, one for $11,169.36 and the other for $4,171.75 or a total of $15,341.11.

In official letter of June 11, 1946, a copy of which I enclose, Bishop Trocellier was advised that the Department was only prepared to allow an amount of $10,000.00.

You will also note from the enclosed letter that before payments can be made we must receive accounts for the material purchased and also receipted pay-lists.

Therefore, it will be necessary for you to forward the following at the earliest possible date:

a. Accounts as shown on the attached statement which is a copy of the one you forwarded. If these accounts have been paid they should be receipted and certified by yourself. If any of the accounts have not been paid they should also be certified by you and we will issue the cheque direct to the firm concerned.

b. Receipted Labour Return forms - it will be necessary to have labour returns prepared in duplicate and receipted by those employed. The names of the persons engaged in the work and also the dates during which they were employed should be shown. Under separate cover we are sending you a supply of Labour Return forms.
The total of the accounts and Labour Return forms should be $11,169.36 and as soon as these are received in the manner indicated above, we will be able to refund the amount of $10,000.00 which was provided in the current year's appropriation.

Mr. Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare and Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Neary,

We are forwarding today the information we received from our personnel at Fort Chipewyan, Alberta, with regard to the installation of the water system at the Indian Residential School there.

The number of hours of work (last item on the list) were found to be calculated incorrectly, as regards the wages per hour, some being only $1.00. This brings the total to $3,156.00 instead of $4,791.00 as previously shown.

On the Labour Return Sheets, it will be noted that two signatures are missing, and the explanation is given as follows: Louis Jureczyk is at present recovering from temporary paralysis and could not sign. Duncan Flett is at present hunting and trapping far away from Chipewyan, and is not expected certainly before the 31st of March.

As regards the accounts, we received the following explanations:

1700 lin. ft. spruce @ $37.00 M.: Invoice reads @ $26.00 M
3% tax.. 2.08
freight from Waterways.. 5.00
hauling from boat to school.. 4.92
$37.00

From other lumber listed on this same invoice (McInnes), we are told that 1,656 feet common spruce was used for work in connection with the septic tank. This item was forgotten in the drawing up of the original list, and at $37.00 M., this would come to $61.26 which should be added to the list already sent in.

300 cedar shingles - these were already on hand at the time of construction, and the price has been figured from current costs at the time the work was in progress. There is consequently no invoice.

The same remark was made for the lumber listed as "40 pieces, 2 x 4 - 12', 9 pieces, 3 x 6 - 8' and 2 pieces, 8 x 8 - 16'."
The 400 feet of insulation - no invoice could be found. The cost was calculated according to current prices in Ashdown's catalogue at the time of construction.

2 rolls roofing - $7.50, plus freight from Waterways and hauling from wharf to school.

1500 feet vitrified sewer pipe - no invoice found. Here again the cost was calculated from current prices in Ashdown's catalogue at time of work. (Likewise for the 6 elbows).

The box-stove was purchased locally for cash, and no record of the transaction exists in writing.

50 sacks of cement - the cost listed includes freight from Waterways and hauling from wharf to mission-school.

The fittings included for the drawing up of this list are marked off on the invoice from Mould and Son. The total of the fittings amounts to $3,346.21. The freight charges on these fittings is figured as $224.21, leaving the total already given, as $3,570.42.

From this invoice from Mould and Son, it is evident that if our personnel at Chipewyan had restricted their calculations simply to this single invoice, the total of which surpasses $10,000.00, they would have quickly reached the full amount of the grant.

It was our purpose, however, to give you a comprehensive view of the labor and various materials required in this installation, and we trust that the information we are forwarding you, will answer your requirements in this connection.

All the material mentioned in this letter and on the previous list has been paid. There are no outstanding debts of any kind with regard to any of this work.

Very truly yours,

Memorandum:

ACTING DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Holy Angels Indian Residential School,
Athabasca Indian Agency.

In the current year's appropriation an amount of $10,000.00 is provided for the installation of a water system at this school. It is the intention to obtain the water from Lake Athabasca, which is approximately three quarters of a mile from the school.

A considerable amount of expenditure will be necessary for labour and some materials will also be required.

His Excellency Bishop Trocellier was in Ottawa recently and requested that authority be given to him to proceed with the installation of the water system. He is prepared to engage labour and buy the materials required, on the understanding that the Department will allow an amount of not more than $10,000.00. He would of course supply receipted invoices for materials purchased and receipted paylists for the labour employed.

The season for doing such work at the Holy Angels School is very short and the Bishop would appreciate it if the Minister would give him authority to proceed.

(Sgd.) R.A. Hoey

Director.

C.C.

Approved on the distinct understanding that no matter what the circumstances may ultimately be, no further expenditure for the project beyond $10,000.00 will be paid by the Department.

(Sgd.) J. Allison Glen, Minister

Re: Mechanical Devices for the supply of cordwood at Fort Chipewyan " Providence " Resolution and Aklavik

My dear Mr. Phelan,

The four schools mentioned above are situated, as you know, in a country where the winters are extremely long, the cold very severe and, therefore, where heating and the means to procure it are always a serious problem.

Moreover, the labour situation is very difficult at all times, but is principally so during the winter months when hunting and trapping supply sufficient work at remunerative prices for all the Indian population.

Our schools depend for the very large quantity of fuel, which in every case is cordwood, on the few lay Brothers attached to each institution. It has been the desire of Bishop Trocellier, just as it was of his predecessors, to provide these Brothers with all the mechanical devices to facilitate and expedite their work.

In this connection, they are anxious to purchase precision light weight portable power chain saws for each of these four schools as the claims made for these machines are well substantiated by the testimonies of those who have purchased and used them.

I am enclosing for your information several pieces of advertisement which you will find interesting to read and which will give you as well the information that your purchasing agent may require.

The price of these saws complete is $435.20 for the 18" type model. This includes 1 extra chain at $19.00 1 filing tool " 11.95 3 spark plugs " 2.25
The Secretary,
Re: Mech. devices, cont'd. October 11, 1947.

These prices are subject to a 10% discount if the order is placed by the Department.

To be of value these machines must be purchased immediately and shipped with the least delay possible so that they may be used for this winter's fuel supply. You will understand how necessary this is when I mention the fact that each of these institutions requires 400 cords of wood for its winter supply. A saving of one dollar per cord would easily pay for this machine, but the information which I have, and which our own Brothers are substantiating, leads me to believe that a saving of five dollars per cord will more truly result.

I leave this whole affair in your hands and hope that you will see to it that as much speed as possible is used in placing the orders.

Thanking you in anticipation, I remain,

Re: Chipewyan, Resolution, Providence and Aklakvik Indian Residential Schools

My dear Mr. Phelan,

During the months of July and August, I had the pleasure of visiting the above schools. I took occasion of my visit to go over their needs with the Principals. Whilst it is my intention to write a letter for each of them, there are three points which apply to all of them and to which I would like to call your attention:

1. The electric plants consist, for each school, of only one 12 H.P. Lister Diesel Engine and four-kilowatt generator. These are very old and whilst they were thought, at the time of their purchase, to be sufficient in size they have been found in practice to be too small. It is not the purpose of the Church authorities to do away with them completely but they should be kept only as an emergency service and be replaced with 16 H.P. diesels and six-kilowatt generators. This applies of course to the four schools.

2. These schools have no frigidaires of any kind outside of ice boxes. This makes the keeping of their meat, which is the principal element of food the year round, a very difficult affair. Moreover, such items as milk, butter and eggs are kept in cupboards which are not intended for that purpose.

3. The laundry equipment in all these institutions is of the most elementary nature. There is no steam boiler, no wringer, no dryer, no flat ironers, and the four buildings all need substantial repairs. In fact I am wondering how the Reverend Sisters do so much laundering the year round.
under such conditions. Their washing machines are also too small and should be supplemented with either a large Domestic or a small type of commercial machine.

The purchase of the above equipment could be made by the Department itself or can be left to the procurator of Bishop Trocellier, who could render accounts for everything purchased after receiving authorization from you to do so.

From information which I have been able to gather, the power plants would cost around $2,600 each, the fridgidares about $1,500 and the laundry equipment in the neighbourhood of $4,500. There would still be repairs to be made to the laundry buildings but I believe that this would not be very expensive as the buildings are now in use and only require such items as flooring and repairs to walls and ceilings.

Hoping that you will give this matter your immediate attention, I remain,

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Aklavit R.C. Residential School; Fort Resolution Residential School; Providence Mission Residential School; Holy Angels Residential School (Fort Chipewyan).

All the above mentioned schools are church-owned and in the diocese of Most Reverend J. Trocellier, O.M.I., Vicar Apostolic of Mackenzie.

For many years past these schools have been using very antiquated methods for washing clothes. Bishop Trocellier is now desirous of installing proper laundry machinery in each of the four schools mentioned above. He proposes to secure the following equipment at each of them:

1 "Leonard" boiler 12 h.p., 100 lb. pressure, complete with ordinary fittings.

1 26" Beaver, motor driven, Laundry Extractor.

1 36 x 30 Beaver Heubsch laundry drying tumbler, complete with ½ h.p. motor.

1 Scissel Sock Dryer (extremely useful in the north country to avoid shrinkage of socks).

1 56" Flat work ironer.

He has obtained estimates of the cost of the above equipment and finds that it will require an expenditure of approximately $3,000.00 at each of the four
schools, or a total of approximately $12,000.00.

In the appropriation for the fiscal year 1947-48, the following amounts which were specifically provided for the four schools are unexpended:

Aklavik..................... $529.00
Providence Mission........ $1,745.00
Fort Resolution........... $1,954.00
Holy Angels............... $5,502.00

Total $9,730.00

Bishop Trocellier requests authority to proceed immediately with the purchase of the equipment for each of the four schools with the understanding that the Department will allow towards the cost of the equipment, the amount unexpended at these four schools in the current year's appropriation. In other words, he is prepared to purchase the five items of equipment for each school as shown above and will pay from his own funds the cost of same over and above the amount of $9,730.00.

I feel it is very important that all our schools should be properly equipped with laundry machinery, not only for the convenience of the staff but for the welfare of the Indian pupils and I would appreciate it if you would authorize me to accept the proposal made by Bishop Trocellier.

As our three classrooms are filled to capacity, we have been forced to refuse children who were not 7 before Christmas; and we foresee a still increasing number for next year. Consequently we have decided to open a fourth classroom in September for the Primary Class.

May we ask the help of the Department of Indian Affairs to furnish that new classroom with desks - as far as it will accommodate Treaty Indian children?

Presently, we have only 76 "Government" school desks: 36 received in 1934 and 40 received in 1944. Still the pupilage allowed Holy Angels Indian Residential School is 80. Moreover we must accommodate 25 Treaty Indian Day Scholars from the Fort.

Consequently I have taken the liberty of putting in a requisition for 30 desks more. Although the chair desks of which we have supplied 20 for the third classroom are most satisfactory, we shall appreciate any kind that the Department deems suitable.

We would be much obliged if you would let us know at your earliest convenience what help we may expect from the Department in furnishing this new classroom.

Yours respectfully,

Sister M. Anne Deslauriers,
Sister M. Anne Deslauriers, principal.
February 11, 1948.

Reverend and dear Sister:

We have your letter of January 29th with reference to additional desks that you state are required at the Holy Angels Residential School.

As you are aware, this is a church-owned school and we are allotted a specific sum each year for repairs and improvements and purchase of new equipment. The amount allotted for the current fiscal year has been totally assigned and consequently we have no funds on hand at the present time to purchase additional desks. However, we will give the matter further consideration after April 1st when our appropriation for the fiscal year 1948-49 is available.

We were not previously aware that you were accepting some pupils as day scholars. We would appreciate it if you would let us have the following information:

(a) Number of Treaty Indian children attending as day scholars.

(b) Number of Treaty Indian children enrolled as residential school pupils.

(c) Number of non-Treaty or white children enrolled as day school pupils.

(d) Number of non-Treaty or white children enrolled as residential school pupils.

Yours sincerely,

Sir:

Re: ADDITIONAL DESKS.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of February 11, replying to our requisition for additional desks to furnish a fourth classroom for next September. To give you an exact idea of how our classrooms are constituted, I willingly submit the following analysis made at the close of the December term 1947:

| TREATY INDIAN PUPILS | RESIDENTS ...... 74 | DAY SCHOLARS ... 22 | 96 |
|-----------------------|---------------------|-------------------|----|
| NON-TREATY PUPILS     | RESIDENTS ...... 20 | DAY SCHOLARS ... 34 | 54 |

TOTAL NUMBER OF RESIDENTS .......... 94
TOTAL NUMBER OF DAY SCHOLARS ....... 56
TOTAL NUMBER OF PUPILS ATTENDING CLASSES ....... 150

All the Non-Treaty Pupils are of Indian descent. They are all Roman Catholics and wish to attend the Holy Angels School which is the only Catholic School of the region.

In this connection another trouble arises: I noticed in the Indian School Bulletin of November 1, the following statement: "These (school) supplies are for Indian children only." It follows that, of our 150 pupils, 54 should not have received books and supplies from the School Store. I must say here that Non-Treaty Half-Breed children are, for the great majority, without resource - the few able to buy themselves scribblers, pencils, pens and ink, have been encouraged to do it; but they are the few. Another point is that these pupils are scattered in all the grades, and should they get their own text books, or should we get them for them from the Alberta School Book Branch of the Department of Education, these books would not be of the kind which the Department of Indian Affairs supplies and there would result two different kind of readers, etc., in each grade, a situation in no way advantageous to any class.

Would you kindly direct me as to where and how to obtain the required books and supplies for these 54 Non-Treaty Pupils?

Yours respectfully,

Sister M. Anne Deslauriers, principal.

N.B. The books and school supplies requisitioned last December for the academic year 1948-49 were intended for the 96 Treaty Indian children only.

S.D.

Sir:

Your letter File 134-1-5 of April 26, 1948, informed me that it is the intention of the Department to order the desks requested for the Holy Angels Indian Residential School. A few weeks later I received a copy of your Purchase Order to F.E. Osborne Limited, 112 - 8th Ave., CALGARY, for 30 movable chair desks, small size, Glche Furniture Company, Size 5.

On my return from the city where I have sojourned a few weeks, I learned that the desks had not yet arrived. On a re-examination of the Purchase Order I remarked that these desks were to be sent to my name at Holy Angels Indian Residential School, FORT MCMURRAY, via Waterways, instead of FORT CHIPWEYAN.

I immediately wired to the N.A.R.Agent in Waterways to inquire whether the goods were still there in storage. I am in receipt of a telegram stating that they are "unable to locate any shipment of chair desks in May or June."

The error in the Purchase Order is probably the cause of this prolonged delay in getting this school furniture. As time is pressing - the classrooms will open on the 7th of September, would you kindly make investigations into the matter and have these desks directed to the Holy Angels Indian Residential School at your earliest convenience. May I beg to be advised by a telegram?

Thanking you in anticipation, I remain,

Yours respectfully,

Sister M. Anne Deslauriers, prnc.

Dear Sir:

We are in receipt of your telegram under date of December 31st, and we cannot understand what has happened to the invoices covering purchase orders 33504, 33693, 33624, 33692. We sent all these invoices direct to Ottawa as per the purchase orders some two months ago. However, they have apparently become lost and so we are attaching hereto copies of these invoices.

You will note that we have not included any bills of lading because this material was quoted F.O.B. Waterways which is the end of steel and we deliver direct from our Yard at that point. If we were shipping from Edmonton we could of course then supply bills of lading.

We might mention that about two months ago Bishop Trocquillier of the Roman Catholic Mission in the North West Territories said that he was on his way to Ottawa and he would O.K. these invoices on his arrival which we presumed had been done. Apparently this was either overlooked by him or your department did not have the invoices to O.K.

We trust that these copies will now straighten this matter out and that payment will be forthcoming promptly.

July 8th, 1949.

Mr. Bernard F. Neary, Supt. of Indian Education,

Dear Sir,

July 19th marks a great event in the life history of the Holy Angels' Indian Residential School. It is the 75th Anniversary of the arrival of the first Sisters, who had come from Fort Providence, N.W.T., after three weeks on the water. We read in the annals of those days that after two weeks of scrubbing and general house cleaning, they converted an old shed into livable quarters where children could assemble for School. There were fifteen pupils for the first Teaching Day, August 1st, 1874. Some had come from the far off "Caribou eating families" of Pond du Lac, 200 miles west on Lake Athabasca.

To-day the School Register marks 1,300 names of children that have passed several years to our Residential Home during 75 years and the majority are Indians.

I am pleased to send you and the Staff a snapshot of our new modern School, built in 1942. You will be interested to note the progress. There are four large, bright classrooms. It is supplied with electricity, running water, a steam heating system. The children enjoy spacious dormitories, recreation, and dining rooms.

On this great Memorial Day, the Teaching Staff feel confident that it would be a pleasure for the Department, through your courtesy, to offer something in behalf of the School, as an encouragement to the Sisters for their cooperation in the tedious work among the Natives for so many years.

May I suggest, for your donation, two Writing Desks with the Chairs for the Teachers. This would be a wonderful SUBSTITUTE for the actual primitive ones. Also, a typewriter, Remington, any size, or any kind you could dispose of, would be highly appreciated by the principal.

These useful gifts will be inscribed, to your credit, on the list of Benefactors, as a token of your satisfaction for the Education of the Indians in the far-off land of "Kid Snow and Ice".

Thanking you most heartily and the members of your Staff, for the powerful helping hand you have given us in the past, in order to promote civilization and education, and awaiting your further favours,

I remain,

Yours gratefully,

Sister Olivia Lavoie,
Principal.

Dear Sir:

I herewith forward Returns for quarter ending September 30th '95. From them you will see how small the number of scholars were during the quarter. The chief reason for this is the great scarcity of fish at that season of the year. Even those on the Returns, few as they are, were to be had on bacon and flour, the latter we could afford, but the former is one of the most expensive of imported provisions.

2nd, Some of the parents live far away on the lake and elsewhere and are unable to bring in their children at that season of the year, in fact while food is plentiful and the weather warm, it is very difficult to get them into the Home and quite as difficult to hold them once the snow has gone in the spring. All the power we have to influence them is, as Ministers and with that we cannot compel them to leave their children with us. With the exception of orphans
orphans or such as have only one parent, it is impossible to hold them through the summer, if we attempt it they would demand their children and we would plead in vain for them after that. Another thing they very strongly object to is the signing of any paper handing over their children for any length of time, the suggestion is enough to frighten them; they are very suspicious about paper and it is with very great difficulty they can be got to put their names thereon. In two cases only I have succeeded, one is Nancy and John Beaver Nos 027, and No 23 Nancy 027 is in for two years and No 23 for five. Will you kindly place these two on the support list instead of Nos. having left for good. No. is now too old and is being kept at home. The other case is that of a poor blind woman who gave me a writing as they call it, for her little daughter only two years old. Any new scholars that have been admitted tho have been promised for at least four years. We have now nearly the same number as last year, and in a few days we shall have 30.

The Indians make their fishing about 30 miles away and this year owing to the very mild weather, the lake has not been safe until a few days ago for either dogs or animals, consequently we could not support the full number of scholars.

SLAVE LAKE MISSIONS.

Rev. Mr. Holmes, Church of England missionary, arrived in town last Wednesday evening from Lesser Slave Lake, where he has been engaged over which Mr. Holmes presides are on Buffalo lake, a small branch off Slave Lake. The Roman Catholic mission is on the opposite side of the same lake.

The English church is a log building which is 24x30 feet in size. The school house is 24x30 with a kitchen attached. About 30 children board at the mission and attend the school there. The mission house is 18x26 and has two stories. There is also a wash house and stable. During the past eight years, in face of almost insurmountable difficulties on account of the hostility of the Indians who are Crees, 23 adults have become communicants. The work amongst the old Indians is very difficult of accomplish-

ing, but amongst the children the mis-

sionaries find every encouragement.

They find them amiable and quick to learn. In addition to the usual educa-

tion in the schools the boys are taught agriculture and the girls sewing and domestic duties. Many of the Indians have commenced raising potatoes which are well cultivated, while others plant their vegetables and there are con-

siderably to go hunting and fishing for a subsistence. Some of their gardens over-

grown with weeds on their return. The Hudson's Bay Company supplies the mission there. At Lesser Slave lake proper there are about 50 communi-

cants. Mr. Holmes says Mr. Warner has baptized about 40 children. Mr. Curry is the teacher and Miss Durwell, matron. In the Indian village there are about 10 head of cattle and horses at the mission. Mr. Holmes brought with him an Indian, a thirty-three year old, who was taken into the mission house seven years ago and who attends to the stock. He was sent back to his tribe in Winnipeg and arrangements will be made for him to learn a trade there, probably shoemaking. Mr. Holmes re-

grets to have to complain that some traders take a liquid, in small bottles that they call "ginger." This when drunk by the Indians intoxicates them and thus causes many ridiculous scenes. Most of these small bottles full will make a man steadily drunk who could be but little affected by a much larger amount of whiskey. A lot of it was given to the Indians near the lake on Sunday night, and the result was a most de-

plorable scene of riot and drunk-

enness. Also another matter requiring mention is the laying of poison and starting of fires. Many fur-

Hon. Sir,

You are doubtless acquainted, through Native School Reports, with St. Peter's Protestant Boarding School, Lower Slave Lake, which was established ten years ago, supported, for some time, by voluntary contributions from friends in Eng. Canada.

The building, which has been used for that purpose, up till the present, is only 24 x 30 ft., which, with from twenty-eight to thirty-four children, has been dangerously overcrowded.

During my furlough in England, two years ago, I was able to collect amongst friends, sufficient money to enable us to erect an additional wing 22 x 34 ft., which will be completed in a day or two. This building is intended for the accommodation of boys, while the old part will be used for girls.

The ground floor of the new building will have to serve as school room, as well as boys' day-room, until the means are forthcoming to enable us to build a separate schoolroom, which is very desirable.

Our only reliable means of support, at present, is the grant of $60 per capita for lonely scholars, kindly allowed us by the Indian Dept. This will barely supply the necessary amount of flour alone, for forty children (total number we hope to admit).
including freight, which is $3.50 per 100 lbs from Edmonton.

Mr. Isaac Cass, who paid the last treaty dues to the school, advised me to apply to your Honour for an increase in the support grant, as well as for assistance for添添 enlargement especially a schoolroom. The Sturgeon Lake Indians too are now willing to give up their children, but they are 100 miles from the nearest school. I think we have the first child from Sturgeon Lake in our school now.

There is, in this district, a sufficient number of children to fill half a dozen schools such as ours. The Roman Catholics, the Indians are so widely scattered that they schools are out of the question. Lesser Slave Lake is certainly the best centre for a Boarding School, especially, as the lake supplies an abundance of fine whitefish.

I humbly trust that your Honour will be able to increase our support grant to forty scholars instead of twenty, to make us some allowance for a separate school-room privilege.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

I have been instructed to inform you of the decision of our Society to close St. Peter's School, Lesser Slave Lake from the 30th of June last, and to request your Department to authorize an increase in the enrolment at St. Andrew's School at White Fish Lake and at St. John's School, Wabasca, to at least 30 pupils each. Without entering fully into detail with regard to the circumstances which necessitated this action on the part of our Society, I may state that it was prompted chiefly by the difficulty in meeting the expenditure involved in the maintenance of three small schools, and especially so since a 10% reduction has been made.

You will recall that, for a number of years past, the question of the consolidation of the Lesser Slave Lake, the White Fish Lake, and the Wabasca Schools, has been under consideration, but without any definite and decisive action being taken. It is still the hope and expectation of our Society that one or two new and fully modern residential school buildings may be provided by your Department to preserve and extend the work which has been carried on so long in the three buildings erected by our Church in that part of Alberta. Until funds are available for this, it is the purpose of our Society to maintain the work at the White Fish Lake and Wabasca centres, and those responsible for the direction of the Society's affairs keenly desire to have your fullest possible cooperation in connection with the same.

As the sanctioned enrolment of 40 pupils between the Lesser Slave Lake and White Fish Lake Schools, and of 25 pupils at the Wabasca School, or 65 pupils in all, will be reduced to 60 pupils by sanctioning an enrolment of 30 pupils at each of
the White Fish Lake and Wabasca Schools, I can see no difficulty, apart from that of accommodation, why this arrangement should not be adopted, and I sincerely trust that it may be approved and sanctioned by your Department.

The difficulty of accommodation, so far as I am informed, applies only to the Wabasca School, and even there it does not appear to be insuperable. The Principal states that, if given material he can add a room to the main building by enclosing the space between the two projecting wings in front. I went carefully into this matter myself when I visited this School last January, and am able to endorse the Principal's opinion. If your Department will supply the material, the school management will be able to do the work. If the material is not provided, a grant of approximately $250.00 would be required to meet the cost of material and of freighting.

As it is proposed, as soon as the summer holidays are over to transfer to the White Fish Lake School, any pupils who would have been returning to St. Peter's School at Lesser Slave had this letter institution been kept open, I shall be obliged if you will give an authorization at the earliest date possible for the enrolment of 30 pupils at each of the White Fish Lake and Wabasca Schools, and notify me which of the alternative courses your Department decides to take in connection with the provision of the additional accommodation at the Wabasca School.

I may state further, that the beds and bedding, dishes, cutlery, etc., now at the Lesser Slave Lake School can be distributed between the White Fish Lake and Wabasca Schools for the use of the additional pupilage, and I trust that your Department may agree to this arrangement also, and undertake to meet the small cost of transportation involved in the same.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in which any pupil was in attendance and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading “Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter”.

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the “Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter” by the “Total number of days in quarter”.

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the “Average attendance of pupils during quarter” by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

I visited this school on February 16th, and found 6 boys and 5 girls present out of an enrolment of 14.

Three pupils did not return after the mid-summer holidays, namely John Belcourt, age 13, admitted in 1922, Maggie Belcourt, age 12, admitted in 1924, and Margaret Belcourt, age 9, admitted in 1926. These children were taken into the St. Bruno's Roman Catholic School without the authority of the Department, and although the Principal has been notified by the Department to send the children back, he has not done so. The mother of these children was educated at St. Peter's School, and it is her desire that her children remain in that school. It is claimed that the children were baptised Roman Catholic.

The Principal of St. Bruno's has, in my opinion, taken an unfair and arbitrary attitude in this matter, and in view of the circumstances, I feel that the Department would be well advised in insisting that their instructions are carried out.

Mr. W. F. Kent is in charge as Principal and acts as teacher, Miss Allan, matron, Miss Halerow, cook, and Mr. Rawlings, outside man.

The original school building was built with logs about thirty-five years ago, and is now in very poor condition. The bottom logs have rotted causing the building to settle.
to settle and warp, with the result that the floors are very uneven and the windows and doors out of line. A frame addition was added twenty-five years ago; the ground floor of this addition provides a classroom 22' x 34' with a 12 ft. ceiling. The upstairs is used as a dormitory for the boys. The old part of the building provides a dining room, kitchen, girls' dormitory, storeroom, and three small staff rooms. The boys' dormitory is 20' x 20' with a ceiling from 3 to 7 ft. high. Three windows provide ventilation and light. There were five beds in use at the time of my visit. The girls' dormitory is 21' x 24', with a 9 ft. ceiling. There are three windows and six beds. Ventilation is obtained from the windows.

It was noted that each child has his own individual towel, as well as a toothbrush.

The building is heated with box stoves with drums in the dormitories. Coal oil lamps are used for lighting purposes.

Six Pyrene extinguishers are placed at convenient points in the building, and a 5 gal. extinguisher with hand pump is on hand. A ladder is placed under the end window at the outside of each dormitory to provide means of escape in the event of fire. The children are given regular fire drill.

The washing of clothes is done in the kitchen, and in the winter months the dining and other rooms are used as a place for drying the clothes. I found the school clean throughout, and can understand that, owing to the rough and uneven floors, it is not an easy task to keep this building in good order.
