Two - 45 gal. barrels are used for water storage purposes. Their water supply is hauled in barrels from the lake.

There is no doubt but that these old buildings have served their purpose and will soon have to be replaced if the school is to be continued at this point.

Separate outside toilets are provided for the boys and for the girls. I found these toilets in a cleanly condition.

I saw the children at their mid-day meal, and noted that they are given plenty of wholesome food.

Seven milk cows are kept, which is plenty for their requirements. Their garden provides an ample supply of roots and vegetables, and there will be a surplus of potatoes for sale. I have never seen better potatoes than those on hand at this school.

The boys cut the wood and help in the care of the garden and stock. The girls assist in the housework, and are given instruction in baking, sewing, and knitting. They are a bright lot of children, and have a healthy appearance. They are making good progress in acquiring a knowledge of the English language and in their school work.

Dear Doctor Keenleyside,

In accordance with a request of your Department, inspections have been made of the Anglican Mission Indian Schools at Wabasca and Whitefish, Alberta. The representative of the Department of Public Works, Chief Architect's Branch, who made the inspections was accompanied by Rev. Canon Cook of the Anglican Missions.

The Whitefish Indian School and the various buildings were inspected and valuations have been placed upon each, with the necessary depreciation being allowed for the years which they have been standing. The total valuation placed on the buildings at Whitefish is shown as $19,927.65. A copy of the valuation for each building is enclosed. I would particularly draw to your attention that there is no well at Whitefish, the water being taken from the river. No plumbing accommodation has been built into the buildings and no electrical services exist.

At Wabasca the valuations total $13,738.42. A copy of the detailed figures making up this valuation is enclosed.

In regard to the water supply, sewage disposal and electrical services, the same condition exists at Wabasca as at Whitefish.

It is my understanding that photographs were taken at both places of the various buildings by Canon Cook of
the Anglican Missions, and that he will forward to you copies of the photographs. If there is any other information you require on these buildings please let me know.

This report constitutes the last of the inspections and valuations which you had requested to be made.

Yours very truly,

E. P. Murphy,
Deputy Minister.

As you are aware, I had $2,100. voted for the current year for the maintenance of the Orph-
Orphanage of 35 children at $60. each, but as the number of children was scarcely expected to reach 35, and as we are forced to economize, I placed the remainder for next year at 25, consequently $1,500 have been passed for maintenance for the fiscal year 1890-91.

Report No. 1 to the Missionary Executive of the Methodist Church covering the Condition and Expenditure of the Indian Boarding School at Morley, Alta., dated March 8th, 1905.

On our arrival at Morley we found a man repairing furnaces. An appropriation of $200 has been made by the Department for this purpose. We considered the time opportune to suggest some changes to provide more perfect heating and much needed ventilation. We asked for an estimate of cost of extras suggested. This will be furnished and if satisfactory - we have assumed the responsibility of authorizing the improvements. It is believed that the appropriation of $200 will cover the entire cost of repairs and changes ordered by us. The man in charge of this work gives it as his opinion that the furnaces will not last more than two years longer.

Water - There seems to be an ample supply and of good quality. The spring is situated about 2000 feet from the School, there is a fall of 70 feet. There is at present 2800 cubic feet of water in the reservoir at the spring which means an ample supply for both domestic purposes and fire protection. The work is satisfactory so far as the outside of the building is concerned. As yet the system is only partially installed. There are two taps, one in the kitchen and one in the laundry. The pipes in the building are not sufficiently guarded against frost. This winter considerable trouble has been experienced owing to this defect. More complete installation is necessary to provide for baths and closets.

Pupils - No. of pupils in attendance at present is 46. Limit 40.

Per Capita $72 - Average during part year 50.

Staff - Principal J. W. Hildreth Salary $800
Matron Miss Jull. " 300
Assistant Matron Miss Gibson. " 180
Cook Miss Rowles " 240
Sewing Teacher. Mrs. Rolston. Salary $200
Teacher. Miss Walsh. * 300
Farmer. Mr. Jolly (just left) 240

Duties - The duties of the Principal are so multifarious and varied as to be difficult of specification - General oversight - The purchase of supplies - General office work. He performs a great deal of manual labor which we think scarcely pertains to the duties of his office, i.e., the going to the bush and hauling wood from four to nine miles often two loads a day - 125 cords of wood burned last year - 3/4 of cord in load. This work is done mainly by the Principal and an Indian boy. The Assistant has to attend to stock and until recently haul water in. Both cannot be away from the Institute at the same time. - The Principal sleeps in the dormitory with the boys - nurses them in sickness and personally bathes them on Saturdays - Indeed he does what but few men could be hired to do. - He does it not for hire, but we believe through a sense of duty and love of the children.

His Assistant should be a more efficient man than can possibly be procured for the salary paid.

Matron - General Supervision.

Assistant Matron - Laundry work. - In summer dairy work. - Keeping Staff's rooms in order. - Oversight of girls while scrubbing floors etc. - Only four or five small girls to assist.

Cook - General Cooking including baking of bread. One girl assistant.

Seamstress - Marking and mending of clothing for both boys and girls.

Teacher - Long tried. Thoroughly efficient both as teacher and missionary.

The question has been raised: - Is not the staff abnormally large
for the care of less than 50 children? This question we have carefully considered and fail to see where a reduction can be made.

The Principal's duties are already too heavy. The money paid for a male Assistant or farmer has failed to procure an efficient man.

The Asst. Matron has her hands full. The laundry work of nearly 60 people (including staff) is in itself a heavy item, with so little assistance as can be rendered by four or five girls under fifteen years of age.

The cook has enough to do to cook for sixty people including the making of bread with only one child assistant.

The Seamstress makes and mends the clothes for both boys and girls. - None are bought ready made. In all these instances it must be borne in mind that help rendered by the children is small. - No boys or girls over fourteen years of age being available at present. - Very few indeed having reached fourteen. - These of course spend part of their time in School.

A general analysis of the accounts would indicate that so far as we can judge, there has been no extravagant expenditure in the following items:

1 - House equipment $386.45, including among other items:
   New Sewing Machine $56. Mattress $8. Table $6.
   2 robes $10. Stove for parlor. Brooms, brushes, lamps curtains, cutlery, crockery, granite-ware etc. etc.

2 - Ranch Expenses $377.33 - Oats, feed and seed $100.
   This is very small. One good horse would eat 100 bushels in a year. The seed is necessary for oats seldom mature in this high altitude. Oats are sown to provide green feed or to cure for feed. New Mowing Machine $78. Bull $47. Wear and tear harness etc. etc.
3 - Extra Labor Bank Exchange etc. $165.90 - fourteen days labor painting at $2.00 per day - An extra man for two months during Mr. Niddrie's Sickness (by Dr. Sutherland's authority) $60. - Freight $45. etc. etc.

4 - Blacksmithing, building and general repairs $203. - About $100 of this item was for flooring mangers - ceiling in stables The balance for blacksmithing and sundries.

5 - Fuel and lights $302.40 - Light $67. - Balance $235 for fuel. This is for cutting wood in bush and hauling to edge of wood or to the church, a distance of 5 miles from bush. As before stated, the Principal hauled it from church 4 miles or edge of woods 9 miles.

6 - Travelling expenses $120 - Miss Rheuler return expenses to Ontario after five year's service $50. Miss Hudson paid for her ticket when she came to Morley. Having remained two years she was entitled to refund $60. Balance of $10, balance of Miss Fairburn's expenses from Toronto, making a total of $120. We assume these items relate to the terms of agreement between the Mission Rooms and parties concerned. The General Superintendent will know whether these amounts should have been paid. It will be noted that the Principal has not charged any of his own expenses, though he made several trips to Calgary on the business of the Institute.

7 - Provisions and Clothing - $4840.76 We are not clear as to this item. We have not sufficient data to compare with other institutions. Conditions are very different with those which obtain, say at Brandon, where a productive farm yields so largely to the support of the Institute. With the exception of milk and butter in part and some meat in the winter, every-
thing has to be purchased, and in most instances at high prices.

Potatoes range from $1.00 to $1.50 per bushel. Last year $25. was paid for seed potatoes - Nothing realized. - The crop was an entire failure. The Principal suggests the following way of viewing the situation. - 50 children at $1.50 each for food and clothing -$75. per week. 7 Members of staff at 10¢ per meal - $14.70 per week - $99.70 per week. - 52 weeks - $4864.40.

Everything to buy except what may be realized from cattle. There were 46 head of cattle when Mr. Middrie came. Near 50,3600 worth has been sold in the last five years.

The milk and butter are considerations. Then the material only of the clothing can be considered in the above calculations. The making otherwise provided for.

There may be a leakage through any one of all the following ways.

1 - Expensive purchases. - Some economy is possible in this line, though not sufficient to very materially affect results. Suggestions were made to the Principal on this line which may prove valuable in the future.

2 - Waste - The Principal was closely questioned on this point. He seems satisfied that rigid economy is practised. We are not in a position to form a judgment. Much depends upon the cook.

3 - The question as to whether hospitality extended to Indians from Reserve is not a larger drain on the supplies than members of the staff are conscious of.

An examination of the books revealed a lack of correspondence between statements of amounts received from Mission Rooms and amounts expended as shown by the cash a/c. Although some hours were spent in the effort to reach an understanding, such effort was fruitless.
The Principal stated that he had Miss Walsh to assist him in his bookkeeping. The General Secretary will know that the Principal has suffered with severe head trouble in consequence of sore eyes caused by poisoning. Many times he felt the need of help in his accounts when thus suffering, hence he procured the assistance of Miss Walsh. He asked us to allow him time to procure further information which he would do on Miss Walsh's return from the East the latter end of March. We have asked that he prepare full statements which shall enable us to see exactly how things stand at the present time. His books are not all posted up to date. The Principal claims that the over-lapping of the various year's accounts will in part and perhaps wholly account for discrepancies. A fuller report may be expected later.

All of which is respectfully submitted.

(Signed) James Woodsworth.
(Signed) T. Perrier.
Dear Sir,

Some weeks ago I was on the point of writing to the Hon. Mr. Biston on sundry matters connected with Indian Schools, etc., but his resignation from the Ministry rendered my intention impracticable. As the office of Superintendent remains vacant, I take the liberty of addressing you directly, and trust you will kindly give any representations such representations as in your judgment they may be entitled to receive.

Letters from the Department some months ago called attention to the fact there was difficulty in securing the Annual Report from the Principal of the Indian Boarding School at Morley. When a copy of the report was finally sent me by Mr. Hiddrie, I found that the deficit on the year's operations was abnormally large, but I saw no reason to challenge any of the items unless it were the amount for provisions and clothing; but I thought it advisable that a careful enquiry should be made. I accordingly instructed the Rev. James Woodsworth, D.D., who acts as Inspector of Indian Schools on behalf of the Missionary Society, to proceed to Morley and
Toronto,

Enquire fully into the condition and expenditure of the school. With him was associated the Principal of the Brandon Indian Institute, whose business training and knowledge of affairs gave guarantee of thorough work. I enclose a copy of their first report, which covers practically all the points except the expenditure on provisions and clothing, into which they desire to make further enquiry. You will note what they say respecting Mr. Kiddie's diligence, industry and faithfulness, and if there is any doubt it is in reference to his capability for the details of business which involve careful and accurate book-keeping. But if there is any defect here—which is not yet apparent—I am persuaded it arises from having too much to do in other departments.

When a further report comes to hand, I will send you a copy. In the meantime you cannot fail to see how utterly impossible it is to carry on a Boarding School on the present financial basis, and how reasonable is our request that we should receive a substantial grant toward meeting the deficiency of last year, and that the per capita should be increased for the future to at least $100, on a basis of fifty pupils, instead of forty as at present.

Yours faithfully,

A. Sutherland

The Books show that during the past seven years a Total of $44556.70 has been paid to the Institution. This with the $6200 required to meet present indebtedness makes a grant total of $50756.70

While the Church has paid $24396, leaving a difference of $962.

Considering all the existing circumstances it would appear that if the entire Cost of maintenance during the seven years be equally divided between the Department and the Church it would be but a fair solution of this costly and unfortunate situation.

Therefore I would suggest that the present indebtedness of $6200 be divided as follows:

The Department paying $5218.00
The Church paying $962.00

The Methodist Church,
Missionary Department,

Toronto, August 6th, '05.

Dear Sir:

In conversation with you a few weeks ago I promised to write you in regard to various points that came up in the conversation, especially with regard to the Indian Institute at Red Deer and the Boarding Schools at Morley and Norway House.

Accompanying this you will find a memo. of the income and expenditure of the three Institutes above named, covering a period of nine years at Red Deer, six years at McDougall Orphanage, and five years at Norway House. From these figures you will see at a glance that the Institutions referred to have been carried on for a number of years at a very heavy loss to the Missionary Society of the Methodist Church.

In regard to the McDougall Orphanage you will see that the shortage there, which we had to make good, aggregates for the six years nearly twenty thousand dollars, and the greater part of this deficit is owing to the simple impossibility of maintaining a school of the kind on the present per capita grant. You have, I think, in the Department a copy of the report prepared by the Rev. Dr. Woodsworth and the Rev. T. Ferrier, showing the amount of outstanding bills on the 30th of June last. You are also aware of the recommendation made by Mr. Ferrier that the Missionary Society pay the balance due to members of the staff on the date above mentioned, and that the Department

The Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, make Ottawa, Ont.
make a grant to cover the other outstanding accounts. On this point permit me to say that the creditors are pressing very strongly for payment, and it is needful that a settlement be made without delay. I sincerely trust that the Department will accept Mr. Ferrier's recommendation, and even then you will see that our loss has been an enormous one.

To sum up the whole, you will see that the loss to the Society on the three Institutions covering the respective periods mentioned aggregates nearly forty-one thousand dollars. In the case of similar Institutions managed by other Societies, where serious deficits have occurred in the past, the usual practice of such Societies or Churches has been to appeal to the Department to recoup the entire amounts thus expended over and above the per capita grant, and in a good many cases (possibly all of them for aught I know), the demand has been met. I am not disposed to urge a claim of that kind, but I do think that the Department might very well bear one-half of the deficiencies that have been incurred. One thing is certain, we cannot proceed further on the present basis, and so far as I am concerned, I would rather abandon these schools altogether than have to provide a large annual deficiency out of money which our people have given for a different purpose.

Bespeaking prompt and favorable consideration of these matters by the Department, I remain,

Yours faithfully,

One thing is certain, we cannot proceed further on the present basis, and so far as I am concerned, I would rather abandon these schools altogether than have to provide a large annual deficiency out of money which our people have given for a different purpose.

Bespeaking prompt and favorable consideration of these matters by the Department, I remain,

Yours faithfully,

A. Sutherland,
General Secretary.

For the Deputy Sup't. General.

With reference to the deficit of the McDougall Orphanage referred to in communication from the Rev. Dr. Sutherland on the 8th. of August last, I beg to say that from a report made by the Rev. Mr. Ferrier who, in company with the Rev. Dr. Woodsworth, made an audit of the books of this institution for the executive of the Methodist Missionary Society and it was found that there were unpaid accounts existing in January last to the amount of $5,790.11. They placed the cost of conducting the school to the 30th. June last at $409.89 which, added to the above, would make a total deficit of $6,200. The Methodist Missionary Society wishes the Department to assume $5,218.00 of this liability for the reason that the Meth. Miss'y Society had, during the last seven years that this school has been in operation, been called upon to pay a total of $24,396.70 in excess of the Government grant which, during that period, amounted to $20,160. Adding the deficit to these two amounts the total cost of the school for that period would reach $50,756.70; and the proposition of the Church is that the entire cost of management during the last seven years should be equally divided. To make this equal division it would require the payment of $6,218.00 from the Department which is the amount they wish it to contribute. It appears that the creditors are pressing for payment of their outstanding claims, and Mr. Ferrier furnishes in his report (on this file) a statement of the unpaid accounts which amount to $5,790.11 as before stated.

The per capita cost of this school as shown by the audited amounted to $181.00 a year for each of the seven years covered by the auditor's report. This is an exceedingly high rate for a school of this class, and it would show a great lack of economy.
Economy in the management, if not worse. The late Principal has been removed as a consequence of his mismanagement, and the Methodist Church are anxious to have the financial matters of the school straightened out so that the new Principal may have a fair start. There would appear to be no doubt as to the insufficiency of the per capita grant of $72.00 to meet the running expenses of boarding schools in the Territories, and it is for the Department to decide what relief it will afford to the Church towards wiping out this existing deficit.

The Department has paid deficits for other Churches carrying on Indian schools, and the Methodist Missionary Society to as favorable consideration of their claims as any other of the religious bodies similarly situated; but, as in nearly every instance, such deficits have been occasioned by the extravagance and incompetency of the men placed in charge of the schools, I think that the Missionary Society should be called upon to make a better selection of principals and staff for the performance of the work: to do this it would most likely be necessary to hold out better inducements. It would, therefore, seem advisable for the Department to consider whether the present per capita grants are sufficient to counterbalance the increased cost of wages and living.

Dear Dr. Sutherland,

Transmitted herewith is a report of my recent visit to the Morley Mission and the McDougall Orphanage.

After receiving your instructions to go to Morley I called on the Hon. David Laird, Indian Commissioner, for the purpose of having him or his Assistant accompany me; but this was not possible at the time, he having just returned to his office after business in Ottawa and his Assistant being away. However Mr. Laird gave me all assistance possible by correspondence with the Government Agent at Morley.

I spent from Mar. 3rd, to Mar. 6th, at Morley and during that time I had a personal interview with Mr. Fleetham, Rev Mr. Ing and his wife, and with every member of the staff of the Orphanage, also with Miss Buehler who is doing missionary work for the W. M. S.

I preached to three different congregations on the Sabbath and on Monday held a public meeting with the Indians. Had a conference with all the Methodist workers present, and from all the information gathered it appears that trouble had been brewing for some time at the Orphanage. Miss Walsh, the teacher, having had her own way so long in this Institution, her conduct conveyed the idea of her superiority, and it implied that she should be consulted in many matters of the management of the Institution. She thus created an uncomfortable feeling in the general spirit of the Institute, and even went so far as to refuse to recognize
Mrs. Oakley as the matron of the Institution, always sending some other member of the staff or even sending a pupil of the school when she required anything from the Matron. She positively objected to make any effort to remove the unpleasantness or misunderstanding. Mrs. Oakley very naturally resented this treatment, and a snubbing of one another began, one getting as good as she gave; a tit for tat sort of policy seems to have been established which reached a crisis that is well expressed in Miss Walsh's resignation of which the following is a literal copy:

"Jan 8, 06

'Mr. G. B. Oakley,
Principal

Sir,

Please take notice that I now vacate the position of teacher on account of the unreasonable, unladylike and unChristian conduct of the matron toward me during the last month.

I shall pack my Xxxx belongings as quickly as my strength will permit and leave the premises.

Yours etc.

(Sgd) M.A.Walsh."

The acceptance of this resignation by the Principal would have remedied the difficulty had all other people strictly attended to their own business. But this was not the case. Sides were taken among the workers, a couple of indignation meetings were held by the Indians and thus the fire spread.

The acceptance of this resignation by the Principal was not the real cause of the outside interference. The former policy of pauperizing the Indians by feeding them in the Orphanage and giving them supplies to carry home has been changed, and the Red dog is growling for his bone; also, the
going to Calgary where more suitable prices can be obtained when purchasing goods for an institution of this kind than at the local stores and neighboring ranches, has, at least, revealed the teeth of a White dog who might be growling over the lost bone of trade.

In accepting the resignation of the teacher I believe the Principal acted in the best interests of the Institution. It is for the Department and Church to say whether he has a correct policy in not feeding the parents and friends at the Institute also, when he goes to Calgary or wherever he can do the best for his supplies when handling trust funds.

The public meeting held on Monday was well attended by the Indians. Mr. Fleetham, Mr. Oakley and Mr. Ing were also present. I made a plain frank statement of the whole situation, pointing out what the government and church were doing for the people and what we expected of them in return. Mr. Fleetham spoke to them of many matters on the reserve. A somewhat lengthy conference followed in which Miss Walsh's name was never mentioned by the Indians. If they are let alone there will never be anything more from them re the going of the teacher.

At a meeting of the members of the staff, Mr. & Mrs. Ing and Miss Buehler, the whole situation and a few general principles that should govern the conduct of individual members of the staff were thoroughly discussed. A very fine and friendly spirit was manifested and, I believe, any lack of harmony was due to misunderstandings rather than any ill-feeling toward each other. Now that these misunderstandings are removed, there will be no further difficulty with the members of the staff and the missionaries.

The task of securing pupils for the school is a difficult one. The Indians are attempting to hold up the school until the management come to their terms. Two or three boys are continually running away from the school. How to deal with them is a serious question.
for it may be, that in some cases the parents may be more to blame than the pupils.

The only objection they would offer as to why they were not sending their children to school was, that they could not get them home on a visit. A programme will be proposed for a limited visitation on Friday, returning on Saturday in time for preparation for the Sabbath, this to be given to those of good behavior and whose parents will see to their prompt return. If this fails in its desired effect, viz., to remove their objection and to fill the school with pupils, some more stringent method must be adopted. This is certainly a case where compulsory attendance ought to be enforced, for it is an outrage to allow those people in their ignorance to hold up a well-equipped institution when it exists for the express purpose to educate and elevate them.

The agent, Mr. Fleetham, is in full sympathy with the Principal, and is doing what he can to assist him in his work. Mr. Fleetham is placing before the people opportunities of work. To assist him in this the Department have provided about 100 (One Hundred) head of cattle during the past year. They have also set aside 12 (Twelve) sections of timber land from which the Indians can get good wages for hauling logs for lumber to the sawmill and cord-wood to the track at $32 a car load. The great bulk of the ration beef is purchased from them at 7¢ per lb. From these sources of industry the Band has earned about $18,000 during the past year, all of which is certainly in the right direction since it tends toward making the people independent.

The financial management of the orphanage is much improved. The total expenditure with all accounts paid up to March 1st, and salary to March 31st, is $4750. Of this amount

$478 has been spent for cattle
247 " " " horses.
53 " " " harness
145 " " " wagons.
180 " " " an ice house.

This $1100 being spent in the way of assets, the outlook is
that about $5200 will meet the ordinary expenses for the year ending June 30th, 1906.

There have been some improvements made to the Orphanage. The basement floor has been cemented and a good job made with one exception, viz., the cement is not under the wash basins nor bath tubs. This portion of the floor is of common board flooring and is liable to become more or less saturated and unsanitary. Considerable plumbing has been done and the material and workmanship are good. A system of flush closets and three bath-rooms have been fitted out, also one set of wash basins for the boys and another for the girls. A system of hose sufficient to reach any part of each flat with a strong pressure and a good supply of water gives excellent fire protection. An ice house has been built and preparation made for the keeping of a moderate supply of fresh meat during the summer months.

A number of cattle have been purchased and the herd numbers about 70, quite sufficient for a start on a range that will not maintain more than 100 head. The habit of allowing other cattle to run on the range has been discontinued. A good barn of moderate size would be of great benefit to the ranch and farm, and it is hoped that this will be built by the Department in the near future.

I understand the exchange of land has been made between the Department and the Methodist Church in the interest of the Reserve and Mission property. The portion received by the Mission ought to be fenced as soon as possible, for without a fence it is of little use to the missionary.

A home for the Principal ought to receive immediate attention. The bulk of his personal effects are not yet unpacked and will not be until some suitable place is found for their storing.

On general principles one of a family is sufficient on the staff of an institution of this kind.

If the Principal has no family, and his wife has to live
in the main building, she should have some position, and the only suitable position for her is the Matronship. Then, if she is the Matron, she is first the Principal's wife and second the Matron and such a dual position will lead to partiality and it will only be a question of time till it ends in trouble.

I would strongly recommend the building of a home for the Principal and thus have the way open for some other person than his wife to be Matron.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

(Signed) T. Ferrier.

Dear Dr.:

In response to your request contained in a letter sent to me on July 17th, I went to Morley. Bro. T.C. Buchanan went with me. There I met Rev. T. Ferrier and Rev. A. Barnet. We reached Morley on the morning of Aug. 7th, and spent the day there looking into the matters of which you wrote. Bros. Ferrier, Barnet, Buchanan and I had a conference with Bro. Ing in his own home and subjected him to a very close examination as to his attitude to the Orphanage and to the Indians. We questioned him very closely as to his statements to the Indians respecting the Orphanage and its management. We went even beyond this, and asked him about his attitude when statements were not made. After a searching enquiry all went to the Orphanage and there held another enquiry in the presence of Mr. C.B. Oakley, the Principal of the Orphanage. We all think that the following facts were brought out by the enquiry:

1. That Bro. Ing has held very firmly to the idea that schools on the reserve would be a better way of educating the children than the method now adopted. But since Bro. Ferrier sometime ago told the Indians distinctly that such could not be, Bro. Ing asserts positively that he has never said a word to the Indians about a school on the reserve. But he has discussed the matter with the white people around the Mission, and this has given ground to the suspicion that he was not loyal to the school (the Orphanage).

2. Bro. Ing has been persuaded that the conditions necessary to the conservation of good health did not obtain in the Orphanage and has expressed his convictions freely to some of his neighbors, and even to the Principal, but never
to the Indians except on one occasion when he indirectly gave evidence of his conviction by advising one Indian to send his boy to a white man's home. Still it is evident that this conviction has made him, to say the least, apathetic so far as getting children to go to the Orphanage was concerned.

3. We find further that he says that the dislike of the Indians for the Principal was so intense that he felt that there was little use in urging the Indians to send their children to an environment which they so thoroughly disliked. Whether this dislike was due to a more strict regime or to improper management of the school we make no declaration. Mr. Ing thinks it was due to both causes.

4. We find that Mr. Ing's actions and attitude at a meeting called to request Mr. Oakley to reinstate Miss Walsh gave the Indians the impression that he was opposed to the management of the school. We find further that Mr. Ing did not call the meeting and did not lend his influence to the calling of the meeting. Still we consider that he made a mistake in having anything to do with the meeting.

5. We find further that Mr. Ing and Mr. Oakley have never gone out together to get children. The reason for this lies largely at the door of Mr. Ing.

6. We find that Mr. Ing did on one occasion go to get a boy, but he so emphasized the regulations of the school and government that he frightened the Indian and his boy.

We find, then, that Mr. Ing by his attitude, rather than by an outspoken criticism of the school or its methods, has to some extent hindered the school from securing children. We have pointed out to him clearly his error on this point, and have insisted that he must be loyal not only in word but also in act and attitude to the order of things established by the Church and the Government. We find that Mr. Ing has nothing to say against the Indian Agent, but speaks of
him in the highest terms. But Mr. Ing's extreme sympathy for the Indian has made him take some positions which would by the Indian be interpreted as indicating opposition to the "powers that be." I have pointed out to Mr. Ing the seriousness of the situation and have told him that unless harmony and hearty co-operation prevailed we would have to move him to another field. He has promised to co-operate with Mr. Oakley and to go out with him on the reserve to get children.

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd.) J. H. Riddell.

P. S. I can give you a more detailed account of the enquiry if you wish it.

Memorandum

Mr Pedley,

In the year 1886 the Methodist Conference petitioned the Department to subsidize the MacDougall Orphanage at Morley and grant the institution the title to the lands it occupied.

This was agreed to and the school was allowed a per capita grant of $60.00 for 50 pupils and a free patent was issued to the Methodist Missionary Society for 1,170 acres on the Morleyville settlement four miles east of the eastern boundary of the Stony Reserve. The patent contained a reservation that the land shall not be used for any purpose but that of an orphanage for Indian children without the consent of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs expressly given in writing.

The Department was then called upon to provide new buildings which it did at a cost of $11,500.00.

The Department purchased an adjoining lot to obtain a water supply for the school as there was none available.
on the school lands and paid for bringing the water into
the building by a pipe line which cost $2,750.00.

The per capita grant was increased to $72.00 in
1898 for 40 pupils and continued at this rate until the school
was closed in November 1908.

Previous to the recognition of this school there
were two day schools in operation on the Stony Reserve known
as Nos. 1 and 2. The Methodist Church suggested the closing
of these two day schools and the enlargement of the orphan-
age to accommodate all the children available on the reserve
and the No. 2 school was closed in September 1896 and No. 1
in 1898. No. 1 was reopened in 1902 and again closed in 1903,
reopened in 1909 after the closing of the MacDougall orphan-
age and was finally closed in July 1910.

The closing of these schools leaves the 130 child-
ren of school age on the Stony reserve without any chance of
securing an education. The day schools were closed to help
the orphanage but the orphanage closed itself through mis-
management.

The committee appointed by the General Board of Mi-
sions for the Methodist Church report as follows on the
situation at Morley:- This question was thoroughly discussed
and the Committee can see but one way of solving the edu-
cational problem for the Morley Indians, viz; To erect a
commodious and modern Boarding School on a new site somewher e
to the south of the present railway station. The school house should be separate from the residence so that the children who reside near enough may attend as day-pupils. When the Boarding School is filled, a day school might be opened on the north side and a hot mid-day meal provided by rig from the Boarding school."

This recommendation of the Committee has remained in abeyance pending a decision as to the future of the Red Deer Industrial School.

Morley, Alberta, October 7th, 1912.

Regarding matter of proposed school to be built on the Stony Reserve, Morley, Alberta. We, the Indians of the Wesley, Chiniquay and Bearspaw Bands situate on said reserve do hereby solemnly agree to the following propositions:

1st: That the best method for the education of our children is in a residential industrial school erected upon the reserve.

2nd: That if the Indian Department will build for us a modern and well equipped school to accommodate not more than 75 pupils, we will provide, as soon as it is ready for occupation 50 children, and we further promise that we will use our influence with the Indians to fill the school and keep it full as long as we have sufficient children belonging to the above mentioned Bands. All the children are to be subject to the inspection of a medical officer who shall be appointed by the Indian Department.

3rd: That if at any time the children shall run away from the school we shall be responsible for immediately returning them.

4th: That the school shall be operated for eleven months each year and that all the pupils shall be given a holiday of one month's duration each year. If at any time a parent is considered by the medical officer to be seriously ill and such parent asks an extra vacation for the pupil the request shall be granted.

5th: We request that the Methodist church manage the school according to the rules and regulations of the Indian Department.

We sign this document believing it to be binding upon our successors in office, and in harmony with the wish of a large majority of our people.

I have the honor to report as follows in regards to your letter # 116861/4 - 15th inst., and also to your letter # 116963/1 - 5th ultimo.

In reference to the latter I beg to say that Rev. Mr. Barner, of the Red Deer Industrial School, was here last week and I attended three meetings with him and the Stony Indians, to talk about building and operating a school on this Reserve. As Mr. Barner was acting for the Dept. in this matter I did not want to report on same until you had heard from him, so as to avoid any confusion in the deal. However, I enclose herewith copy of a resolution signed at that time, the original of which is held by Mr. Barner.

This resolution, in my opinion, is not of much effect, for the reason that there are double the number of Indians on this reserve, of school age, than that mentioned viz - 75, and if a school were built to accommodate this number only it would lead to trouble in case the Dept. were to enforce a school attendance upon every child of school age on the Reserve. Another reason against it is that the Indians absolutely refused to sign away their right to a day school, though Mr. Barner talked to them for hours in an endeavor to have it included in the report.

The Secretary,

Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Mr. Barner gave the Indians some good reasons against having a day school on this particular Reserve, and I fully agree with him when he states that the children will have no home on the reserve when the parents go away on their annual hunt, which lasts about three months, unless it is decided to have a boarding school, as it would break up a school to allow the children three months holidays every year to go hunting with their parents.

The Stonies held a meeting with Mr. Campbell and myself early in August, and the ones who attended were all in favor of a day school only, they would not talk about a boarding school being established here at all.

In view of the above you will see that the Stonies are very changeable, and really do not know what they want in the school line, but the fact remains that they want a school of some kind, and are willing to send their children if a school is erected.

Some of the educated Indians, who attended school for years, say they want a residential industrial school, to be erected upon the Reserve, but they do not want to send their children to a school run by missionaries. This brings in something entirely new I believe, but it is the outspoken opinion of some of the leaders of the tribe, and they told Mr. Barner this when he held council with them last week.

We have in the above three distinct propositions, and it will take a visit here from some person in authority with the Department, who is used to school matters, to find out what is really best to do in the affair. From my position as Agent I cannot give an opinion without getting into trouble with the church, but I will give my endeavors to help out on whatever is finally decided upon.
In reply to your enquiry as to accommodation here for a school and teachers quarters, I beg to say that there is a splendid site ½ mile west of agency for buildings, with a spring on the hill above same which would deliver water to top floor of any building erected. There is no building on Reserve at all that could be used in connection with the proposed school, as the McDougall Orphanage is about six miles east of the Reserve. Also in regards to your query re day school, I beg to say that I do not believe it would be a success.

I have the honor to remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

In personal communications from the resident missionary on the Morley reserve west of Calgary, information has been brought to my attention concerning the growing desire on the part of the band to have school facilities provided. During the last 12 years 80 young people have grown up on the Morley reserve, only 40 miles from Calgary, without any education whatever. I understand the Indians waited on the agent to ask for a school and Mr. Yeomans promised to refer the matter to Ottawa. I am of the opinion that a residential school is what is needed at this point.

MEMO FOR FILE:

I visited the Morley Reserve this summer and informed certain members of the Indian Band that it was not possible for the Department to erect a boarding school on their reserve in the immediate future. I learned that there was a total of 130 children of school age. Families are scattered over the reserve, hunting and lumbering and wandering to neighboring ranches and farms for day labour. I am of the opinion that the whole band should be moved to a more suitable reserve site, as it is practically impossible to earn a respectable living as they are situated at present.

I am favourably disposed to make a grant to the resident missionary, of $60 for the coming winter to meet the express charges on lantern slides supplied gratis by the Extension Department of the University of Alberta. These slides are used in a series of educational lectures to the members of the band during the winter months.

Dear Mr. Stewart:

RE MORLEY, ALTA.,
INDIAN BOARDING SCHOOL.

At the recent session of the General Board of Missions, held in October last, strong representations were made relative to the desirability of proceeding as soon as possible to provide a Boarding School for the Indian children on the Morley Reserve, Alberta.

After due consideration, the Board adopted the following resolutions:

"WHEREAS no school facilities have been provided for the Indians at Morley for some years;
AND WHEREAS a Boarding School was planned for, but delayed by the War and post-war conditions;
THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED THAT we urge upon the Government the necessity of proceeding with the Boarding School as originally planned for, with the utmost dispatch;
AND FURTHER THAT provision be made for converting the present hospital building into a dwelling for resident pupils, and using the new church for classrooms; thus accommodating twelve to fifteen pupils in dormitories and caring for the ten children resident adjacent to the agency.

The above plan subject to reasonable co-operation by the Indians."

The proposal to convert the present hospital building into a dwelling for resident pupils and to use the new church for classrooms is suggested as a temporary expedient and not by any means as a substitute for the Boarding School for which we trust the Government will soon provide necessary funds.

It is many years since the Indians on the Morley Reserve have had adequate facilities for the education of their children, and we cannot regard it as other than deplorable that a generation of Indian children is growing up on this Reserve without even the elements of an English education. We trust that the necessary appropriation to provide the Boarding School will be made at the next session of Parliament.

I am,
Very respectfully yours,

Hon. Charles Stewart,
Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,-

Last week I paid a visit to Morley, Alberta and discussed with your Agent and our missionary what might be considered as a policy for carrying on our school work. I would respectfully suggest the following:

1. That all supplies needed and have to be purchased, be done so through your Agent on the recommendation of Mr. Staley. That the Agent be responsible for keeping up the supply of wood and water. For the latter there is an elevated tank in the building which will hold about five barrels. The need can be met by attention every other day. The river is close by but too far for small children to carry the water.

2. That Mr. Staley have the over-sight and care of the buildings looking after the welfare and care of the pupils and teachers. In other words he will be the principal without any salary consideration from the Department.

3. That no parents or friends be given any meals at the school. If it is found that large pupils attend late in the day for the sake of the hot dinner, that they be ruled out at meal time.

4. That a general announcement be given regarding the opportunity of sending the limited number to reside in the school, but that no pressure of any kind be brought to bear upon the parents to bring their children. That all who bring them be required to sign the usual application form required for admittance to our residential schools.

5. That all legitimate means be used to secure a regular attendance of all children of school age to the classes.

Mr. Staley has kindly offered to give special night lessons to any over sixteen who desire the same. The policy of giving meals to parents and friends became a system of pauperizing these people at the MacDougall Orphanage years ago. I counted as many as twenty-one sitting down at one meal and they even demanded food for others at home. When the principal was changed and this policy discontinued, they refused to send their children. When they got them home on holiday they failed to return them! This was the reason the boarding school was closed. If the Department approve of these recommendations it might be well to have them incorporated with any other suggestions the Department see fit to make and sent officially to Mr. Staley and your Agent. I believe both of these men will heartily endorse the above.

Yours sincerely,

On Sept. 13th, I examined all the children of the Indian school at Morley, Alta. These children are just entering school, and a few, perhaps 20%, appear undernourished. The majority have signs of pulmonary tuberculosis but none have cough or expectoration. The majority have palpable glands in the neck, but no case of open sores, or scrofula. One case of this which was had a year ago, is now completely healed. I arranged to have one girl in the school who is nearly blind see Dr. J. H. Murray of Calgary. I have not heard from him yet. A boy in the school also has had severe inflammation of eyes but his sight is not yet seriously impaired.

The food and the sanitary conditions
appeared to be excellent.

I believe that a better supply of cow's milk would be a great benefit.

Madam:—

The Department is in receipt of a report from Inspector Buchanan, who visited the Morley Indian Day School on the 25th ultimo.

In his report the inspector makes the following suggestions which the Department trusts you will keep in mind and carry into effect as far as possible:

(1) Pupils should be urged and encouraged to make the greatest effort each day. Reading and language work should be stressed. Arithmetic should be made as practical as possible, with particular reference to the use of money and ordinary measurements.

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

Regarding the attached letter from J. T. Shaw, M.P., referring to the lack of school accommodation on the Morley Reserve, I beg to say that there is at present a school of the semi-boarding type being conducted. Fifteen children are in residence and besides approximately 25 children attend irregularly as day pupils. The school is conducted under the auspices of the Methodist Church. The classroom activities are carried on in the building that was formerly used as a hospital in connection with the old McDougall Orphanage boarding school. Quarters are fitted up in this building as a residence for the teachers and for the children.

The members of the Band, the Church Authorities and the late Agent Yeomans have requested from time to time that a boarding school be established. There are about 130 children of school age on the reserve. The families are scattered over the reserve, hunting and lumbering and wandering to neighbouring ranches and farms for day labour.

We have two teachers and a cook employed at the semi-boarding school which is now being conducted. One of the teachers, besides assisting in the classroom, also performs certain field matron's duties on the reserve as her time will permit.

Commissioner Graham, in April last, recommended that two detached buildings of the bungalow type, one for boys and one for girls, and another building to contain a dining room and kitchen should be erected to provide accommodation for at least 50 children. He estimated the cost of the buildings to be about $20,000. He was requested to furnish a sketch of the proposed buildings. We have no funds provided for the extension of the work or the erection of buildings on this reserve. There are, no doubt, a number of children who are receiving no education.

I find that Mr. Ferrier has noted for next year's Estimates the providing of a grant to erect the buildings as recommended by the Commissioner. The amount this Department expended during the last fiscal year in payment of salaries of teachers, food, clothing, repairs and other expenses for the maintenance of the semi-boarding school was $3,842.24.

NEW SCHOOL FOR INDIAN CHILDREN NOT BIG ENOUGH

On Opening Day Institution at Morley Has to Turn Twenty-five Away

FORMAL CEREMONY HELD ON THURSDAY

Resolution Expresses Appreciation to Department for Opening School

With accommodation for sixty Indian boys and girls, the new school at the Morley reserve, recently completed by the federal government at a cost of $15,000, proved inadequate to meet the demand according to information brought back to the city by Dr. A. M. Scott, superintendent of Calgary schools, who attended the formal opening of the institution Thursday.

Before noon of the day that the school was opened, the principal, Rev. L. J. Staley, found that he had 25 more pupils than he could accept; or a total of 85.

Accommodation Provided

This school provides accommodation for 60 boys and girls to live in the institution, as well as classroom space for the school attending for day pupils not living in the school.

On behalf of the institution, Mr. and Mrs. Staley welcomed the visitors at the formal opening; who had come from Calgary, Okotoks, Banff, as well as from Morley and the reserve. First, under the direction of the teachers, a programme of outdoor sports for boys and girls was carried out at a nearby lake, which afterwards led to the rising roofs of the school, where Mr. Riley presided over the gathering, welcomed the guests and called on Rev. T. Ferrier, representative of the Christian Education for the United Church, who gave a brief account of the history of Indian treaties in the west, outlined the policy of the church and the government regarding Indian schools, and recounted the steps leading up to the opening of the present institution in Morley. He congratulated the principal and staff, praised the contractors and financiers, on behalf of the department of Indian affairs, declared the school open. Mrs. John MacDougall followed with a carefully prepared account of the story of the MacDougall orphanage and training school over forty years ago, and indicated some of the difficulties and struggles of the early days.

Resolution Passed

After these two interesting addresses a motion was proposed and unanimously accepted by all present as follows:

"Resolved, that the members of the Calgary presbytery and all others here present do place on record their appreciation of the work of the federal government through the department of Indian affairs, in creating and furnishing this well-equipped Indian-hostelling school at Morley for the education and training of the boys and girls of the reserve. We further express the hope that this school may be used mainly in the hands of the United Church of Canada of developing a fine type of Christian citizenship among the Stony Indians in the future. We also urge that this situation be forwarded through the Rev. T. Ferrier, to the department of Indian affairs at Ottawa."

Following the resolution, words of appreciation were expressed for the faithful work of the pioneer missionaries of Alberta, especially the late Rev. George MacDougall and his son, afterwards so well known throughout our province. Among those present were Mrs. John MacDougall, as well as other members of the MacDougall family, several of whom were present at the opening, including Mrs. John MacDougall, Mrs. Douglas MacDougall, as well as Mrs. Nellie Macdonald, a daughter of the late Rev. George MacDougall.

The first Indian orphanage and training school in temporary quarters was opened twenty-five years ago with fifteen boys and girls. One of these, George McLean, was present at the opening and was called upon to say a few words to the gathering. NEW SCHOOL FOR INDIAN CHILDREN NOT BIG ENOUGH

On Opening Day Institution at Morley Has to Turn Twenty-five Away

FORMAL CEREMONY HELD ON THURSDAY

Resolution Expresses Appreciation to Department for Opening School

With accommodation for sixty Indian boys and girls, the new school at the Morley reserve, recently completed by the federal government at a cost of $46,000, has proved inadequate to meet the needs, according to information brought back to the city by Dr. A. M. Scott, superintendent of Calgary schools, who attended the formal opening of the institution on Thursday.

Before noon of the day that the school was opened, the principal, Rev. E. J. Staley, found that he had 25 more pupils than he could accept, or a total of 85.

Accommodation Provided

This school provides accommodation for 60 boys and girls to live in the institution, as well as classroom space in the church adjacent for day pupils not living in the school.

On behalf of the institution, Mr. and Mrs. Staley welcomed the visitors at the formal opening, who had come from Calgary, Cochrane, and Banff, as well as from Morley and the reserve. First, under the direction of the teachers, a programme of entertainment for boys and girls was carried out at 2 o'clock, after which all adjourned to the dining room of the school, where Mr. Staley presided over the gathering, welcoming the guests, and called on Rev. T. Ferrier, superintendent of Indian Education for the United Church, who gave a brief account of the history of Indian treaties in Canada, outlined the policy of the church and the government regarding Indian schools, and recounted the steps leading up to the opening of the present institution in Morley. He congratulated the principal and staff, praised the congregation, and formally on behalf of the department of Indian affairs declared the school open. Mrs. John MacDougall followed with a carefully prepared account of the story of the inception and development of the MacDougall orphanage and training school over forty years ago, and indicated some of the difficulties and struggles in the early days.

Resolution Passed

After these two interesting addresses a motion was proposed and unanimously accepted by all present as follows:

"Resolved, that the members of the Calgary presbytery and all others here present, do place on record their appreciation of the work of the Federal government through the department of Indian affairs in erecting and furnishing this well-equipped Indian boarding school at Morley for the education and training of the boys and girls of the reserve. We further express the hope that this school may be the means in the hands of the United Church of Canada of promoting the growth of Christian citizenship among the Stony Indians in the years to come. We also request that this resolution be forwarded through the Rev. T. Ferrier, to the department of Indian affairs at Ottawa."

Following the resolution, words of appreciation were expressed for the faithful work of the pioneer missionaries, Mr. Albert Staley and the late Rev. George MacDougall and his son, afterwards so well known throughout the province, the late Rev. Dr. John MacDougall, as well as other members of the MacDougall family, several of whom were present at the opening, including Mrs. John MacDougall and her daughter, Miss MacDougall, as well as Mrs. Wood, of Edmonton, a daughter of the late Rev. George MacDougall.

The first Indian orphanage and training school in temporary quarters was opened over forty years ago with fifteen boys and girls. One of these, George McLean, was present at the opening and was called upon to say a few words in the gathering. He spoke in good English, setting forth his idea that Indian and white people all belong to one great family, but that in his opinion the Indian has gone far in the way he needed the help of the white people to enable them to develop a civilization which would put them on a level with the white man. He expressed his pleasure at the opening of the school and hoped it would be beneficial to all the boys and girls of the reserve.

Following a musical programme, the tea was served by the staff of the institution and the guests having examined the building throughout, expressed themselves as thoroughly delighted with the progress being made and left with the feeling that a great step in advance had been taken by the opening of this school at Morley.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to report on the Indian Residential School at Morley. Just before I arrived there they had an epidemic of Influenza at the school and practically all the children had been sick. Two boys took Pneumonia and one of these died, but the other was on a fair way to recovery when I left and the other children were all up and around before I left the Agency. A special nurse came up from Calgary and was still there when I left.

The Indians were all excited over the sickness and seemed to blame the school authorities, and some of them were very bitter against the Principal. They presented me with a letter and petition. You will admit the letter has not very much meaning to it, but they persisted that it go forward to the Department, and I would ask the Department to acknowledge the receipt of same through the Agent. I met the Chief and Councillors and enquired into their grievances. They seemed to be under the impression that they had a say in the management of the school, and further, that they were barred admission to the school when their children were sick. I informed the Indians that they could not possibly have any say in the management of the school as the Principal was responsible to the Department, but that they could always put their complaints before the Agent or the Inspector when he visited the Agency. I enquired into the matter of them
always allowed to see their children if they are sick, and any time the parents come around, when the children are not in school, they are allowed to see them, so the Indians have no ground for complaint in this matter. I went over the school and saw the children, and in my opinion, they are well fed and well cared for. The mistake that was made, which probably brought about the colds, was that the children were allowed to go out with their parents to a feast held between Christmas and New Years, and the weather being extremely cold, a number of the children caught colds, and naturally it soon went through the school. The Principal admitted this, but the parents are just as much to blame, as they went and got the children and everything would probably have been well if the weather had been a little milder. However, it is most regrettable that a death occurred.

You will note that in the last part of the letter handed in by the Indians, they state "for we want a preacher that is honest and true to the Indians". Some of the Indians made the remark that they could not listen to a preacher they did not believe in. I told the Chief and Councillors that I was quite satisfied with the way in which the school was being managed and that I intended to report that way to the Department, but if they were not satisfied with the missionary part of Mr. Staley's work, they had better take the matter up with the Rev. Mr. Barner, Western Supt. of Missions, and the Rev. Mr. Ferrier, who is, I believe, still Supt. of the Methodist schools that went into the Union. I also told them that as far as the school work was concerned, I was quite satisfied that it was being carried out to the satisfaction of the Department.

I have the honour to be,

REPORT.

Re:- Isaiah Crawler - Truant, Indian Residential School, Morley, Alta.

I have the honour to report that on the 17th inst., Rev. H. J. Staley principal of the Indian residential school at Morley, Alta., reported to me that a fire had been located and extinguished in the basement of the school on the night of the 16th inst. Upon some of the boys being questioned by Mr. Staley the following morning, they stated that the above named had been the one who had started the fire.

Upon making investigations in connection with this matter I took down the following statements:

MacFarlane Dixon stated:—"I am a pupil in the Indian residential school at Morley. On the 15th inst., Isaiah Crawler asked me to help him to burn down the school building, he spoke to me several times about burning down the building, but I did not help or see him set the fire."

Steinbauer Bar stated:—"I am a pupil in the Indian residential school at Morley. On Sunday the 16th inst., Isaiah Crawler told me that he was going to make a fire in the corner of the building in the coal bin, he asked me to stay on the steps and look out for Mr. Candy and let him know if he was coming, but instead of staying on the steps I went down to the barn. I did not see Isaiah start the fire."

Horace Rider stated:—"I am a pupil in the Indian residential school at Morley. On the 16th inst., before going to Sunday school Isaiah Crawler sent me to Dick Amos for some matches. I went to Dick Amos who was in the barn and got some matches from him and gave them to Isaiah. After sunday school Isaiah told me that he was going to build a fire in the Coal bin, and not for me to tell anyone. I did not see Isaiah start the fire, the first that I knew of the fire being lit was with the fire alarm ringing."

Dick Amos stated:—"I am a pupil in the Indian residential school at Morley. On Sunday the 16th inst., Isaiah Crawler sent Horace Rider to me for some matches which I gave to him. Before sunday school I saw Isaiah put some wood in the corner of the building in the coal bin and put some coal oil on it. He noticed that I was watching him and told me to get out of the building. After sunday school all the other boys went up stairs to take off their clothes, Isaiah went into the coal bin and I followed him, he told me if I did not get out he would hit me. I then went up stairs and in a short time the fire alarm was sounded."
On the morning of the 17th inst., Isaiah Crawler, age 16, ran away from the school, and upon making enquiries as to his whereabouts, James Rider, Stoney Indian, informed me that on the night of the 18th inst., Isaiah Crawler had come to his camp and had left soon after he had arrived, saying that he wanted to return but did not like the Police to take him back. Rider stated that he expected Crawler would return to his camp again that night the 19th, and requested that he should return him to the school. As there was no charge laid against Crawler I informed Rider that it would be in order for him to bring him Isaiah in, which he did accompanied by George McLean on the 20th inst.

On the 20th inst., Mr. Pringle, Indian Agent, Morley, Alta., had Isaiah Crawler brought before him in the office of the Indian School, and questioned him regarding the fire. Crawler stated that he had started the fire at the instigation of three other boys, namely, Steinbauer, Bar, age 14, Horace Rider age 16 and Dick Ames age 12, saying that if the school burnt down he would not have to attend school anymore. Mr. Pringle then questioned the other three boys mentioned, and with the exception of Dick Ames they denied having anything to do with the fire. Dick Ames stated that when he gave Horace Rider the matches for Isaiah, he knew what Isaiah wanted them for but was too afraid of Crawler to report.

After Mr. Pringle had questioned the boys he ordered Rev. J. Staley, principal of the school to punish Isaiah Crawler by giving him 12 straps, 6 on each hand, and that he be sent to the Indian residential school at Edmonton. At this time I enquired from Mr. Pringle if he did not intend taking criminal action against Crawler for attempt of Arson, he informed me that he did not intend taking any criminal action until such time as he heard from the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa, as he had reported the matter to them, but it was quiet in order for him to have Isaiah punished by Mr. Staley under the regulations relating to the education of Indian Children.

I might state that Isaiah Crawler's parents who are camping four miles west of the Bar-O Ranch were not informed that Isaiah had attempted to burn down the school and were not consulted in this matter.

Mr. Staley did not carry out the Agent's orders regarding to punishing Crawler, but took him to Calgary on the 22nd inst., handing him over to the principal of the Indian residential school of Edmonton that point.

Dear Mr. Scott,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 2nd of October.

When I was in Morley a few days ago I took a look over this building. I think it is in pretty fair state of repair at the present time. I noticed there was a large stove in it, which I think would be sufficient to heat the building. Mr. Staley assured me that the Indians would supply the wood required to heat the building, that he had an excellent crop of vegetables which he could use for the children, and that he was satisfied he could get enough subscriptions to make suitable sleeping accommodation in the building for this year. If the Department could see its way to give us the use of that building in its present condition from now until the first of July next year, I am satisfied that we could take care of from fifteen to twenty children with very little additional expense.

I also note your remarks regarding some of the Indian children on this Reserve going to Edmonton. I quite appreciate that in an ordinary case that would be the common sense thing to do; but from my experience the Indians are just like big children. They will not consent to their children being sent away. If we get them away, it will mean that they will be away a few months at school; then when they come home at Christmas, their parents will not let
Deputy Superintendent General,

them go back. At least, that was the experience we had years ago when we tried to get the children to go to the Edmonton School. My recollection is that owing to failure of the Department to recognize that the Indians themselves were but children and to bad advice giving to the Indians, it practically meant that these children had no school for years. I am not blaming any one for this. I do not know, except from hear-say, what the real facts were, but I think my guess would probably be correct when I say that the Indians themselves were only to blame.

The Rev. Staley may be out-spoken, but I am satisfied that he has the welfare of the Indians at heart, and that he is doing a wonderful work among them.

If I understand the situation correctly, if we send some of these Morley children to Edmonton, the Government will pay the extra per capita tax for the children going to Edmonton. Personally speaking I cannot see why this per capita tax should not be granted in the event of the children going to the Morley school. I quite realize that money is very scarce, but I do believe that even if we cannot get the per capita tax, we can finance it for this year, if you could see your way clear to give us the use of this building for the next few months.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Dr. Scott,

Many thanks for your kind letter herein. I forwarded it on to Mr. Staley. He now realizes that under the existing circumstances, it is difficult to do anything for this year. He is, however, still in hopes that we can do something to take care of some of the children on the Reserve. I appreciate very much the trouble you are going to in regard to these Indians.

As I see it, the following facts have considerable to do with the Indians. The Stony Indians came here many years ago, probably from the shores of Lake Huron. They have a different dialect, and in other ways are quite different from the rest of the Indians on the western plains.

The Cree language is spoken solely in the School at Edmonton. Should the Stony Indian go to that School, it would be almost as strange to him as going to a White School, or as sending a French Canadian child up to Western Canada.

In any event, all the larger boys are being let out of the Morley School to make room for the smaller ones. I am satisfied if we attempt to send any of these children away to Edmonton, that it will cause a lot of uneasiness in the minds of those who have younger children going to the School. Ordinarily speaking, your suggestion of sending them to Edmonton would be the proper thing to do, but from my point of view, it will probably do more harm than good to attempt to do so.
Dr. Duncan C. Scott,

I also think that we can always approach a subject better by knowing the man who is in charge. For an example, the Rev. Staley was probably the greatest football player the Old Country ever produced. While he was in University, he was the champion boxer in Western Canada. He is a wonderful man; a little cut-spoken and head-strong, but he has a heart of gold. He is as honest as they make them. I am satisfied he is doing excellent work among the Stoney Indians, and that he is spending nearly half his stipend in assisting them.

I have tried, and I think with some measure of success, to have him view this from the Department's standpoint. Things are going very well at the Reserve, but I think we could make certain changes which would be a wonderful improvement.

There are practically 625 Stoneys. Around 125 are at Nordegg, and 500 on the Reserve at Morley. They have an Indian Agent, who has had little experience with Indian work. I believe he is doing the best he can, but I feel that he is not giving satisfaction to the Indians. They also have employed an Indian by the name of Dan Wildman to act as stockman. Dan gets $60.00 per month. From reports, I gather that he knows about as much about stock as the ordinary Indian child. In any event, he is a local man, and the Indians are very much dissatisfied with both Wildman and the agent. Remember, I do not say they are justified, but I am telling you facts. The agent gets around $1900.00 a year and everything found. The nurse, I believe, is paid around $140.00 per month, and the doctor gets $600.00 per year for his work. The last two are a charge on the Indian Fund. The Clerk, who is about to retire, gives wonderful service.

My idea is that the personnel of the staff should be entirely changed. I would recommend putting a medical man in as agent. Hinton could be transferred to another Reserve. I would also recommend that the new Clerk who is appointed
Dr. Duncan S. Scott,

should be a practical stockman; and that you continue on
the nurse, but that she take her instructions from the
Indian Agent, who would be a medical man.

There has been considerable in the newspapers
in regard to the disease known as Trachoma among the Indians.
I do not believe this disease is nearly as serious as the
newspapers make out. I understand that some years ago, a
doctor by the name of Wall made an examination on the Morley
Reserve; that he examined 250 Indians, and that out of these
250, 129 were suffering from Trachoma. There has been several
examinations since then. Some physicians call it "granulated
eyelids", while others have another technical name for it.
The Alberta Provincial Health Officer has examined them,
and I understand pronounced it Trachoma.

From inquiries I have made, I believe that
this disease can be practically stamped out within six months
or a year if proper precautions are taken. My suggestion
would be that after the re-organization as above suggested,
the old hospital be opened and the Indians receive regular
treatment from the nurse and the agent. I understand that in
a very few instances will it be necessary for the Indians to
remain in the Hospital any length of time. Most of them can
be treated in their homes. I am quite frank to admit to you
that I am not in a position to give advice along this line.
I am only a layman, but I am greatly interested in the Indians.
I try to help them as best I can. I believe that if you look
into my suggestion, you will find in the end it will work out to
the interest of all concerned.

I have been associated with the Indians long
enough to realize that it is difficult to know just what is
best for them. If, after investigation, any of these suggestions
meet with your approval, I will be well pleased. On the other
Dr. Duncan G. Scott,

hand, if they do not, I trust that you will consider this letter in the spirit in which it is written.

Dear Mr. Peacock,

I have to thank you for your letter of November 3rd, to the contents of which I have given careful attention.

I think we mutually understand the school question on the Stony reserve, and I hope when things improve that we may be able to provide educational facilities on this reserve that will meet all the needs of the case. I share your good opinion of the Reverend Mr. Staley.

As regards the arrangements you suggest, I may remark that Daniel Wildman is not a stockman, but an interpreter. He has no duties whatever in connection with the cattle. The Agent is himself expected to look after the cattle industry.

We have several Agents who are also Physicians and whose duties are dual,—that is administrative and medical. As you know, Doctor Murray at the Sarcee Reserve is one of these and we have two in the north, at Fort Resolution and at Fort Simpson. Dr. O. Bourget is at Fort Resolution and Dr. W. A. M. Trussell is at Fort Simpson. We have also Dr. W.L.Tyler at Moose Factory, James Bay Agency, Ontario. It might eventually come to the establishment of such a position at the Stony Reserve. I should like, however, to leave that matter in abeyance for some time.

As you note, the question of Trachoma on the reserve has come up for public discussion and that question must supersede all others at the moment. I am making arrangements which I hope may be successful to send an expert to the reserve, and we will rely on his experience to deal as effectively as possible with the situation.

Thanking you again for your letter, and with kindest regards, I am

Yours sincerely,
