Indian Schools Represented in Colorful Choral Contests.

Monday

Children from the Morley Indian reserve and white pupils from nearby villages and outlying districts gathered at the festival platform for competitions which were judged by well-known Calgary adjudicators. Maurice Jacot, former adjudicator, paid glowing tribute to the enthusiasm and potentialities of the Indian school chorus from Morley. The afternoon session was opened by the public school choruses in all grades up to VII, part of whom came from rural villages and city schools, and acted songs which proved wonderful entertainment for audience and competitors alike.

For many of the out-of-towners, the experience of a street car ride around Calgary proved exciting, but not so for the small town children from Morley reserve, who were invited to attend the day's festivities, but declined, saying they preferred to remain at their school for the duration of the contest.

Mr. Jacot, in remarking upon their choice, said: "It was the beginning of great things and their natural musical abilities cannot be overestimated."

Black Diamond school children, led by George Johnson, sang a song competition during the afternoon. Morley Indian school chorus, which had been given marks 85 in their classes, when they were granted a special privilege of being able to perform after having been unable to reach the city in time to participate in the afternoon's activities, sang earlier in the day. McDougall school grade III, with 84 marks, was second place, followed by Black Diamond school grade III chorus, with 83 marks; both classes final results showed.

Hillhurst school grade I class, which sang Monday morning, was praised for the splendid spirit of its singing and ability to make itself heard in the class.

Black Diamond chorus, grades I and II, scored again with 82 marks, singing a charming "White Song," presented by Miss E. M. Ward, public school chorus from High River was second with 81 marks. There were only two entries.

Passed Choirs

Victoria school choir, led by Miss Aldous, sang a song in grades II and III competition, while Hillhurst choir sang a grade IV song. Both choirs competed with 85 marks, closely followed by the only other entry, Miss E. M. Ward's school chorus, which secured 84 marks. The festival platform was given a thoroughly enjoyable performance of the songs under Mr. Jacot's direction.

Miss Evelyn Aldous, leading Rose View school grades VI and VII, sang a song in her class, for which there was no competition.

Black Diamond grades V and VI chorus was close behind the winner of its class with 83 marks. In the competition for grades VII, choir won the contest with 82 marks.

Mr. Jacot led both evening sessions. Adjudicator Jacot arranged the program. The best marked songs were "Song of the Indians," sung by Miss Ward's school, and "Ode to Joy," by Miss Aldous' choir.

Indian Schools Represented In Colorful Choral Contests Monday

Children from the Morley Indian reserve met with pupils from city schools Monday afternoon's festival platform for competitions which were attended by a large audience. Maurice Jacobsen, adjudicator, discussed the musical instinct and potentialities of the Indian school choirs from the reserve after the festival was featured by public school choruses in three grades. The festival included choirs by rural, town, village and city schools, and achieved a high degree of choral delightfulness for audience and competitors alike.

For many of the out-of-town listeners the city's offer of a street car ride around Calgary proved enticing, but not so far.

The small Indian children from Morley reserve, who were invited by the city's invitation, politely declined, saying they preferred to remain at their own level and watch the other contests. Mr. Jacobsen, in remarking upon their choice, said, "I am sure we are at the beginning of great things and their talent is not to be overestimated."

Black Diamond school children, under Mr. E. Bower, won many honors in competition during the day. Morley Indians sang first place and each class secured 90 marks or more. They sang on Monday afternoon, after having been unable to reach the festival grounds earlier in the day. The second place went to the Black Diamond grade III chorus, with 85 marks; and Black Diamond grade II chorus, with 82 marks.

First honors in these classes, final results showed:

The school grade I class, which sang on Monday morning, was praised for the quality of its singing and was granted 85 marks to place first in this class.

Robson, sang in grades I and II competition, while Hillhurst chorus from grades III and IV won its competition with 84 marks, followed closely by the only other entrant, Turner Valley public school choir, in the same category. INSPECTOR'S OFFICE:
CALGARY, ALTA. Jan. 13th, 1933.

Dear Dr. McGill,

I have the honor to bring to your attention that I have just reported on an inspection of the Indian Residential School at Morley. The Principal brought to my attention, which he has on several occasions, that there are 75 children in residence in this school, and they only received a grant for 65. Five of the children sleep in the principal's house. Room for the other five additional has been made at the school, and the place does not seem to be over-crowded, as the dormitories have high ceilings and lots of ventilation.

The reason for having ten more children in the school than the grant calls for is that there are still thirty children of school age on the Reserve that we have no room for.

The parents come to the principal and request to have their children admitted into school and in this way it is often very hard for the principal to turn them down. However, he is not complaining very much.

The other matter that I wish to bring to your attention is this, that this school is in a different position from a number of others, in this way, on account of the Reserve being all hills and rock no farming is carried on. There is no revenue from cattle, and all the school has to depend on to finance, is the grant, whereas some of the others get considerable revenue from their farming and stock-raising operations.
I understand that it costs the church about $7000.00 a year, over and above the grant, to maintain this school. If after the end of the fiscal year this school could receive the grant for the additional ten children it would lighten the burden that the church is now carrying.

The church authorities may have brought this to your attention. If they haven't, I am aware that they intend to do so, and this letter is written for the purpose of letting you know exactly how the situation stands, from my point of view.

I have the honor to be,

Your obedient servant

M. Christianson
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Alberta Inspectorate.

Sir:

I have been directed to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 13th instant, regarding the number of pupils in attendance at the Morley Indian Residential School. In this connection it is noted there are 75 children in residence, while the per capita grant is allowed for 65 only. It is noted, further, that sleeping accommodation for five children is provided in the Principal's residence.

When this school was erected, it was to provide accommodation for not more than 60 or 65 pupils, and it is considered, in order to prevent overcrowding in the dormitories, that not more than 65 children should be accommodated in the building. At the present time, there are no funds to increase either the pupilage or the accommodation, and, for the coming fiscal year, grant can be provided for only 65 pupils. As the admission of any children over that number adds to the cost, the Principal should seriously consider reducing the enrolment to the number for which grant is provided. We might keep not more than three children in excess of the 65 allowed, in order that they could replace any absentees and the average be maintained so as to draw the full grant.

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

Re: Per Capita Grant - Morley Indian Residential School.

I have been thinking a good deal about the failure of the Department to include in the Estimates for the current year an amount to cover an increase in the per capita grants at Morley from 65 to 75, as was agreed upon when I was in Ottawa in February. I wish to quote from a letter which I sent to Mr. Staley following that visit:

"Re Increase in Per Capita Grants: I visited Ottawa on February 15th and had extended interviews with the new Deputy and several other officials of the Indian Department. I spent a long time with them considering the Morley situation. I feel that there is, under the circumstances, a lot of justification for their attitude. The School was built by agreement with the former Methodist Church to accommodate 60 pupils. Gradually, the number was increased until the financing of the situation was found to be too great a burden and insistent representations were made to Ottawa to increase the per capita to sixty-five. I was faced on this occasion with the necessity of asking that the per capita be allowed for seventy-five children who are actually in residence, although - as the officials of the Department very rightly pointed out, in spite of a definite agreement limiting the number of children to sixty - the number had been gradually increased to seventy-five, without consultation either with them or with the Board of Home Missions.

"I pointed out to the officials of the Department of Indian Affairs that with a decrease in our income of at least $225,000 in 1933 as compared with 1932, we could not continue to spend almost $6,000 on our Indian work at Morley; that I could see nothing for it except to hand the school back to them and let them make the best of it, unless they were prepared to assume a more adequate share of what it was actually costing. The best I could get, however, was a promise that in the Estimates which are presumably now before Parliament they would put in from April 1st an application for per capita grants for 75 pupils at Morley."
"The officials who are handling the Department of Indian Affairs at the present time are worthy of our very best support and entitled to sympathetic consideration. With a budget suddenly reduced from five and a half millions to three and a quarter millions and increasing amounts being demanded by practically every Indian Agent across the whole country for relief purposes, the Schools and Medical Services Departments are having a terrible time to keep within their appropriations. I think one might very reasonably protest, as I have already done, against these two Departments bearing the brunt of the cuts and carrying the main burden of relief. With the Dominion Government spending $7,500,000 on relief across the country last year, surely the Indians should have been included, but they were not. All Indian relief came out of the vote to the Department of Indian Affairs."

You will notice that I only promised Mr. Staley that increased per capita grants would be included in the Estimates. I was, however, entirely unprepared for the news that you gave me the other day, that the total amount of the increase asked for had been struck out.

Since my return from Ottawa I have been going over the financial situation of the Morley School and can see no way in which the Board of Home Missions can increase the amount of money which it is now expending to keep this School a going concern. I would suggest that you write Dr. McGill, requesting that he make a personal investigation of this particular situation while he is in the West. He is thoroughly at home in Calgary, and, in the city itself, can obtain information from Dr. Thomas Powell, our Superintendent of Missions, whose address is - 210-2nd Ave., N.W., or from Mr. W. G. Hunt, Secretary of the Alberta Medical Association, who is a member of our Board and a personal friend of Dr. McGill's.

As you are well aware, we have had in the last four years a good many conferences with Dr. Scott and Mr. Russell Ferrier about this Morley situation, and in the final letter which Dr. Scott wrote to Mr. Staley he said that Morley was one problem which he was handing over unsolved to his successor. I am sure you realize that we are prepared to bear our full share of responsibility for the education of the Indian children in this band, which has been so difficult of approach from every standpoint. We recognize that in the last year we have made some progress both from the point of view of the Department and of the Church. We are grateful for the sympathetic and intelligent interest that Mr. Christianson, your Inspector, is taking in the problem and are hopeful that the appointment of the new Agent at Morley may be helpful.

In spite of all these facts, however, unless the Department can do something more financially than is suggested for
their current financial year in connection with Morley, I am very apprehensive about the School.

Thanking you for your interest in and attention to this important matter,

I am

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the third instant, addressed to Mr. Sutherland, of this Department, relative to per capita grant for an increased pupilage, from 65 to 75, at the Morley Indian Residential School and quoting from a letter which you sent to the Principal, regarding the matter.

In reply I have to say that, when our Estimates for the current fiscal year were being prepared, an item to provide a grant for ten more pupils was included but, owing to the need for drastic economy, was not allowed. As you are aware, the Principal admitted, without reference to the Department, ten pupils over the number for which grant is allowed. No doubt, the admission of any children over the grant-earning pupils adds to the cost. It might help to lower the cost of this school if the Principal would reduce the enrollment to the number for which grant is provided, keeping not more than three children in excess of the 65 allowed, in order that they could replace any absentees and the average be maintained, so that the full grant would be earned each quarter.

It will not be possible to provide for any number in excess of 65 during the present fiscal year. It is hoped that it will be possible to carry on with the grant provided. If not, I am not aware of any other solution than the temporary closing of the school. Dear Doctor,

I was very sorry to learn that you were in Calgary while I was away on the postgraduate tour and therefore missed seeing you. I learn however that you were so busy when you were that most of your friends are mourners like myself. Hope for better things next time.

Re Morley Indian School

As you are aware they have been carrying on there with ten more pupils than the number for which the grant was made, and were under the impression that an additional grant to cover the extra ten had or would be made, but are now informed that nothing is forthcoming.

Few Indian reserves have suffered more than the Stoney Reserve for practically a whole generation, were raised and passed beyond the School age without any provision for Education, and it was only recently that conditions have altered. It was impossible for the principal of the school to refuse admission to the additional children who presented themselves and were of school age, so Mr. Stayley finds himself with 75 and provision for 65 (I think these are the figures).

I have been making some investigation and am informed that there is no band more intelligent than the Stonys, and none inside the settled areas of the Western Provinces where their reserve is endowed with less natural resources or possibilities, which would seem to be an added reason why further consideration in the matter of Education should readily be given.

Will you give this your attention on your return to Ottawa, but perhaps Mr. Christianson will answer any questions you may ask concerning them.

I am handing this letter to him to deliver to you as we understand he is to meet you early in August.

Reverend Sir:

With reference to the employment of Mrs. Gordon E. Locke (nee Miss Dorothy Grayson) as teacher of the Morley Indian Day School, the Treasury Board has drawn attention to Section 36 (1) of the Civil Service Regulations, which provides as follows:

1. "Hereafter no married woman, whose husband is living, shall be eligible for appointment in the Public Service."

This applies in the case where salary is being paid from Government Appropriation.

2. "Provided that, when the supply of experienced help for any particular kind of work is not sufficient to meet the demands of the Public Service, a married woman may be certified for temporary employment."

3. "Where it can be established by a married woman that her husband is unable, through illness or other cause, to contribute to her support, such married woman may be certified for permanent or temporary appointment."

In the Public Service, when a woman marries, she is required, under the regulations, to resign her position. The Department was advised of the marriage of Miss Grayson early in September, last, but did not desire to take any exception to her continuing duties as teacher and has been forwarding her salary cheques in her maiden name. However, as the Treasury Board has drawn our attention to the above regulations, it will be necessary for you to arrange for the engagement of another teacher for the coming school year. The Department does not desire to make any break in teaching arrangements during the balance of the current academic year. It will be necessary to continue to issue cheques in payment of salary in the name of Miss Dorothy Grayson.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:-

I beg to report that acting on the instructions of the Medical Health Officer here that the date of our school opening has been postponed to October 1st.

The staff had all reported for duty for the beginning of September; the necessary supplies had been put in and everything was in readiness for the school opening when it was thought advisable by the Medical Health Officer to postpone the date of opening for two weeks. An epidemic has been raging on the reserve all summer, which has been diagnosed as Black Measles. The disease is of a serious nature and has been very rampant among the children. The epidemic seemed to be dying down when another outbreak occurred, and it has been thought wise to move the opening date until October 1st, when it is hoped the epidemic will be over.

The hospital has been filled to its utmost capacity with patients, and the school has been used as a supplementary hospital. We have had as many as nine patients here, with three members of the staff delegated to do the night and day nursing. At present there are five patients.

This delay in opening has put us to a great deal of expense, as the fall work which is usually done by the boys in the school has had to be done by hired labour.

We shall keep you advised as to further developments and the outcome of the epidemic.

Yours very truly,

Dear Dr. McGill:

At our recent Board meeting we had before us a resolution of the Calgary Presbytery, in which the Morley Indian Residential School is situated, asking us to approach your Department, with a view to having the full cost of Indian Education borne by the Government. I pointed out that the policy of the Department was to make a per capita grant, in addition to providing buildings, etc., and that the Churches co-operating assumed responsibility for carrying on the work on that basis. It was pointed out, however, that there was a difference in the per capita grant received by the Church for the Morley School as compared with that for the Edmonton School; and it was further stated that this seemed an unfair discrimination, in view of the fact that the School at Edmonton was provided with one of the best farms in the Province, from which a very considerable revenue was derived.

I am writing to ask that your Department take into consideration when estimates are being prepared for next year the raising of the grant to the Morley School to the same level as Edmonton, namely, $170. There would seem to be no reason, based on the cost of operation, cost of living, or any other logical ground, why the grant to Morley should be on a lower basis than that of Edmonton.

I hope this request will receive favorable consideration. I shall be glad to discuss it with you on the occasion of my next visit.

THEY MADE THEIR OWN ARMY

Indian Girls Have Well Trained Militia

By M. H. LEPPARD

Correspondent of the Herald

HALLS, dormitories, classrooms, kitchens—all are still. What had resounded a moment before to the sound of girls' voices at breakfast is now silent. The time is 8:30 am; the place, the Indian residential school at Morley. Suddenly the peace is disturbed by the shrill voice of a bugler which booms out "Fall in!"

Then bursts forth from the radio throughout the vast main. Communion track out, and the local militia is off on its first parade of the day.

Feats up, chins in, shoulders squared, round and rounded in and out they sway. No group of girls ever gave such perfect concentra- tion into the job at hand than do these 45 girls, ranging in age from 12 to 16 years. They stand at attention, command, and the not always silent seven of hot soldiers is more effective than the icy glare of the "mam."

In the early days of the organiza- tion it was suddenly noticed one day that the privates were doing something that was not right for her. It is not known whose idea that was; however, the major decided that the girls must be put out of dignity. It is the en- deavor to feed all the children without favor but if one should imperatively wish you can be very sure that the roll at an "of- ficers" place is untouched.

The metamorphosis of these girls is apparent in a different attitude toward other activities of the school. There are no questions or trouble regarding discipline. They are reading with heads up, in clear sight of the teacher. They are eager to learn when in the classroom, and a more cheerful spirit prevails.

From the health angle the good thing about the girls is that they are healthy. They are filled with zest for living. Vigorous exercise brings vigorous appetites. An erect carriage is the result of the constant "This scarcely touched the school."

A Red Cross group was formed and once each week the older girls, with some of the Eltony and white girls, go out to the hospital to wash and knit and do Red-Cross work. The girls put on a concert yester- day afternoon for this purpose. It is affiliated with the South branch.

The feeling of patriotism is in- creasing among the girls. Canadian flags and the maple leaf are seen everywhere. In their more militant moods any one of them will receive the praise of the girls.

To those unfamiliar with life at an Indian school, it may be said that while activities among the boys never presented any problem, thanks to football and hockey, getting the girls out of their shells was a real one.

Year after year they came and went—round shoulders, heads bowed. As they grew older, the sound was more pronounced; the sound of their own voice apparently covered them. But not this year. Soccer, basketball, every game was tried, but at the best the response was half-hearted, even with the urging.

Then with the war there came an idea into the mind of a 14-year-old girl, Anna Beaver. With a group of girls she formed a little group who tried to act like soldiers. They couldn't march without a soldier's hat, and when they bought in the attic, these were brought into use. A good job of selling was done, for other girls were gradually brought until all are now eager members.

The girls have selected their own officers, and the organization is complete from the "major" to the lowest private. It has developed without interference from the staff. Very occasionally, when punishment is in order, depriving a girl of entering certain activities of the school for a day will do more good than a strap.

This little army is quite democratic. Privilege is given the opportunity of drilling the group. Each is a "nom de guerre." Names are taken from Royal Canadian Mounted Police who have stationed in Morley and vicinity; also soldiers whose names appear in the papers. They call each other by these names, too.

In the early days of the organization it was suddenly noticed one day that the privates were doing the major's work. It was a trick for her. It is not known whose idea that was; however, the "major" realized her work was being without loss of dignity. It is the endeavor to feed all the children without favor, but if one should become ill he or she can be very sure that the roll at an "officer's" place is untouched.

The metamorphosis of these girls is apparent in a different attitude toward other activities of the school. There is present no longer receding discipline. They are reading with heads up, in clear tones. There is a marked incentive to work in the classroom, and a more cheerful spirit prevails.

From the health angle the good these girls are deriving is incalculable. This fills the most important exercise begets vigorous appetite. An erect carriage improves health. The red cross scarcely touched the school.

A Red Cross group was formed and once each week the older girls with some of the black and white women of the community meet and knit and do Red Cross work. The girls have been asked yesterday to raise money for this. Morley is affiliated with the Seebe branch.

The feeling of patriotism is intense among these pure Canadians, and the desire to do more for the Empire ever with them. In case more Indian moods escaped internee would receive far from gentle handling.

Anna Beaver has trained her army to a nice peak of perfection. They march and drill with much skill and real military units adopting their arms in unison. They have been taught to salute correctly. They have a company bugler. The unit is graded for size, going down from the tall girls in the front ranks, to the small ones at the rear. On week-ends they go on long route marches.

It is not known whose idea that was; however, the "major" now does her own work, and within the ranks there is a sincere endeavor to feed all the children without favor, but if one should inadvertently be short you can be very sure that his roll at an "office" place is untouched.

The metamorphosis of these girls is apparent in their different attitude toward other activities of the school. There is practically no trouble regarding discipline. They are willing to work up in clear tones. There is a marked incentive to learn when in the classroom, and a more cheerful spirit prevails.

From the military side the good things the girls are deriving are noticeable. They are filled with zest for living. Vigorous exercise before breakfast and after dinner, exact carriage improves health. The recent flu scarcely touched the school.

A Red Cross group was formed and once each week the older girls, with some of the Story and white children of the Morley family, meet and lend a hand to Red Cross work. The girls put on a concert yesterday to raise money for this. Morley is affiliated with the Sackville branch.

The feeling of patriotism is intense among these pure Canadians, and the desire to do more for the country is evident in them. In their more militant moods any escaped internate would receive far from gentle handling.

Anna Beaver has trained her army to a nice peak of perfection. They march and drill with as much skill as a real military unit, swinging their arms in unison. They have been taught to salute correctly. They have a company bugler. The unit is graded for size, going down from the tall girls in the front ranks, to the small ones at the rear. On week-ends they go on long route marches.

Indian Girls Have Well Trained Militia

By M. H. LEPPARD
A Correspondent of the Herald

HALLS, dormitories, dining rooms and kitchens—all are silent. The only sound resonant a moment before the clamor of girls busy at different work is now quiet.

The time is 8:30 a.m.; the place, the Indian Affairs School at Morley.

Suddenly the peace is disturbed by a voice from the basement, shrilly bellowing out "Fall in!"

The bursts out into the radio rousing British band music. Commands crack out, and the local "militia" is off on its first parade of the day.

Heads up, chin in, shoulders squared, heads down and feet in step of the marching. No group of trainees puts more pure concentration into the job at hand than do these 45 girls ranging in age from ten to sixteen years. A misunderstood command, and the not always silent scorn of her fellow soldiers is more effective than the icy glare of the "major."

To those unfamiliar with life at an Indian school it may be said that while activities among the boys are never present, any attempt to rankle or to football and hockey, getting the girls out of their shells was a real one.

Yesterday year they came and went—shoulder-shouldered, heads bowed. As they grew older this was less pronounced, but the sound of their own voice apparently covered them with confusion. Softball, basketball, every game was tried, but still the response was half-hearted, even with the young.

Then with the war there came an idea into the mind of a 14-year-old girl, Anna Beaver. With a handful of girls she formed a little group who decided to get into a military outfit. They couldn't march without a soldier's hat, so some being found in the attic, they donned them and did a good job of selling what was done, for other girls were gradually brought in until all are now eager members.

The girls have selected their own officers and the organization is complete from the "major" to the newest private. It has developed without interference from the staff. Very occasionally, when punishment is in order, depriving them of entrance to certain activities of her company for a day does no more good than a strap.

This little army is quite democratic. Privileges are given the opportunity of drilling the group. Each as a "nom de guerre." Names are taken from Reserve Canadian Mounted Police who have been stationed in Morley and vicinity; also soldiers whose names appear in the papers. They address each other by their last names, too.

In the early days of the organization it was suddenly noticed one day that the privilege of doing the "major's" scrubbing trick for her. It is not known whose idea this was, however, but the result? Now does her own work, and without loss of dignity. It is the endearing thing to feel all the children without failure, but one should inadvertently be short, you can be very sure that the roll at an "officer's" place is untouchable.

The metamorphosis of these girls is apparent in a different attitude toward life and toward the school. There is practically no trouble regarding discipline. They are readily with the times in their actions. There is marked incentive to learn when in the classroom, and a more cheerful spirit prevails.

From the outside inside the good these girls are deriving is measurable. They are filled with zest for living. Vigorous exercise begins to take hold, and the effect improves health. The recent 'flu scarcely touched the school.

A Red Cross group was formed and once each week the older girls, with some of the Stony and White Mountain Indians, meet and knit and do Red Cross work. The girls put on a concert yesterday afternoon for this Morley branch affiliated with the Seneca branch.

The feeling of patriotism is intense among these poor Canadians, and the desire to do more for the Empire is ever with them. In their more militant moods any escaped internecine would receive far from gentle handling.

Anna Beaver has trained her army to a nice peak of perfection. They march and drill with as much skill as a real military unit, swinging their arms in unison. They have been taught to salute correctly. They have a company bugler. The unit is graded for size, going down from the tall girls in the front ranks, to the small ones at the rear. On week-ends they go on long route marches.

Indian Girls Form Own School Corps

CALGARY, March 30.—Although never noticeable among the boys, the matter of getting girls interested in the corps was always a major problem at the Indian residential school at Morley. However, all that is now changed.

After war was declared and soldiers were marching around an idea came into the mind of Miss Anna, the old Indian girl, Anna Beaver. Under her guidance a group of girls formed a corps and started drilling in the forms they had seen themselves. Now every girl attending the school is a member of the brigade.

The girls have their own officers and the brigade is complete from the "major" to the "privates."

A Red Cross group was formed and girls are learning the skills needed to knit and do Red Cross work. Recently they staged a concert to raise funds for the Red Cross.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

Thank you very much for your letter of April 7. I appreciate the interest revealed in it.

The article from which you quote could only, of course, tell in part of the start of this movement and of its value to the children and the school as a whole. It is no exaggeration what it has done for the girls of this institution. Our girls, up to two years ago, were much like all girls in these institutions. They did their work without any enthusiasm, they took part in other activities because they had to but there was always the deadening sense that little was being accomplished to develop initiative or anything else. You speak of the C.G.I.T. movement. It has its good points but, frankly, I have found that both it and the boys' movements do not fill the bill with Indian children. The world in which the Indian lives is much too circumscribed to allow full advantage to be taken of the so-called four-fold development. We have tried many things here and I am beginning to wonder if this is not a good example of what could easily result with our Indian population if we took a little more time to allow movements to develop amongst the children themselves.

Frankly, I have been delighted in the past few years at the degree of latitude that you are allowing us in the educational work. I have my doubts about the value of many of the things that we are still supposed to teach. I have my doubts about high school education for 99% of the Indian children. I can see the value of much more time being spent in manual training, in home crafts and handicrafts. To illustrate what I have in mind I think it might be a good thing to allow a boy after he reaches the age of 14, to go on a hunting trip in the fall or the winter with his parents and see for himself how he will have to earn a living a few years later in a place like this. I have a great many more ideas along these lines that I would like to pass on for your consideration if the ideas seem of value to you.

In your letter you wonder if an organization might appeal more if given an Indian name. I wonder whether back of that idea is not the record of our difficulties. Have we not in much too big a hurry tried to give to the Indian the whole of the civilization that has taken us thousands of years to build up?
All we have done in our haste has been a magnificent job of veneering. We have killed initiative amongst the Indians. An Indian with original ideas is not wanted, we call him a trouble maker. Names do not matter a great deal. The big thing, I feel sure, is to allow a little more freedom to the children to do as they please.

You may be interested to know that this group of girls are going to parade next week before the Governor General when he visits Calgary. You will be delighted to know, I am sure that these girls are just as enthusiastic about the Red Cross work as about the militia group and a week from Friday they are presenting a concert, largely of military drills, the whole proceeds from which will go to the War Services Fund.

You will notice that I have made no mention of boys in this letter. We have found here that our problem with the boys has been solved by organized games and team work. I should be very happy to discuss the matter with Mr Doucet when he visits our school.

Thank you for the courtesies given at all times to our many requests for our school here.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Indian Girl's Show Aids Spitfire Fund

(Special to the Journal)

BANFF, MAY 22.—"Empire Pageant" originated and written by a 14-year-old Stoney Indian girl, Annie Beaver, has been seen by more than 40 Indian school girls who have staged in the Banff auditorium May 24.

This will give students and visitors alike something of which to be proud. It will give them a great deal of amusement as it did Rev. E.J. Stanley, Morley minister, and Mrs. Leonard, headmistress of the Morley Indian School, when they first discovered Annie training her cast.

Annie, on one or two occasions, has been able to see something about which they have heard in recent weeks. It is probably also the greatest show of its kind ever given.

The "Empire Pageant," all planned and directed by herself, includes gun drills, airplane drill and band drill. The final offering of the program is a Red Cross scene where a wounded soldier is given treatment but fails to recover. Those who have witnessed it claim this number is the most realistic and effective of any of the fighting services represented on the stage.

All branches of the fighting services are represented on the stage, lacking other means of providing accommodations for the drills, Annie has created her cast with the aid of an old gramophone. The gramophone will be used on Saturday night. Proceeds of the presentation will go to the Banff-Jasper Spitfire Fund.

Chief Proud Of Daughter

(By Herald Correspondent)

ROCKY MOUNTAIN HOUSE,
July 22—Chief Walking Eagle is very proud of his daughter, Annie Beaver, who is a student at the Morley residential school. Annie has been in the public eye this winter and spring, since she trained her schoolmates for a patriotic pageant that the girls presented at Morley and later at Banff.

The chief carries the pictures and The Herald story about with him, and shows them to all his friends. He sent his son at school in Morley since she was six, but he says she will soon be through and then she will return to the Kootenay Plains, where her branch of the Stones has lived "since the world began."

These Stones are treaty Indians, and belong to the Morley reserve. But Stones never lived there; they prefer their homes on the plains, but most of them send their children there to school, and all go down to visit when they take the notion.

Walking Eagle has two boys in Morley and another son, Blue Duck, lives with him. We asked why Blue Duck isn't in school, but it seems he wants to be a cowboy and doesn't think he needs to go to school to learn that trade.
MORLEY, ALTA.

Dear Mr. Iredale,

I wonder whether you would be good enough to ascertain the wishes of your Department in regard to a situation that here, as well as elsewhere will be extremely acute this fall.

I refer to the problem of labor. It is already apparent that this part of the country will have a bumper crop to harvest and it is already apparent that the labor is not here to handle same. In view of this I think it would be well to ask if there is any plan in prospect, for doing from our schools what is already planned for the white schools. Many, if not most, both in city and in country will not re-open until the harvest is in and I venture to think and to suggest that some such procedure would be the logical one for our Indians to follow in this year of need.

The Indians here, as you know, go out and contact work by the acre and every member of the family takes part in the labor and so from our school alone more than half the children could be of use in the harvest fields.

Perhaps if the plan proposed by the Provincial Department of Education were followed and if the time lost by our children were paid for by the usual per capita grant, it would mean that any grants by the Dept. for cost of living bonus could be eliminated this year.

I make these suggestions now, in order that we may know early enough what plans to make regarding our fall work.

Yours truly,

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 31st ultimo, enclosing letter from the Principal of the Morley Residential School suggesting that the re-opening of the school be delayed until the first or fifteenth of October.

While the Department is anxious to assist in relieving the labour shortage, at the same time present Treasury regulations will not permit our paying per capita allowance at a residential school when pupils are absent, except for the annual two months' holiday leave for which grant is allowed.

Besides, I am inclined to feel that only the older pupils would be of much assistance in harvesting operations. What advantage would there be in keeping the younger children out of school, as they would be unable to do any effective work?

We could not adopt the Principal's suggestion at the Morley School without putting the same into effect at other Indian residential schools. This would involve consulting the various churches before taking the action suggested.

Yours truly,

RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL AT MORLEY

While at Morley I visited the residential school and was favourably impressed with the institution and the type of instruction given. The Rev. Mr. Staley is keenly interested in preparing the Indian for the time when he leaves school and has to look after himself. It was this gentleman who asked our nurses' co-operation in First Aid lectures and instructed in child care in the home. He will no doubt do everything possible to encourage this type of instruction. He commenced a manual training class for the older boys; at the time of my visit, each boy had completed a kitchen table which he was to take with him on his return home. These tables were well made and would compare favourably with anything turned out by a factory, of the same type. It is a pleasure to see the more practical side of education stressed in the school.

Re: Morley Residential School

We have received from Mr. Staley a telegram as follows:

"Find it utterly impossible to secure staff. Stop.

Dear Doctor Dorey:

Re: Morley Residential School

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 14th instant, in which you refer to the difficulty experienced by Mr. Staley in securing the staff necessary for the operation of the Morley School. I regret that I am not in a position to state just what the answer is to the questions raised by you in your communication. While the war news appears to be encouraging at the moment, I am personally disposed to think that the labour shortage is likely to become more acute during the months immediately ahead of us. In view of the fact, however, that our residential schools are Government institutions it does seem to me that we ought to be able to reach an agreement with the officials of the National Selective Service Organization whereby we would be able to secure the teachers necessary to carry on. The suggestion that these schools should be closed is one that, in my judgment, should not be entertained. Should these schools cease to operate, we would be confronted with juvenile delinquency on our reserves and a number of other problems that would prove more costly than the operation of our residential schools.

It was, of course, gratifying to receive your telegram of yesterday and to learn that the Principal had secured the staff necessary to carry on. This is a matter, however, which I feel should be discussed more fully with the officials responsible for administering the existing regulations. I shall be glad to discuss this matter with you more fully when I visit Toronto on the 28th. It is my hope that I may be able to call at your office around 12 o'clock noon on that date.

BAND CONCERT BY STONIES

The residents of Banff have a treat in store for them on Friday, June 28th, when the Stony Indian Band will give a concert in the School Auditorium. The event is under the auspices of the Banff Kinsmen Club, and the proceeds will go to the British Milk Fund. The Stony Band is credited with giving an excellent performance and deserves the whole-hearted support of Banff citizens.
Stony Indian Girls' Band Delights Large Banff Audience

Those who were fortunate enough to attend the Stony Indian Band Concert, held last Friday in the School Auditorium, enjoyed one of the musical treats of the year, and came away from the performance with high praise for the talent displayed.

The concert was given under the auspices of the Kinsmen Club of Banff in aid of the British Milk Fund and netted the Fund $45.

This Girls' Band, all Stony Indians, put on an excellent performance, the highlights being the rendering of Hiawatha (all being in native costume) and the Precision Drills.

The following pertinent facts regarding the Band enhance the credit due them for their fine performance.

The Band members are all girls and members of the Stony Indian Tribe at Morley.

There are 18 girls in the Band, ranging in age from 12 to 17 years.

Each member of the Band bought her own instrument.

The Band, as a unit, has received up to date only eleven lessons.

Great credit for the training of the girls goes to Mrs. Leppard, teacher at the Indian School, Morley, who coached them in several of their numbers, and to Thomas Haywood, Bandmaster of Calgary, who brought them forward in eleven lessons in instrumental work.

The Band narrowly missed keeping their appointment in Banff, as the truck in which they were travelling broke down near Morley. Harold Perlin, of Banff, came to the rescue, picked the girls up at Morley, brought them to Banff, and after the performance took them home to Morley. Those who enjoyed the concert so much extend their thanks to Mr. Perlin.

Dear Sir:

In the matter of charges against Anna Beaver of the Morley Indian School, investigated by your inspector, Mr. G.P. Schmidt, and myself, January 8, I may state:

- Anna Beaver, 21 years of age; 4 years as helper in the kitchen and laundry and as supervisor of play activities.
- Tina Wellman, 21 years of age; 2 years working in the hospital; the past 2 years in the main building engaged mainly in sewing but also assisting in supervision of recreation.
- Horace Hallway, 17 years of age; farm helper for the past year.

Anna Beaver has talent in music and some qualities of leadership, and she has been quite active as matron's assistant in supervising the play and recreational activities of the girls of the school. I have observed these exercises on a number of occasions and, although I am in no position to remark upon the reaction of parents, I am convinced that the children look to Anna Beaver as a leader and are happy in their associations with her.

5. I should especially urge that, since Anna Beaver shows a disinclination to return to the life of the Indian Reserve and in view of her evident capacity for normal Canadian citizenship, a concerted effort be made to find employment for her, preferably in Indian School work.

Re: Complaints made against Anna Beaver of the Morley Indian Residential School.

Further to my letter of the 30th ultimo, and your No. 119-1-1 of the 20th idem, I beg to report that Mr. G.L. Wilson of Calgary, Provincial Inspector of Public Schools, and myself visited the above-mentioned School yesterday, and took the matter up with Rev. Mr. E.J. Staley, the Principal; we also interviewed Mrs. Leppard, the Matron of the School.

Rev. Mr. Staley knew that the Indians had written complaints against Anna Beaver. He said that copies of these had been sent to the Church authorities.

According to Rev. Mr. Staley, Anna Beaver is an ex-pupil of the Morley Indian Residential School. She is now twenty-one (21) years of age. Her parents are not living together; her father is in the Nordegg district; her mother is on the home (Morley) reserve, and lives with another man.

Rev. Mr. Staley says, that when Anna was discharged from School on account of her age, she said that she had no place to go to live; she was therefore kept at the School, where she helped with the work, and was later given the position of Laundress. She is assisted at this work by the girl pupils.

When she is not working, Anna spends most of her time amongst the other girl pupils. Being older than they, she has, it would appear, assumed an authoritative attitude over the pupils, and this has, to a certain degree (more or less) been approved—not to say encouraged by the Matron, with the knowledge of the Principal, it being thought by them that it was beneficial as regards discipline amongst the girl pupils.

I think that probably too much attention and praise, and perhaps some favouritism has been shown to Anna by the Matron and others. This may have been resented by pupils who were in School with Anne, and they mentioned it to their parents, with the result that they are now demanding the removal of Anna Beaver from the School.

Rev. Mr. Staley is aware of this, and has decided to let Anne go as soon as he can find another Laundress to take her place; this will likely be before the end of the present month.

Rev. Mr. Staley is somewhat worried as to what the girl will do when she leaves the School: Where will she go? With whom will she live? I appreciate his feelings, after having had the girl under his care and guidance for many years—since childhood. He asked whether there is not some other School where she could be employed; I suggested that he take this up with the Missionary Society of the Church.

Reference departmental letter No. 119-1-1 of the 28th February, re Anna Beaver, employed as Laundress at the Morley Indian Residential School; I beg to report that I interviewed Rev. Mr. E.J. Staley at this office on January 23rd, and again late during the month of February, when he informed me that he was doing everything possible to find and engage another woman to take charge of the Laundry work at the School, but could not find anyone. I drove out to the School today, and called on Rev. Mr. Staley, who said that he was making every effort to get a Laundress, but could not find one.

Mr. Staley stated that he had applied to the Selective Service; in February he advertised in both Calgary Papers — the Herald and the Albertan; and in the Winnipeg Free Press. He also wrote to Dr. Darcey of the Head Office, Toronto; to Dr. R.B. Cochrane, Head of Home Missions Board, and to Dr. T. Powell, head of Home Missions Board for Alberta. Dear Doctor Dorey:

Your letter of May 8th, addressed to the Minister of this Department, has, in the absence of the Minister from the city, been passed on to me for consideration and reply.

A great deal of earnest thought has been given to our immediate post-war program, particularly to the educational needs of the Indian population. You are aware, of course, that a large number of schools have been destroyed by fire during the last five-year period. I have in mind the classroom building at Alberti, the large Indian Day School at Gushnawga and a number of others that might be mentioned. It is our intention to proceed with the construction of new buildings to take the place of the buildings destroyed by fire at the earliest possible date. It would appear also that a number of reserves Indian Day Schools are urgently needed. We have not included an addition to the Morley Residential School in our program, but there is no reason why it should not be included in the list for consideration at a later date.

Conditions in the province of Alberta are somewhat unusual. We have, as you know, two Residential Schools in that province operated under the auspices of the United Church - Edmonton, with an enrolment of 150, and Morley, with an enrolment of 100. We have never, however, succeeded in securing a full enrolment at Edmonton in recent years. The enrolment for example at this date is 107 and yet Edmonton is one of our best equipped institutions. Would it be possible to have a member representing your Board look into the educational needs of the Indians of Alberta, with the object of making certain adjustments...
certain adjustments between these two institutions? It will be readily appreciated that we may experience difficulty in securing funds for an addition at Nurley while the Edmonton enrolment stands at its present figure. Re: Morley Residential School
School Accommodation

I wish again to draw your attention to the lack of accommodation at the Morley Indian Residential School. In view of the situation which is bound to arise in connection with regulations in regard to the Family Allowance payments I would ask that further accommodation be provided as early as possible.

As the matter now stands we cannot accommodate more than 100 pupils and on the Reserve we have approximately 180 children of the prescribed school age.

At the present time the parents of the school children are receiving the family allowances for the children during the summer holidays. When school re-opens in September the payments will cease for those children who re-enter or commence school and the children who do not enter school, on account of lack of accommodation, or to be precise, their parents, will most likely continue to receive the allowance cheques.

The problem thus created will be a difficult one because the parents with children in school will not be paid and those with children not attending school will be paid.

Therefore we may experience trouble in getting the Indians to send their children to school. Of course I know that if they refuse to send their children to school they will forfeit the family allowance for such and each child, but, if we had sufficient accommodation to take care of all the children we could, and would, enforce the act (as it applies to school attendance) to the fullest extent.

I would ask that some concrete plan be formulated, before the re-opening of school, to meet this situation. Could we lower the age for discharge, (temporarily) in order that we could get all the younger children enrolled, until such times as further accommodation is provided?

I would appreciate hearing from you with regard to this matter.

J.N.R. Laidale,
Acting Indian Agent.

In view of this fact, it is not my intention to deal at length with the issues submitted by you.

I should like, however, to refer to the provision made in existing legislation for the payment of Family Allowances to Indians. The registration of Indians for this purpose has been almost completed. Payments will be made to the members of Indian bands on the same basis as payments are made to members of white families. In this connection, you were apparently misinformed when you state that no Indian mother can get the allowance for children above seven years. As a matter of fact, provisions of the Act are being very liberally interpreted and no Indian entitled to such payments will experience the slightest difficulty in securing these allowances, either in cash or in kind. Where Indian Day Schools have not been established or where accommodation at Residential Schools is inadequate, the provision in the Act for non-attendance of children at school will not apply to Indian families. In other words, the officials of the department are anxious that everything humanly possible should be done to enable Indians to benefit from the Family Allowance Act to the fullest extent possible.

I note also your reference to the Residential School at the Stony Agency and to the fact that no provision has been made for sixty-eight children of school age. This school, as you state, is operated under the auspices of the United Church of Canada. You are, no doubt, aware that we have at Edmonton a Residential School operated also by the
United Church. This school is one of the most up-to-date and one of the best schools of its kind in Canada. The officials inform me that despite the fact that recruiting has been undertaken by the Principal of this school as far west as the Pacific Coast, he has never at any time succeeded in securing the quota of pupils for which we allow per capita grants. You will readily appreciate how difficult, in view of this condition, it would be for the Minister to persuade Parliament that an additional capital outlay for the extension of the Morley School could be justified. However, this is a matter that will be thoroughly investigated by the official to whom I have already referred.

I find it somewhat difficult to understand your reference to the aged and physically incapacitated Indians of this reserve. Our field officials have been instructed from time to time that it is their duty and responsibility to supply these Indians with the full clothing and housing accommodation necessary to maintain them in a state of comfort. The Stony Indians have on deposit with the Government at this date Trust Funds amounting to $75,065.78. Section 95 of the Indian Act, paragraph (d), reads:

"The Superintendent General (Minister) may whenever sick or disabled, or aged or destitute Indians are not provided for by the band of which they are members, furnish sufficient aid from the funds of the band for the relief of such sick, disabled, aged or destitute Indians."

The records here indicate that relief supplies have been provided on the recommendation of the Inspector and the Indian Agent from time to time from both Parliamentary Appropriations and Trust Funds and no complaints with respect to the inadequacy of these supplies have reached the department since the Inspector made his last investigation, now almost a year ago. The Indian Agent in his quarterly report for the period ending June 30, 1945, in referring to general conditions at the agency, states:

"There has been no lack of employment for Indians at this agency or for those able and willing to work. Quite a number were employed by the Roxana Oil Company building roads and the Mannix Contracting Company wanted about fifty Indians to work on a dam construction project, but were only able to get twelve men."

It has occurred to me that it would be helpful to the department if you would discuss conditions at this agency with our representative immediately following his arrival in Calgary. It is unnecessary to add that I appreciate very fully your interest in the members of this band and your willingness to cooperate with the department in finding a solution for what appears to be a very involved and perplexing problem.

Yours sincerely,

Report from Dr. T.F. Murray,
Medical Superintendent,
Morley Indian Hospital.

I have made a complete examination of this girl and have the following to report:

She walks, when under observation, with a limp and favors the right hip. Upon leaving the hospital she ran down the front steps and up the road at full speed without any limp or favoring. She evidently did not know that she was observed.

There is no palpable lesion in the area of her pain and nothing that may be observed.

Adduction, rotation, abduction are all normal, but she complains of slight pain. These movements were both active and passive. There are no marks in the area complained of and no contusions or lacerations. The abdomen in the area is normal.

The area complained about is the anterior superior spine of the ileum on the right side.

The girl is well developed and well nourished. She has a slight valvular condition of the aortic region. It suggests acute rheumatic fever of some years ago.

It is necessary to have an x-ray of the right hip joint in order to rule out injury to the hip joint and the various pelvic bones and bursal. Measurements are all normal in spite of apparent shortening.

Re: Complaint of Stone Indians Concerning the Indian Residential School on that Reserve.

On the 23rd instant I was interviewed by Mr. Iredale, Acting Agent, and Rev. G. R. Inglis, Principal of the school, in regard to a complaint of one Moses Wesley.

Attached hereto please find copy of report on a meeting held at the Agency Office on the 25th, concerning which these two gentlemen came to see me.

From the interview it was apparent that this complaint might be one of many that would arise from the manner in which the Principal was operating this school. The Agent was asked to call a meeting of the Councillors and interested parents at Morley on the 26th, in order that I could meet with them and get a clearer picture of the existing situation.

Apparently rumours and complaints had reached the ears of Rev. E. J. Staley, now Principal of the Indian Residential School at Edmonton and formerly Principal of this school. He came from Edmonton and accompanied me to Morley on the 26th. Dr. E. L. Stone, who was on routine inspection in the south, was informed of this complaint and he also went to Morley on the 27th and remained there for two days. A very good representative meeting of Councillors and parents met with us at the Church Hall, and the entire afternoon was given over to the consideration of their complaints, to wit:

1. The Indians had complained of the punishment meted out by the Principal and the Matron in charge.
2. The food.
3. Clothing supplied to children.
4. Part-time school work.
5. Health and cleanliness of the pupils.

The verbatim report is not yet available, but dealing with the foregoing as remembered -

1. There were a number of charges that capital punishment was meted out by the Matron, and that, in some instances, she had not only strapped on the hands, but beat pupils on the head. The Principal had also employed capital
punishment for various misdemeanours even in the presence of parents. We were satisfied that the complaints were mostly true, though possibly exaggerated. The parents stated that they realized that their children should receive a certain amount of capital punishment, but that they felt that the Principal and the Matron lacked kindness and understanding; they had found it very difficult to approach the staff members as friends.

2. In regard to food. It was not clearly indicated that the food was poor and insufficient, but it was not what the parents expected nor what the pupils had formerly received when Mr. Staley was Principal.

3. It was established that children were often not properly clothed to go out into the cold, and that from some source they should be given better and warmer clothing.

4. In regard to part-time school work. The usual complaints were made that children were not getting enough class room work, and too much time was employed in duties in and about the school and the farm.

5. It was stated that a number of children had lice in their hair, which did not indicate that very great interest was employed in assuring that the children were always clean.

The writer asked for comments regarding these complaints from Mr. Staley, and he spoke to the Indians stating that it certainly would be the desire of his Church to correct anything that was wrong as quickly as possible, and to remove any canker in the organization that would lead to a happier understanding between the staff and parents. Dr. Stone kindly spoke in regard to food and health. He stated that very shortly a Departmental dietitian would report on the food, and he would give it his very particular attention.

After hearing all complaints, I informed the Indians that I would report -

That capital punishment was uncalled for if the organization was running smoothly; that capital punishment was always frowned upon by the Department, and that I was immediately going to ask the Principal to discontinue this form of punishment until he had discussed the reason for it with the parent, and only when there was no better way would capital punishment be meted out.

As for the other complaints, the Principal would be asked to immediately check on the food and clothing and the cleanliness of the children.

I did not state that the removal of the Matron would be requested, but so many had mentioned that she was so unsympathetic and so prone to punishment on the least provocation, that her removal from this school at an early
date would be the only way to satisfy the Indians and regain their confidence in the school. This lady, Miss Hodgson, was for many years a teacher, and though she undoubtedly is very efficient, it is felt that she has not got a sympathetic approach to her present work. It is our belief that the United Church would be well advised to transfer her to some other work and replace her with somebody with better understanding.

The Principal, Mr. Inglis, appears to be a very fine gentleman, but with no experience in this particular work. Possibly he is too strict a disciplinarian, and he does not mingle freely enough with the Indians. It must be remembered, of course, that he followed Mr. Staley, who lived with them for 25 years, and the Indians must learn to know him just as much as it is necessary for him to learn to know them. Immediately after the meeting I spoke to him and acquainted him of the foregoing.

The meeting closed with the understanding that every attempt would be made to correct what would appear to be wrong. The Indians were asked to be charitable towards the Principal and to the staff, and they were also asked to give Mr. Inglis the opportunity to make certain reforms in his attitude and that of his staff, which we believe to be necessary for the smooth running of this school. Then, if he should fail, we could do no more than report that he was not the proper person to be the head of this school.

Acting Agent Mr. Iredale remained at the meeting part of the time; Mr. Horton, who will be Clerk-in-Charge when Mr. Iredale goes on sick leave, remained throughout and took extensive notes. The meeting was carried on in a very pleasant and orderly manner. The Indians were quiet and deliberate, which fact indicated that they were very serious and disturbed, but not yet to a point of rebellion.

It is our recommendation that the United Church officials be advised of the unsettled condition and that as quickly as possible try to correct it.

G. H. Gooderham,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

Miss Alice McCready, Dietitian of the Department of National Health and Welfare, has spent four days looking into the diet of the Stony Indian Residential School at Morley. Her verbal report was:

(1) That the feeding was about average for the better fed schools.

(2) That the diet is low in citrus fruits, as at all schools, but higher than at some, and perhaps than at the average.

(3) That the present school resources in milk could be better utilized than they are.

On my own account I ascertained that the average gain in weight of seventy-eight pupils between September 15th and February 15th - five months - was nine pounds.

I conferred with Miss McCready and the Rev. Principal at the beginning and end of her visit. The Principal was interested, open to advice and undertook to profit by Miss McCready's recommendations.

In view of the limited funds at the disposal of the Principal of this, as of other Residential schools, and considering that the Principal, the Matron and many of the staff are in their first year at this kind of work, I judge that feeding conditions are as good as can be reasonably expected, and are likely to improve.

The Matron told me that she had apparently solved the problem of keeping the pupils heads free of lice. I had sent her some DDT powder, but consider that the key to the problem is in treatment with oil every Monday, following Sunday contact with members of the family living at home.

E. L. Stone

Attendance Morley Residential School.

Reference your 119-6-7 of December 10th.

The situation at this residential school might be summed up as follows:

(a) Pupilage ...... 100
   Present Not Attending 88.

It is noted that Mr. Pugh feels that the pupilage allowed by the Department to this school is too great. It is also noted that this matter has not apparently been discussed with the Principal of the Morley Residential School. I feel certain that we would have some complaint from the United Church if we were to proceed without their approval.

However, for your information I may say that we are operating day schools in certain of our residential schools elsewhere. Where a school has a number in attendance in excess of its pupilage we investigate the possibility of having a certain number of children attend on a day school basis. The usual standard is that followed by most Provincial Departments of Education namely:

(a) That pupils under ten years of age can be expected to walk two miles to school.

(b) That pupils ten years of age and over can be expected to walk three miles to school.

Family Allowances are paid to the parents concerned provided that these children attend the required number of days.

An Order in Council is obtained authorizing the establishment of a day school. One of the teachers at the school is paid on a part time basis as the day school teacher, directly by the Department. Her salary is based on our day school teachers' salary schedule. For example, if there are twenty-five day school pupils in attendance, we would allow her a salary at the rate of two thirds of the amount which would be allowed her on the day school teachers' salary schedule. It is realized, of course, that these day school pupils might well be scattered throughout two or three classrooms and it would be impossible to pay small amounts to all teachers concerned. Therefore, the denomination is requested to name one teacher to teach and be paid as described above and it is left to the school principal to make the necessary adjustments.

It will be necessary to approach Dr. Dorey concerning this proposal. Our attitude might be summed up as follows: That if this school had pupils in excess of its pupilage, we would not hesitate to proceed with the establishment of a day school, but in view of the fact that it is not the case, we feel that the denomination concerned will have to be consulted before a decision can be reached. We would appreciate hearing from you if you have an opportunity of discussing this matter with the principal of the school. We will then approach Dr. Dorey on the matter.

Acknowledgement is made of copy of letter received from the Supt. of Welfare & Training in regard to the proposal outlined in our letter 119-6-7 of Dec.9/47. It is realised that the plan is experimental. The object is to put ourselves in a position to be able to offer the Indians further accommodation for schooling in the simplest and most economical way possible. As a step towards this end, it is felt if there are a number of children living within a 3 mile radius of the school, who could attend on a day basis, that for each of these children not in residence by reason of attending day school only, accommodation could be provided for an equal number of children up to 90 in residence.

To carry out this plan it is suggested that the school provide a mid-day meal, which could possibly be paid for by a monthly grant. In regard to the teachers, it is not recommended that a difference be made in the status i.e., one being paid as a day school teacher and one by the Church Authorities on their basis. Re: Attendance Morley Residential School

Reference your 119-1-1 (W.T.1) of December 23rd. I am attaching hereto copy of a letter from Mr. Pugh, together with copy of a letter to him from the Principal of the school. These letters indicate that the suggestion of day pupils is made purely as an experiment.

You state in your letter that the pupilage is one hundred. You know as well as I do that the churches always try to keep the pupilage to the very extreme of accommodation. In the case of Morley school, the present accommodation is limited ninety. Therefore, the present attendance is now only two short of capacity.

Mr. Inglis states that there are approximately 180 children of school age. This includes Stonies living to the far north near Nordegg and those living in the Pekisko area in the far south. I am sure it is not our intention or hope to continue indefinitely to bring all these children into one central residential school. The Indians in the north are waiting patiently for the establishment of a day school near Nordegg. As for those in the Pekisko area, it is almost impossible to get many to go to Morley, and if and when a reservation can be purchased in that area, a day school would naturally be set up for their children.

I cannot give definite figures, but I would say that there are fifty Stony children at these outside settlements that we cannot ever expect to get into the residential school at Morley. That leaves 125 or 130 to be educated at this point.

I think it is agreed that the residential school should not be enlarged to look after the increasing pupilage, but that some form of day school be set up to care for this surplus. There is therefore a need for a day school on the Stony Indian Reserve, as well as the present residential school. In setting up a day school, we may anticipate complications. These are obvious.

However, until something is done along this line, the experiment suggested by Mr. Pugh and Mr. Inglis would not only educate the children but the parents. It is anticipated there are parents, who today are so rabid in their demands for a day school, that they would be very happy after a couple of years to send their children back to a residential school if it were available, thus relieving themselves of a lot of family responsibility. I am not saying it is right to relieve them of this responsibility,
but it would create a different mental attitude which would make it easier to operate a residential school as well as a day school in the same vicinity.

To carry out this experiment, it is suggested:

1. that the total enrollment of the resident and day school be limited to one hundred, because there are only two class rooms.

2. that no day pupils be allowed unless there are ninety in residence.

3. that ten day pupils be allowed, and that the school be paid $10.00 per month per pupil, to whom it will supply not only the normal class room work, but a mid-day meal.

It is not known here what authority would be required to follow this procedure, but the method of payment mentioned in your letter is too involved and cumbersome. It would not work here.

All children of school age, within a radius of three miles, could readily get to the school, because most of them ride ponies and do not have to walk.

I want you to know that all the children returned the first day of school after the Christmas holidays, and that there is a different feeling towards the school today than there was a year ago. I feel that the Indians will fully co-operate on this experiment if it can be tried.

My final suggestions have not been discussed with Mr. Pugh nor the school principal, but a copy is going to them, and of course you will get Dr. Dorey's reaction.

G. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Colonel Neary:

Norley Indian Residential School; Visited on Nov. 15

This school continues to serve only a fraction of the eligible children in a fractional way. The children appear to come voluntarily, but too often they come too late in life and too tardily in the school term.

Unless facilities are provided to give complete educational coverage over one generation the effects of any lesser degree of coverage are correspondingly negatived as the small minority of schooled children are returned to the pool of the unschooled. Vital statistics also work against the attainment of the objective as each year the population increases faster than accommodation is being provided.

The teaching in this school is at a disadvantage. A lack of mechanization for household activities compels an allotment of pupils and time that retards progress through the grades as will be seen from the age-grade tables. This withdrawal of the pupils from congested classrooms appears momentarily to lighten the load on the senior teacher who conducts Grades three to eight.

I understand that the Alberta school inspector is to make some comments on the classroom situation. I had hoped that the Grade eight pupils (two) might have been sent to school in Calgary.

The junior teacher is to some extent trained but is getting her first experience here under tryout conditions and progress in the primary grades may be expected to be slow.

I deplore the tendency to permit Indians to consume time on alien forms of art to the exclusion of attention to other disciplines. There are already enough examples of white people who prefer or who are content while someone else supports them to fool away their time in art colonies in activities at which they cannot excel sufficiently to bring economic stability to themselves or aesthetic enjoyment to a significant number of people.

From the staff's point of view the school's needs appear to be "more kitchen space and more classrooms" but actually an all-round expansion is necessary (as previously reported) so that the school may properly integrate all its activities which are presently notably deficient in adequate vocational and physical education.

A canopy over the kitchen stove which I expected to see has not yet been installed.

C.A.F. Clark

9. Chief Enos Hunter placed before the Superintendent the matter of Miss Hodgson, matron at the Morley Indian Residential School, stating that, in her capacity as matron at the school, she was unsatisfactory to the Indians. This matter has been before the Council previously and has not been dealt with in view of the fact that individual personalities were more or less at the bottom of the agitation.

The writer informed the Council that from his observations at the school he felt that Miss Hodgson was rendering good service, and that in the matter of discipline towards their children, that providing this was carried out in a fair manner, it was essential to the welfare of the school, and the following was quoted to the Indians from No. 1 Vol.3, October issue of the Indian School Bulletin, under the heading "Little Angel?":

"I love my infant more than breath
Or bread or drink. I'd suffer death
Or pain or illness, short or long,
To keep him flourishing and strong.
But candor forces me to say
I eagerly await the day
When some poor kindergarten teacher
Will wrestle with the little creature."

An explanation of this quotation was made to the Council and they were informed that the writer did not feel disposed to making any specific charges out of their complaint. Chief Enos Hunter advised me that the Council decided to take it to higher authority.

(Sgd) John E. Pugh,
