NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper column.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days pupils in all schools attended during quarter, excluding holidays, including the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of the Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days attended of all pupils whose names appear on the Return and is obtained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper column.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the feet thereof.

3. When owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days of residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days pupils in residence during quarter, excluding Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, filling the column under the heading “Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter”.

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the “Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter” by the “Total number of days in quarter”.

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the “Average attendance of pupils during quarter” by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, can payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

MEMORANDUM RE MORLEY ORPHANAGE.

The late Rev Geo. McDougall had for years in contemplation the establishment of an Orphanage in the North-West, chiefly for the benefit of the numerous children who had been left friendless by the smallpox epidemic, and was about taking definite steps in the matter when his tragic death occurred. Two or three years later the enterprise was taken up by his son, the Rev John McDougall, with no other assistance than such as was voluntarily given by friends of the Indians in the Methodist Church; the Missionary Board feeling unable to make an annual grant in view of the other claims of the work. Land was occupied with the consent of the Government, and application was made for a grant of some two sections, so as to afford sufficient room for a cattle ranch. Mr. McDougall proceeded with the work, fencing in a large portion of the land, erecting a small building, supplied some live stock, and opened the home for the reception of orphan children. This was all done largely at his own expense, and from the time the enterprise began until the autumn of last year he expended some $2,500 more than he had received from all sources. Sometime after the Orphanage was opened the Government made an annual per capita grant of $60 for a certain number of pupils, and over a year ago erected a new building at a cost of some $6000. This building has given increased facilities for the work, and has much increased the comfort of the inmates; but it is still too small for the actual needs of the work, especially in regard to the accommodation for school purposes. Last summer the per capita grant from the Government was increased to $72, which does not nearly meet the expenditure, and there has been nothing wherewith to provide comfortable furnishings for the building. The late Rev Geo. McDougall had for years in contemplation the establishment of an Orphanage in the North-West, chiefly for the benefit of the numerous children who had been left friendless by the smallpox epidemic, and was about taking definite steps in the matter when his tragic death occurred. Two or three years later the enterprise was taken up by his son, the Rev John McDougall, with no other assistance than such as was voluntarily given by friends of the Indians in the Methodist Church; the Missionary Board feeling unable to make an annual grant in view of the other claims of the work. Land was occupied with the consent of the Government, and application was made for a grant of some two sections, so as to afford sufficient room for a cattle ranch. Mr. McDougall proceeded with the work, fencing in a large portion of the land, erecting a small building, supplied some live stock, and opened the Home for the reception of orphan children. This was all done largely at his own expense, and from the time the enterprise began until the autumn of last year he expended some $2,500 more than he had received from all sources. Sometime after the Orphanage was opened the Government made an annual per capita grant of $60 for a certain number of pupils, and over a year ago erected a new building at a cost of some $6000. This building has given increased facilities for the work, and has much increased the comfort of the inmates; but it is still too small for the actual needs of the work, especially in regard to the accommodation for school purposes. Last summer the per capita grant from the Government was increased to $72; does not nearly meet the expenditure, and there has been nothing wherewith to provide comfortable furnishings for the building. The future of this Institute will doubtless be fully considered at the next meeting of the General Board of Missions; and it has been suggested that it be taken over from Mr. McDougall, and be made a part of the regular
work of the Missionary Society. In view of this possibility it is very desirable there should be a clear understanding between the Government and the Missionary Society. We think that this Institute should be put on the same basis, and brought under the same Government control as other Industrial Institutes in the North-West. I should have said that years ago the Government promised to give us a patent of the land occupied; but if the change I have indicated should be brought about, then I presume the land as well as the buildings would be the property of the Government.

What I would suggest is that the Indian Department take the Morley Orphanage as one of their regular Industrial Institutes, make provision for the present indebtedness, say $2,500, and provide on a more liberal scale for its future maintenance. It is impossible to carry on such an Institute with a per capita grant of only $72, which is very much lower than is given to some other Institutes in the North-West. If such an arrangement is found impracticable, then as an alternative I would propose that the Government give us, as formerly promised, a patent for the land, and make a grant to provide increased schoolroom accommodation, also lavatories and bathrooms, and increase the per capita grant to not less than $100. The first suggestion would be the best, because, on the one hand, we cannot incur the expense of enlarging or erecting buildings on Government land that we do not own, while, on the other hand, the Government would not be willing to expend money on land owned by the Missionary Society. If the Orphanage is assumed by the Government, then it would be easy through their own agents, say the Commissioner for the North-West, to examine Mr. McDougall's accounts, and satisfy themselves as to the amount which he has actually expended over and above the entire receipts, and then they would be in a position to say how much
should be allowed in settlement of his claim.

I enclose herewith part of a letter, with sketch of the building attached, received from Mr Bubler who, under Mr McDougall's direction, is in charge of the Orphanage. I may say that in a letter from Mr McDougall he expresses the opinion that the per capita grant should not be less than $110.

My Dear Doctor,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo re Orphanage. I would call your attention to our school accommodation which is inadequate to meet our present requirements. I am informed that when last the Government Inspector visited this Institution he condemned it on account of its being so small. It is also very important and necessary that we have at once lavatories and bath rooms for boys and girls. I feel quite sure that if the matter were brought before the Government steps would at once be taken to remedy this state of things.

We have no laundry, all our washing has to be done in the kitchen. You will see by the plan enclosed how inadequate the kitchen is for general kitchen work alone; the building is only 18 x 24, with a pantry taken off 6 x 8, and basement steps 3 ft 6 in x 8.

I may say that it is our intention to have more land under cultivation this spring, and also in the future to launch out into the dairy business; it should prove quite a source of income. The outlay will be very small. We will require stables for winter; most of the work we can do ourselves.

Yours Faithfully,

Dear Mr. Orr:

I beg to advise that I have today issued the Final Certificate for $5527.18 to Messrs Smith Bros. & Wilson, Ltd., for full payment of their contract price of $26,629.30 and authorized extras of $2,161.80. This Certificate includes the 10% holdback which was maintained when previous payments were made.

This Final Certificate would have been issued sooner but for the fact that several vouchers were lacking when the contractors rendered me their statement of the account, and only last night were these vouchers received by me.

I enclose herewith the contractors' complete detailed statement of their contract and extras, from which you will see how the amount of the Certificate is arrived at. You will note that I have deducted $65.00 for "Extra re-work at Church." I had no authority to include this item, and on questioning the contractors concerning its inclusion in their statement, they told me that Mr. Pringle, the Indian Agent, would take care of this charge, and it is with the contractors' consent that I am deleting it from their statement.

I have gone over the account carefully, and it is correct. The various items making up the extras are properly vouched. The only vouchers lacking are the timesheets for the labour performed on the extra work, and the contractors inform me that they are not in a position to furnish separate timesheets for this, but as the charges for labour are not excessive, I have endorsed the account as rendered.

The credit of $5.00 on the electrical fixtures results from the cost of these being $5.00 less than the allowance for same in the specifications.

I enclose invoices which apply to the various extras. On the whole, I may say, the contract has been satisfactorily carried out.

Dear Mr. Scott,

I beg to inform you that I left here on August 28th, to visit some of the Western Agencies. The first point visited was Morley. My object in going to this point was particularly to see the new school, which was recently built and opened.

The building has been erected without eavestroughing, which is a great mistake, as the paint around the bottom is being spattered, and there is a danger of dampness going through and making the basement unfit for use. This eavestroughing should be put on without delay. I have not the exact figures as to the cost of this as yet, but it will not be very great.

W. M. Graham,

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

You will remember that the Department signed an agreement with the Calgary Power Company for the lighting of the Indian Residential School and the Agency Buildings at Morley, Alta. The current charges were to be met by Vote II for the agency and the school management for the institution. The school pays $50.00 per month.

The Superintendent of Methodist Indian Schools and Hospitals has drawn my attention to an educational programme on this reserve, for which they have no assistance from the Department. A number of Indian children attend the residential school classroom as day pupils and the school management is providing a teacher and a heated classroom without assistance from us. You will remember that the classroom used for the Morley Institution is the church building.

I wish to recommend that the Department make a grant of the electric light current expenses, or $50 per month, to the school management for this day school activity and that Mr. Indian Agent Pringle be instructed to make the accounts of the Calgary Power Company to Ottawa for payment, so they could be charged to Vote II and Indian Education Vote in the ratio of 2 to 3. This proportion of the cost has been determined by the Power Company, the Indian Agent and the Principal as a fair division.

Dear Mr. Shaw:

I have your letter of the 31st ultimo, with reference to conditions at the Morley Indian Residential School. It is true that the accommodation at this institution is not sufficient for the children of school age on the reserve. It has been the intention to transfer the older pupils to our school at Edmonton, where an intensive training in farming is offered. The Edmonton Institution is conducted by the same church authorities, who fully concur in this proposal.

Concerning classroom facilities, I propose to erect a suitable two-roomed building next year. In the interim, the church is serving the purpose. It has been fitted up with desks and other classroom equipment.

I cannot understand the report that the barns are not satisfactory. Mr. Commissioner Graham of Regina had this in hand last year, and the records of the Department show that suitable accommodation for stock has already been provided. Some weeks ago, an expenditure for suitable fencing of the property was authorized.

Yours faithfully,

Joseph T. Shaw, Esq., LL.B.,
Short, Ross, Shaw & Haywood,
Calgary, Alta.
The Sect.,
Dept. Indian Affairs.

Dear Sir;

I would like to urge again for the immediate consideration of your Dept. that some attention be given to the very inadequate educational facilities on the Morley Reserve. While on every other Reserve practically in Alberta there is room and to spare for all children wishing to enter into a Residential school here we have a waiting list of between thirty and forty, with absolutely no prospect of being able to do anything for them. While a small waiting list may be a good thing to have there is no justification for keeping almost half the children of this Reserve out of school. If consideration cannot be given at once to extra accommodation at the boarding school could not the Dept. at least give us class room accommodation. If two Class Rooms could be provided it would be at least possible to alleviate our problem.

It was understood some time ago that this matter would be considered. Could it now be reconsidered? If it has been shelved and the matter dealt with so that the class rooms could be in use for the fall term.

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, with reference to the lack of accommodation at the Morley Indian Residential School. I regret that it will not be possible to give favorable consideration to an addition to the school at the present time. The advisability of providing a building of two classrooms will not be overlooked as the Department prepares its Estimates for next year.

Concerning the lack of accommodation, I wish to refer to earlier correspondence with reference to the advisability of grading the more advanced pupils to the Edmonton Indian Residential School. You should also seriously consider transferring any whose parents are willing to let them go, no matter what age, and also those children who are orphans.

The circular letter issued by your Dept. with regard to fire escape and fire fighting facilities at Indian School prompts me to make several requests of you with regard to the Morley Residential School. While our fire escape facilities are on the whole adequate we have next to nothing with which to combat a fire. Our water supply is such that we can never have a reserve of more than 4500 gallons and such are the conditions that within five minutes our tank would be empty and we would be unable to force water through the building for another hour at least. Under these circumstances and bearing in mind further that ours is a wooden building I would request the Dept. to provide at least twelve large chemical fire extinguishers, four for each floor of the building. Two of these should be larger than the other ten to be placed adjacent to the two furnace rooms.

I would also ask that six lights be placed, two by the entrance porch at the front, two by the back doors of the building and two above the fire escape platform. All doors leading into the building have to be approached by a flight of steps, and in the dark, in the event of the slightest panic a disastrous piling up of children might result.

Thanking you for your attention to these matters,

Yours truly,

[Signature]

I have the honour to report that on my recent trip to Alberta, in company with Dr. Murray, the Agent from the Sarcee, who is at present Acting Agent for the Stony Reserve, I spent a day at the latter agency and school. I found that Dr. Murray had made all the necessary arrangements for the building of the two classrooms, and had secured prices on all the material, as well as getting several tenders on the erection, and picking out a site for the building, which I went over and approved of. Everything at the school was in good order, and I must say they have an excellent garden, which is something new up in that part of the country. ED REGINA, SASK. July 5th, 1929.

Inspector Christiasson's Report on the Indian Residential School, Stony Agency.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to report that while at the Stony Agency I inspected the Residential School there, and I must say that I found everything in A shape. The building, from top to bottom, was clean and tidy. The furniture was well arranged and has been well cared for. The same can be said about everything inside the school. It shows that proper care is being given to the building. The grounds were also in good shape and an effort is being made to beautify them. Some shrubs and flowers have been planted in front of the school, earth having been hauled, but I must say that this is some proposition here as a wind comes up and blows everything away.

The children all appeared to be in the best of health and looked as if they were well cared for.

The school planted a large garden just below the hill right by the school. They also broke considerable land for potatoes up on the side hill above the school. The night before I arrived they had a frost which killed most of the potato tops. They will probably come back, but the potatoes will no doubt be small.

The school has a very nice herd of milk cows and they are getting abundance of milk, which is given to the children. One thing I was pleased to note was

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
was that the children all get butter twice a day. I wish this could be said of more of our schools.

Additional stable room is required which should be provided for in the Estimates this coming year.

In my opinion it would be economy to have the school and outbuildings painted this coming year.

One thing that is badly needed at this school is a frigidaire as they really have no place where they can keep anything in the way of perishable food supplies, and if possible, this should be provided for in next year's Estimates.

The school was filled to capacity as far as pupils are concerned, and I believe about ten or eleven children have been attending school and living at home.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Dr. Scott:

Mr. Staley, the Principal of the Indian Residential School at Morley, has just written me saying that the Department of Indian Affairs is asking the Church to be responsible for the electric light account amounting to $360 per year, this account being previously paid by the Department of Indian Affairs.

We appreciate very highly the generosity of the Department of Indian Affairs in providing the salary of the additional teacher necessary to care for the day pupils, but we still believe that the Department should also continue to pay this electric light account. The Church gives a large grant to maintain this School, and we feel sure that the excellent work that it does should commend itself to the Department of Indian Affairs. Although the grant towards the teacher's salary is $750 a year, yet the teacher's board and the additional amount required for fuel for this extra room reduces the grant from the Department by a very substantial amount.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INSPECTOR MACGREGOR,
DATED OCTOBER 3, 1930, ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE
BORLEY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

Original on File 119-1-6.

It will be noted that, while there are desks for only sixty pupils, there are seventy-six enrolled. A table and chairs in the junior room have been provided to accommodate eight additional pupils. This leaves eight pupils for whom there is no accommodation, if all of those enrolled were present at the same time. Furthermore, I am advised by the Principal that there are some forty pupils of school age on the reserve who are not attending school on account of the fact that there is no accommodation for them, neither in the school nor in the residence. It would appear that the matter of additional accommodation should receive attention at an early date so that those now without any educational facilities could be provided for by September next, at least. The present two-roomed school can easily be remodelled to provide two additional classrooms, which additional accommodation seems necessary if all of the pupils on the reserve are to be afforded some educational advantages.
Sir:

I am enclosing herewith a report on the Morley Indian Residential School, which was inspected by Mr. J. A. MacGregor on October 3rd.

You will note that the Inspector in his report speaks well of the school, and states that there are 76 pupils enrolled.

He points out that there are about forty children of school age on this reserve who are not attending school. His information is of course received from Mr. Staley, and I do not think it is exactly correct, as I understand there are about 25 or 30.

The question of enlarging the school is one that should be considered by the Department, and I believe we could provide the necessary accommodation for additional pupils at a cost of about $12,000.00. However, I do not think it was within the province of Inspector MacGregor to comment on this.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to enclose herewith a report of a visit made to the Stony Indian Residential School by Mr. Christianson. You will note that everything in connection with the institution seems to be in good shape.

I am not satisfied, however, with the Principal's reply to the Inspector when he asked whether the girls were milking cows - that they did once in a while. They should milk them regularly, during the summer time at least, and I am writing him to this effect.

It is true that I received a request from Mr. Hinton, asking that the dormitories be re-floored. I told myself it was a most extraordinary request when the school was only built a short time ago. You will note what the Inspector says - that he found holes where they had been neglectful, but this can be repaired for a small sum. It just shows how much reliance can be placed on the recommendations of some people. The work is being done.

Yours very truly,

REGINA, SASK., Jan. 14th, 1931.

Inspector Christianson's Report on the Stony Indian Residential School.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to report that on my last visit to the Stony Agency, I inspected the Residential School. There were 70 children in residence, but as there is not sufficient room in the school for that number of children, 5 girls were sleeping in the Principal's residence.

Everything at this institution was in good shape. The children all looked healthy, and at the time of my visit the teachers were preparing for the Christmas concert.

A new addition to the stable was built last summer, and they now have sufficient stable room to take care of their stock. They have 18 milk cows, 9 of which were milking at the time of my inspection.

I made enquiries from the Principal as to whether the girls milked the cows, and was informed that they only did this once in a while. However, he informed me that as soon as spring came, he would see that the girls did the milking during the warm weather.

The buildings are all in a good state of repair, with the exception of the floors in the dormitories. I believe you received a letter from Mr. Hinton asking that the two dormitories be re-floored. I went into this matter, and found that the small castors on the beds have worn the floors; this is caused by the movement of the beds back and forth.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
forth. There are about two boards at the wall and about three boards at the foot of the beds which are badly worn—some of them right through to the under flooring. All that is necessary is to have these boards taken out and new ones put in. There were some carpenters working on the residence for the Mounted Police, which was being erected there, so I had one of them over, and he informed me that he could take out the boards that were worn, put in new ones, and it would be just as satisfactory as if it were re-floored. This would only mean a small expenditure, and it should be carried out.

I am of the opinion that it would be money well spent if the Department furnished the school with castor shoes. I note that they are quoted at 20¢ for a set of four in Eaton's catalogue.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, January 21, 1931.

Sir:

I have your 409-11 of the 15th instant, enclosing the report of Mr. Inspector Christianson on his recent inspection of the Morley Indian Residential School.

In this connection I have to say that the Department is pleased to note that general conditions at this school are satisfactory. Your action in having the floors in the dormitories repaired is approved. In order that the casters on the beds will not again wear out the flooring, the Department will approve of the supplying of caster shoes, which, the Inspector states, can be obtained at a cost of 20 cents per bed, and I shall be pleased if you will arrange for the purchase and instruct the Principal to have same properly installed.

It is noted that you will take up with the Principal the matter of having the girls given proper instruction in milking. It is considered that the girls should milk the cows regularly during the summer months at least.

Sir:

I beg to bring to your attention that while at the Stony Agency, Morley, last Monday, I paid a visit to the school, inspecting the buildings, &c. The Reverend Mr. Staley drew to my attention that the floors throughout most of the building were in very poor shape. Being ordinary fir floors, the Department will realize that with several boys and girls continually tramping around the school, it does not take long to wear them out.

I pointed out to Mr. Staley that as far as I knew the amount allowed for repairs to schools was very limited, and we would have to try to get along with as little as possible. This, of course, the Principal is quite prepared to do, and the floors will be left as they are for another year. In parts where they are more worn than others, such as the boys' dormitory and the dining room, patches will be put in, and they can get along without any expense in that connection.

If there is any money available, over and above what it takes to pay the grant, it would certainly be very much appreciated if the school were furnished with a new kitchen range. The one now in use has never been suitable from the first; It is too small for the purpose for which it was intended, and is so badly burned out that it does not warrant repair.

I might also bring to your attention that this school was never furnished with a refrigerator, and naturally they have always had difficulty in keeping their food supplies cool in the summer. The Principal purchased an electric refrigerator for $300.00, on monthly instalments, and I think it would only be fair if the Department could so arrange it, to pay something towards this. If there are no funds available, of course the Principal will have to go on paying his monthly instalments, and either they will have to

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
get along with the range they have now, or the Church authorities will have to buy a new one.

The building as a whole is in a first class state of repair, and has been well kept up. The staff and the boys have done considerable painting in the interior, and the premises as a whole are certainly well looked after. The school has about 35 acres of green feed and their garden is excellent; it will supply the school with sufficient potatoes and other vegetables, providing they do not have an early frost. The potatoes froze off about a month ago, which probably retarded the growth, but at the time of my visit Monday, the garden looked exceptionally good.

Mr. Staley is running a good school. The children are well fed and well looked after in every way. From year to year the church authorities in the East have to put up considerable money over and above the grant to finance the school, as nothing can be earned here: No farming can be done and only enough cattle to supply the school with milk, &c., can be raised. The schools where farming and stock raising, &c., is carried on are certainly in a different position. Therefore, I think it would be only fair if this school were furnished with a range, and even a small sum provided to partly pay for the refrigerator.

Sir:

I have the honor to report on an inspection of the Indian Residential School at Morley, where I spent the best part of a day this week.

At the time of my inspection I found that there were 75 children in residence there. As the classroom work in this school has been recently inspected by the Provincial School Inspector, I need not dwell on this part of the work and more than to say that we have two splendid teachers at this institution, and good progress is being made in the classroom work.

The children are bright and looked exceptionally well. They are well clothed, and outside of the classroom work the children engage in different sports. A rink is maintained throughout the winter, which is boarded in on all sides, and is located just below the hill, right near the school, and only a short distance from the C.P.R. pump station, where they get water to flood the rink, and the Calgary Power Company are giving the school the power free of charge, for lights on the rink.

A hockey league has been formed on the reserve, and besides this the boys from the school play teams from Calgary, Cochrane, etc.

As the Department are aware no farming is carried on at this school on account of the soil on the Reserve not being fit to carry on farming. They put in some green feed and a large garden. Last summer the potatoes were a failure, on account of a heavy frost in June and July, which froze off the tops and the crop did not amount to anything. They raised 40 ton of turnips, 2 ton of carrots and a ½ ton of beets, and all other kinds of garden truck such as onions, parsnips, peas, etc.

The school maintains a herd of 35 cattle, practically all cows, so the school has ample milk, and several cows are due to freshen shortly, so there is no shortage of milk at this institution. The school also keeps chickens and a few hogs, sufficient to take care of the refuse etc. from the school.
As no farming operations are carried on at this Reserve it is not possible to teach the boys anything in that nature, but the boys are taught all the possible carpenter work that is done around the building, and to look after a garden, milk cows etc. The girls are taught along the same lines as in other Indian institutions of this kind. Cooking, sewing, and general housework.

The main school building and the two classrooms are in good state of repairs, with the exception of floors wearing out in the main building. The Department are aware that the out-buildings at this school are a very miserable affair. The stable serves the purpose at the present time, although it is very small, but the other out-buildings are practically useless. I trust some provision is being made in the Estimates for some repairs to the floors in the main building. The floors are pitch-grain fir, and the Department are aware that as there are a great many children tramping over the floors every day, and the floors being of a soft wood, that they soon wear out. This will again be brought to the attention of the Department after the end of the year.

When the holidays come around the two furnaces need to be over-hauled by a competent furnace man. The electric wiring in the school should also be gone over next summer, as there are some short circuits in the wires evidently, as a lot of fuses burn out from time to time.

The staff consists of the principal, the Reverend Mr. Staley, J.Hogarth as laborer, and Mr. and Mrs. E.Sheppard as teachers. Mrs. J.Rich, Matron; Mrs. N.Magee, seamstress; Miss L.Landale, laundress; Mrs. E.McGee, cook.

From my observations the staff at this institution are efficient, and rendering good work. In conclusion I wish to state that in my opinion this is a very good institution. The children are well cared for in every way, and good results are being obtained by the school, as far as it is possible to do so.

Mr. Staley brought to my attention that the school only received a grant for 65 children, although there are 75 children in residence. Five of these are sleeping upstairs in the principal's residence. I am bringing this matter to the attention of the Deputy Superintendent General by special letter.

Your obedient servant,

M.Christianson
Inspector of Indian Agencies

Sir:

I beg to inform you that today Mr. Staley came in to see me in connection with the hot water tank at his school. At the present time Dr. Murray is attending the Medical Convention here in the city, and he was unable to get in touch with him.

It seems that yesterday the hot water tank which supplies the hot water for the building, cracked open at one of the seams. As the tank evidently in some way controls the whole water supply at the school, the building is without water at the present time. Mr. Staley also informed me that the girls' end of the basement, where the tank is, is flooded, and he pointed out that something would have to be done. I authorized him to get in touch with an electric welder at Chochrane, the nearest town to the school, and get him to weld the seam in question. If he is successful in doing this the tank may last for sometime yet, and it would save the purchase of a new one, which, I believe, would cost over $100.00.

The cost of welding the present boiler will not be very great and I trust the Department will approve of the action I have taken in this matter.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of the Department's letter No. 119-1-5 of the 19th instant in connection with the hot water tank required for the boarding school at Morley. I am sure when the Department received two telegrams on the same subject they had every reason to believe that something was wrong with the administration here.

What actually happened was that Dr. Murray called me up about 10.00 P.M. Saturday advising me that the tank had just burst open and that something would have to be done to install a new tank as the school would be without water. I informed him that I would wire the Department on Sunday, which I did. Shortly after I received the Department's letter yesterday, Dr. Murray was in the office here and I asked him for an explanation; He claims that over the phone he understood me to say that he was to wire. This accounts for the two wires being send, and I am sure that I told him quite distinctly that I would send the wire. However, I have no reason to believe anything but that he misinterpreted what I said. I am sorry that the Department were put to the expense of paying for two wires instead of one.

Sir:-

I am in receipt of your letter of the 14th instant enquiring as to the feasibility of enlarging the day school running in connection with the residential school.

The six pupils shown in day school are actually in residence. Mr. Staley has found it possible to do this by putting six pupils in the attic of his own home.

I may state that the day school idea has not been found satisfactory on this reserve. The Stonys are by nature hunters. In the fall of the year about three quarters of the tribe leave the reserve to hunt for about two months, and take their whole families. This winter many families have been hunting squirrels off the reserve for the greater part of the winter. During such times the children would be out of school.

It has also been found here that when the families are at home, the attendance at day school has been so irregular as to be almost useless. That was the reason for Mr. Staley taking as many pupils in to his house as he could reasonably accommodate.

From enquiries I have made I believe 50 children more would be eager to go into residence. This is due not so much to a thirst for knowledge, as to the desire of the parents to have the children fed and clothed. Most of the parents are too apathetic toward a day school to cooperate in the matter of attendance.

For the above reasons, I would not recommend a day school here; in fact, I believe the system would be better left as at present. There is, however, a real need of further residential school accommodation.

Your obedient servant,

W. Barr Murray

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on a recent inspection of the Morley Indian Residential School. While there I went thoroughly into all matters pertaining to the management of the school, care of children, food, &c.

BUILDINGS:— The buildings, both school and outbuildings are kept in a first class state of repair. The Principal showed me a stock of paint that he had on hand and the interior of the building is painted as required from time to time. The boys do the work. At the time of my visit the boys' dormitory was being painted, both walls and ceiling. This naturally keeps the buildings in a good state of repair, and the only replacement necessary at this institution is the flooring in the boys' dormitory and dining room which is in very bad shape. I believe this matter was brought to the attention of the Acting Superintendent of Indian Education when he was there last fall. Therefore it is not necessary for me to dwell on this matter here, any more than to say that

Doctor Harold W. McGill,

Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs

OTTAWA.
Buildings. (Continued).—
if there are any funds available this coming year, this work could be done during the summer holidays. However, if the Department have not the funds the school will simply have to get along without the new flooring.

The machinery in the school was in a good state of repair and well taken care of. The only thing that I noticed had gone out of order was the well, about which I wrote the Department a few days ago, but this had been repaired when I was there.

The furnishings of the school were all in good order and seemed to be well taken care of.

Training outside of classroom work.—
In receiving instructions in household science the girls are divided into five groups: No. 1, that is the youngest girls, do sewing from 8.30 to 9.00 in the morning and on Fridays from 2.30 to 4.00. The other groups, 2, 3, 4, and 5, are handled in a similar manner, certain hours of the day being set aside for sewing. I saw the work the girls were doing and was very well pleased with what I saw. I also noticed that the girls worked in the kitchen and laundry. Washing is done every morning with the exception of Sunday, and they have a White girl, Miss Lansdale, as Laundress. Different girls are detailed each morning to assist her in the laundry, and also to do the ironing in the afternoon. The girls
Training (Continued):

ALSO do the mending of the school. The older girls help in the kitchen and receive instructions in cooking; and I was told by those in charge of the various departments that every girl was taught everything in the way of housekeeping, cooking, scrubbing floor and general household duties before leaving the school. It would appear that the girls are getting a very fair training in this work. Of course, as the Department knows, most of the bread used at the school is purchased from outside and the washing is done with modern laundry equipment. Still, every girl is taught to bake bread and wash by hand, which is very essential, as they will not have machinery to work with when they leave the school.

The outside training that the boys receive is, of course, very limited, as no farming is carried on there. Both boys and girls help with the garden, and the boys milk cows and look after the stock.

CLOTHING AND FOOD:

Ample clothing is supplied to the children. The girls all have four or five changes of dresses. In the winter they are supplied with woollen and fleece-lined underwear, and all have winter coats. The girls wear moccasins and rubbers in the winter time. The moccasins are made by the Indians and purchased by the school. The girls make most of their clothing and their dresses were very nice. Of course the Department will understand
Clothing & Food (Continued):

that occasionally the Principal has an opportunity of buying a job lot of dresses at a very low price, which he does, but this does not happen very often, so that most of the dresses are made by the girls themselves under the instruction of the seamstress. The girls knit the mitts for the school and also some stockings, and most of them can do embroidery work as well.

The boys were all well dressed and their everyday clothes consist of sweaters, overalls and a wind-breaker if it is cold. Woollen and fleece-lined underwear, woollen stockings and heavy gum-rubber shoes in winter and running shoes in the summer time. The boys also have good warm overcoats, caps, mitts, &c.

I was at the institution when the children sat down to lunch, and went into the question of food. I was informed that breakfast, as a rule, consists of porridge, milk and sugar, bread, butter, jam, honey or syrup, and tea; and twice a week they give the children cereals instead of the porridge. Dinner consists of two vegetables, meat in some form, bannock, pudding or pie, water and milk. Supper consists of weaners, sausages or cold meat and sometimes fish; pork and beans, peas, or peas and pork, bread and butter or biscuits; cake and fruit, tea; and sometimes they are given an apple apiece after supper. The food of course varies from time to time, but this is the main issue.
HEALTH & GENERAL:

The children looked exceptionally well and there was no illness amongst them. There were 76 children in residence and as the Department is aware, this is more than are provided for in the grant, and I believe 5 or 6 of the girls sleep over in the Principal's house. I also took special note that each child had a tooth brush and an individual towel both upstairs and down, and I enquired particularly as to whether the children were using the tooth brushes, and found that they were actually using them. I have often been at schools where the tooth brushes were never used.

For recreation the children have skating rink on a flat below the school which is boarded in and lit electrically, and all are furnished with skates. They also play other outdoor games such as football, &c., so they get lots of exercise.

As I previously mentioned, the outbuildings, although not in conformity with the school, are kept in a good state of repair. The cow and horse stable is kept well whitewashed inside, both walls and stalls.

The school owns 24 head of cows and at the time of my inspection there were 11 cows milking, and about 5 pails were milked per day. They make 24 pounds of butter per week and a great deal is made during the holidays while most of the children are away. Besides this the school purchases a quantity of butter
GENERAL (Continued).-

The children receiving butter with their bread twice every day is something that is done at very few schools. They may give them fat of a kind, but actually giving them butter used to be unheard of. I am glad to note as I go around, that butter is being given to the children in several of the schools. The school also has 6 horses, 6 pigs and 40 chickens. The Department will understand that it would not pay the school to raise many hogs as they do not raise any feed, so they just keep enough to take care of the leavings from the school.

On the whole the work carried on at this institution is very satisfactory. They have a good competent staff and the children are well cared for. Personally I have no criticism to offer of anything I saw there.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

Mr. R. Gurney Orr,
Architects' Department,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Orr:

For the last five weeks I have been in Western Canada and the other day had the opportunity of going carefully over the School at Morley, Alberta. Fortunately, the plans for the extension had arrived and I had the chance to discuss them in detail with Mr. Staley. There are a few suggestions I should like to make after having studied the plans in the building itself rather than from the blue print. These will not add appreciably to the cost and will make no difference in the letting of the contracts.

I think that the dispensary and the principal's office should be exchanged moving the principal into the inside room. It would be very much easier for the nurse to carry on in the room opening off the hall than it would be for the principal to have the children passing through his office every afternoon in order to get to the nurse.

There is no provision made in the present plans for lockers, but with the enlarged play rooms for both boys and girls, I think that some type of cheap lockers should be put in. The school is also tremendously short of cupboard space. I would appreciate it when you are on the ground if you would discuss this important matter with Mr. Staley and the matron.

In connection with the sewing room to which I objected on the original plans because I felt it was going to be too dark, I have changed my mind, as the three windows which are in the present sewing room seem to give adequate light.

There are no separate bathroom and toilet facilities for the staff in the present building and I should like to request that the room marked "store room" on your present plans should be turned into a bathroom for the staff.

By putting a few locked cupboards or even open shelves around the walls of the new sewing room, I think you could secure all the storage facilities needed, in view of the fact that there will be two other small rooms available in the building when the alterations are completed which are not now in use for that purpose.

I wish it were possible also in connection with the work which is being done to put a rough floor into the attic as was done in connection with
the Norway House School. That provides excellent storage facilities for the heavy winter clothing and bedding during the summer and for any extra stock which the principal has an opportunity to buy when the market is good. At the present time he has to buy in small quantities because of lack of such a store room.

While you are at Morley, I would like to get your expert opinion in regard to the possibility of providing running water in the principal's residence. Four or five years ago I discussed this with Mr. Russell Ferrier who was enthusiastic about it. Our proposition at that time was to pipe the water from the present school supply which seems to be quite ample for the purpose. There are those who feel, however, that it would be cheaper and more satisfactory to dig a well close to the house and put in a small electric pump on account of the great difficulty of digging drains of the necessary depth through the hard gravel of those hillsides. If you have time, I would appreciate getting an estimate as to what you think both types of equipment would cost. I feel that having put in fifteen years in that house without running water, the principal's wife is entitled to immediate consideration from both the Department of Indian Affairs and the Board of Home Missions in this particular.

Thanking you for your co-operation and with very kind personal regards, I am,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

KJB/DM.

Sir:

I am requested by the principal of the Residential School, Rev. E.J. Staley, to report that the furnace in the Classroom building is inadequate. Since it was first installed it has been impossible to heat the building. It is only a small furnace, which is apparently the reason that it is unsatisfactory.

When the new heating plant is installed in the residence building, it will replace the two old furnaces at present in use. One of them is in good condition as to brick and grates, and it would undoubtedly heat the classroom building satisfactorily. The Anderson Plumbing Co., who are putting the new heating plant in the Residence building, have quoted $69 to change the furnace in the classrooms. It would be such a great advantage to have this done, that I beg your authority to do it.

In connection with the same building, it is reported to me by Mr. Gardiner-Smith, that the floor is not sufficiently supported, in fact that it is unsafe. One person walking across the floor causes it to swing, as was demonstrated to me. There is one beam supporting the joists, in the centre, and it is 36 feet from this beam to the foundation on either side. Two more beams with posts, under the joists, would make it solid. I am assured by Mr. Gardiner-Smith, that the cost will be under $25, as beams will be made out of waste lengths of plank from the construction now going on. I beg to suggest that this be done while we have carpenters out here.

Your obedient servant,

SPECIFICATION

MODEL "C"

CANADIAN IRON STOKER

HOPPER:

To be made of Copper Steel, Heavy Gauge, Rust Treated, with a capacity of 500 pounds of coal. The body to be close riveted and to have extended flanges on the bottom for bolting to the base. An agitator within the hopper will prevent the arching of the coal and insure a steady flow of coal to the fire.

HOPPER BASE:

The Hopper Base shall be of Cast Iron, Heavy Section, and ribbed to make a rigid base for the machine. It shall be flanged outward, properly supplied with an asbestos gasket and have bolted thereto the Hopper in a manner that shall insure a leak-proof joint.

CONVEYOR:

The Conveyor Screw shall be a one piece casting of Manganese Steel, properly annealed, and shall be of a length to suit the installation. It shall be enclosed in a steel housing which shall form the food connection between the Hopper Base and the Retort.

RETORT:

The Retort shall be made of Cast Iron, 14" wide by 31" long, of heavy section, and designed to withstand the heat of combustion. The top portion will be made up of heavy sectional Square Blocks, opening through which will permit of withdrawing of the ash from the pan, ample for permission of the coal bed below as well as through the fire zone. These Square Blocks are designed to be readily renewable. Trough shaped Interlocking Head plates, supported upon the Retort are furnished of the proper size to fit the furnace. A cleanout door will be conveniently placed providing access below the Retort.
SPECIFICATION

MODEL "C"

GEAR REDUCTION:

The Gear Reductions for the proper reduction of speed between the Motor and the Conveyor shall comprise a quiet triple reduction and provide three speeds to the Conveyor and which shall be equal to 50 pounds, 100 pounds, and 150 pounds per hour respectively, also a neutral, and shall be so designed as to permit changes of speeds while the machine is operating, noiselessly, and by the most approved design of shifting mechanism. The Worm Gear shall be hobbed from Hard Phosphor Bronze, and other Gears shall be made from an Alloy Steel and Bearings of Bronze. S.A.F. Ball Thrust Bearings will be supplied on the Worm Shaft. The Base will be of Cast Iron and be oil tight and a suitable oil gauge will be provided at a convenient position on the Case. A safety shear pin, conveniently replaceable, will be provided in the Drive to protect the machine against overloads. Connection to the Motor will be made by means of a "V" Belt.

ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT:

The Motor shall be one of approved make, 3/4 Horsepower capacity and guaranteed to take care of the maximum load and be equipped with Service Switch and an approved type of Circuit Breaker.

FAN:

The Fan will be of the balanced centrifugal type with single delivery and will be enclosed in an aluminum housing with a well-designed shutter for efficient control of the air supply. The duct leading from the fan to the retort will be made of Copper Bearing Steel as a preventive against rust. An auxiliary air duct prevents back smoking.

CONTROLS:

A thermostat for the automatic control of the room temperature shall form a part of this specification, also a boiler control for the safe regulation of the boiler from excess pressure. The Thermostat, which is intended to be conveniently located and in one of the rooms to be heated, shall be of an approved make and designed to function within a few degree variation in temperatures; that is to say when there is a call for heat or when the desired temperature is reached the thermostatic control electrically connects or disconnects the Motor.
SPECIFICATION

GUARDS:

Proper guards shall be provided for protection of all moving parts.

INSTALLATION:

In the event of the installation being hired to the manufacturer, each installation shall provide for a pit properly walled and floored with suitable mixture of fine gravel sand and cinders located in a manner which will permit of the location of the Stoker on the side of the boiler. All brickwork, material and labor necessary to the proper installation of the equipment, including wiring and location of the Controls, shall be understood to be a part of the installation. The installing Engineer, upon completion of the installation, shall place the machine in practical operation and shall furnish the Staff with all reasonable instructions for the efficient management and control of the equipment.

GUARANTEE:

The equipment is guaranteed against all mechanical defects or faulty workmanship for the period of one year.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have made certain enquiries and I believe the stokers are working very satisfactorily and no doubt they are money-savers, as they will burn cheaper coal. You will note that Mr. Low claims the saving will be anywhere from 25% to 53%.

Report on Addition to School, Stony Reserve.

Sir:

Since my Report of a month ago we have been experiencing the most extreme wintry weather for many years, with drifting snowstorms, and phenomenal low temperatures. Under such conditions it was generally impossible to carry on any outside work, and although we had just succeeded in getting the new addition closed in, yet without heat it was almost equally impossible for men to work inside. The result is that for several weeks but little progress has been made on this job. However, our carpentry work had almost reached the stage where it could have been stopped until after the plastering, which cannot be commenced at this season of the year until heat is available. The heating men have been working intermittently whenever the weather was not too severe, and the various heating mains, returns and risers are now being placed, and a fair proportion of this work is well advanced. Two or three days ago a welcome Chinook wind made its long-awaited appearance, and we are now experiencing its genial influence. The temperature today is well above freezing.

The heating boilers have not yet arrived, but are expected shortly. Railway services are greatly disrupted in consequence of serious snow-slides in the mountains, which may delay their shipment. I am sending you a blue print of the boilers we are getting. Owing to somebody making the heating contractor order No. 109, and which I had to reject because of insufficient capacity, we are now getting boilers No. 112, which seem in every way suitable. I have asked that the Provincial Boiler Inspector at Edmonton approve these boilers before they are shipped, and they will be inspected again in the usual course after installation. Mr. Alex. Walker, of Calgary, has been useful to me in checking the proposed boilers, and on heating matters generally.

In my last Report I mentioned that I had had to reject the siding sent because of too many dead knots. The lumber people agreed to take it back, and replace it with No. 1 Coast fir siding. This arrived about two weeks ago, but only recently was it possible to commence putting it in place, because of the very cold weather. However, we have now seen the siding all on, and as the lathing will be completed about the same time, we shall have to await the completion of the plastering before any more carpentry work can be done. However, I can employ the best of the men in placing the inside finish in the new hospital, at which work I already have three good men engaged.

It will probably be about three weeks before the plastering of the school addition can commence, for from present indications it will be fully that time before temporary heat will be available.

I duly received the Architect's telegram accepting Lepper & Co.'s tender for the plumbing required in the school, and I lost no time in notifying this contractor accordingly, and the roughing-in, etc., will, I expect, be done promptly, and in advance of the plastering.
The Reverend Principal has asked that all ceilings in the new addition be metal ceilings similar to that in the main building, with the exception that in the original school the ceilings of the top storey are plastered. The main reason why he wants metal ceilings for the top storey of the addition is because he intends using the attic space there for storage of children's garments when not in use. He has thought that even this light traffic on the small loftists might tend to crack plastered ceilings. As I could see no objection to meeting his wish in this respect, I have had this ceiling sheeted with metal in preparation for the metal. We shall build him a new stairway from the store room of this top storey, giving access to the attic, and shall place a light switch (in conduit) in the attic, with switch controls in said store room, and shall lay a sniplap floor 12 wide the length of the new attic. The cost of this convenience will be but little more than if the ceiling were plastered.

The electrical contractor, Mr. Lloyd Orr, of Calgary, has completed the placing of conduits with light and switch outlets, and panel boxes, bell and gong wiring, etc., and will return when the job is ready to pull his wires and hang the fixtures.

We shall defer the erection of the divisional wall in the present girl's dormitory, also the extension of the plumbing in the existing girl's dormitory until the new dormitory is available, because of the present girl's dormitory being occupied to capacity, there being scarcely walking room between the beds. We shall also defer taking down the existing stairway, and the alterations in that area, until other work is about completed. Our aim is to make as little disturbance and interruption to the operation of the school as possible.

Will you kindly send me another blueprint of the school, as the three copies sent are being used by the various trades, and I am without a copy at present.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

E. Gardner Smith
Building Supervisor.

SPECIFICATION

MODEL "C"

CANADIAN IRON STOKER

HOPPER:

To be made of Copper Steel, Heavy Gauge, Rust Treated, with a capacity of 500 pounds of coal. The body to be close riveted and to have extended flanges on the bottom for bolting to the Base. An agitator within the Hopper will prevent the settling of the coal and insure a steady flow of coal to the fire.

HOPPER BASE:

The Hopper Base shall be of Cast Iron, Heavy Section, and ribbed to make a rigid base for the machine. It shall be flanged outward, properly supplied with an asbestos gasket and have bolted thereto the Hopper in a manner that shall insure a leak-proof joint.

CONVEYOR:

The Conveyor Screw shall be a one piece casting of Manganese Steel, properly annealed, and shall be of a length to suit the installation. It shall be enclosed in a steel housing which shall form the feed connection between the Hopper Base and the Retort.

RETORT:

The Retort shall be made of Cast Iron, 14" wide by 21" long, of heavy section, and designed to withstand the heat of combustion. The top section will be made up of heavy sectional tuyere blocks, opening through which will permit of a distribution of the air from the fan, ample for permeation of the coal bed below as well as the tuyeres. These tuyere blocks are designed to be readily removable. Trough shaped interlocking dead plates supported upon the Retort are furnished of the proper size to fit the furnace. A cemented door will be conveniently placed providing access below the Retort.

IRON STOKER DIVISION
VANCOUVER, BRITISH COLUMBIA

SPECIFICATION

MODEL NO.

GEAR REDUCTION:

The Gear Reduction, for the proper reduction of speed between the Motor and the Conveyor, shall comprise a quiet triple reduction and provide three speeds to the Conveyor and which shall be equal to 50 pounds, 100 pounds, and 150 pounds per hour respectively; also a neutral, and shall be so designed as to permit change of speeds while the machine is operating, noiselessly, and by the most approved design of shifting mechanism. The Worm Gear shall be hobbed from Hard Phosphor Bronze, and other Gears shall be made from an Alloy Steel and Bearings of Bronze. S.K.F. Ball Thrust Bearings will be used on the Worm Shaft. Gear case will be of Cast Iron and be oil tight and a suitable oil gauge will be provided at a convenient position on the Case. A safety shear pin, conveniently replaceable, will be provided in the Drive to protect the machine against overloads. Connection to the Motor will be made by means of a "V" Belt.

ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT:

The Motor shall be one of approved make, 3/4 Horsepower capacity and guaranteed to take care of the maximum load and be equipped with Service Switch and an approved type of Circuit Breaker.

FAN:

The Fan will be of the balanced centrifugal type with ample delivery and will be enclosed in an aluminum housing with a well designed shutter for efficient control of the air supply. The Duct leading from the fan to the retort will be made of Copper Bearing Steel as a preventive against rust. An auxiliary air duct prevents back smoking.

CONTROL:

A thermostat for the automatic control of the room temperature shall form a part of this specification, also a boiler control for the safe regulation of the boiler fire under pressure. The Thermostat, which is intended to be conveniently located and in one of the rooms to be heated, shall be of an approved make and designed to function within a two degree variation in temperature; that is to say when there is a call for heat or when the desired temperature is reached the thermostatic control electrically connects or disconnects the Motor.

Dear Mr. Orr:

Sir:

I beg to bring to your attention that when I was inspecting the Calgary School I noticed that the two doors to the fire escapes were padlocked. I mentioned this to Mr. Staley and pointed out how dangerous this practice was. His explanation was that every member of the staff had a key and there was also an axe in the wall alongside the door to break it in case of a fire, but even this does not satisfy me. I am quite aware that leaving the door unlocked gives instantaneous opportunity of getting into the girls' dormitory, and it is also an invitation for the boys to slip out of the school at night. I would recommend that an alarm system be attached to the doors. We have this, I know, at some of our institutions, and hope the Department will give this immediate consideration.

Your obedient servant,
