Report on Addition to Indian School.

Sir:

Since my Report of January 28th steady progress has been maintained. On the 16th ultimo the plastering of the new addition was completed, and the plasterers (Jonathan & Sons) returned to Calgary. An excellent job of plastering was performed. We supplied all the materials, including excellent sand, cement, etc., and specified and supervised the work for this work, and the plastering was done by day labour, to a strict specification. The plasterers will return to plaster the new partition wall in the existing girls' dormitory, the toilet extension in the same room, and in making good around the existing stairway after removal.

On the 21st of Feb'y the heating contractors, (Anderson Plumbing Co.) completed the installing of the new heating system, and steam heat thus became available for the plumbing work. The domestic immediately following the new heating plant is proving very satisfactory, and the fine new boilers fitted remarkably well into the former furnace room, just neatly filling the furnace pit. As we had to cut a deep opening in the west concrete wall to admit the boiler, the new Principal urged that this opening instead of being closed up again be converted into an outside entrance into the boiler-room which has been done, and this entry is being provided with concrete steps, with roof over, and a further outside door as its outlet from the boiler-room will be most convenient for removing ashes, and permitting bulk articles. As the 24" breeching from the new boilers passes just below the basement ceiling to reach the altered chimney, I deemed it necessary to take unusual measures against fire hazard, and have had the ceiling along this line of breeching entirely insulated with asbestos bricks 12" wide, covered with galvanized iron, with air-space between the insulation and the ceiling. The contractors may make an extra charge for this feature of their work.

The plumbing fixtures have been installed in the new addition to the school, and this branch of the work is completed except in the lavatory extension which we have yet to extend in the existing girls' dormitory. The fixtures are here for that purpose, but the work in doing out the completion of this work is having to be deferred until the lavatory extension can be made. In reorganizing the plumbing and heating of the school, it became necessary to remove the hot water storage tank to the room adjoining the new boilers, also to remove the siphoning pipe at similar location, so as to make a few other minor changes resulting from these removals. The plumbing contractor performed this work very satisfactorily. The east furnace room is being converted into a drying room, with connection to their laundry-room, and provided with radiation. This will be very helpful in drying their washings, especially during severe weather. An extra charge was made by the heating contractor for this feature, as radiators spared from outside rear porches were placed in this room instead.
Carpenters are now doing the finish carpentry in the new addition. We are finishing the top dormitory and adjoining matron's room. These rooms are now completed, and the plumbing in operation, and the painters are painting the metal ceilings, staining and varnishing the trim, and oiling the floors. This fine new dormitory will be ready for occupation within about two or three days, and then the beds will be moved from the existing dormitory and we can proceed with the partition wall across the old dormitory, and build the lavatory extension shown on the plans. Most of the door openings in the new addition are now cased in, and most of the doors hung. The floorboards have been laid in the new addition, and the carpenters will commence laying the floors on the ground floor, and joiners will follow as fast as the carpentry work is ready. After that we shall take down the existing stairs which have to be removed, and install them in the new addition. Then the existing entry and steps will be taken down and moved to their new location to give access to the verandah of the addition.

The sheet-metal workers have completed putting on the metal ceilings of the first and second floors, and are today doing this work in the basement of the new addition. We shall then have a good deal of patching of the metal ceilings to do in the original building, where numerous pipes and risers from the old furnaces passed through the basement ceilings.

We have not yet laid the concrete floor in the new addition, partly because we have utilized this room for storage of materials, and also because the weather has been too severe for mixing concrete outside. All through March the weather has been unusually cold, with zero and sub-zero temperatures. However, we should get milder weather very soon now, and it will not take long to run this floor. Excellent gravel and sand are on hand for this work.

Regarding the outside painting of the new addition, both the Reverend Principal and the Indian Agent would like it to be done in a light grey with red roof, and dark green trim, so as to harmonize with the existing Agency buildings and residences. But the existing school was done in a dark brown with green roof, and as this color is drab and depressing, and also commencing to show age, the wish has been expressed that the old building be painted again, and therefore I will likely be asked to match the colors of the Agency buildings, as stated. Our painting contractor estimates that it would cost $350.00 to paint the old building 2 coats, including the roof and trim, and as I have no authority to make any extra expenditure, I am desirous of the outside painting until the Department instructs me concerning the colors for the new addition. Also, any request for the re-painting of the existing building would more properly come from the local authorities rather than from me. Obviously, however, it would soon be necessary to paint the new addition grey if the former building is to remain brown. I shall, therefore, await your instructions regarding the outside colours for the new addition before ordering the materials.

The work throughout has been carried on without any interruption to the operation of the school, and I have received friendly cooperation from both the Reverend Principal and the Indian Agent. The extension to the building will provide much needed additional accommodation; and the modern heating plant, and additional plumbing facilities make the building quite up to date.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Construction

Your obedient servant,
